DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR J. B. KEEFFE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House of the death on Sunday, 15 May, of Mr James Bernard Keeffe, a former senator. Mr Keeffe represented the State of Queensland from 1965 to 1983. As a mark of respect to the memory of Mr Keeffe, I invite honourable members to rise in their places.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members having stood in their places--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable members will be aware of reports of major civil disturbances in Vanuatu yesterday, 16 May. I wish to make a statement about these developments and my Government's response to them. There was extensive rioting by about 2,000 people in the capital, Vila, in connection with what I believe is a long running land dispute. Reports indicate that one person was killed, a number injured and considerable property damage sustained in the capital. In a city with a population of fewer than 20,000 it is clear that these disturbances have been on a very serious scale.

SPEECH.PARA: At around 10.30 last night the Government received a request, through the Australian High Commission in Vila, from Prime Minister Lini and the Vanuatu Minister for Home Affairs for riot control equipment and material to replenish the stocks available to the Vanuatu authorities in containing the disturbances. Following receipt of the request, I decided to speak personally with Prime Minister Lini to obtain first hand information about the situation in Vila and to discuss the nature of his Government's request. In this conversation, which took place early this morning, Prime Minister Lini confirmed the seriousness of the disturbances and that the request for riot control equipment and material was for the purpose of assisting the Vanuatu authorities to prevent further loss of live and property damage and to restore order.

In consultation with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Duffy) I decided that it was important for Australia to respond promptly and positively to the request, coming as it did from the duly elected government of a friendly South Pacific neighbour facing a very significant problem of law and order.

Both in my telephone conversation with Prime Minister Lini and through our High Commissioner we have made clear to the Vanuatu Government that the equipment and material is being provided on the basis that it is for containment of the situation and that any use of it should be in that context-that is, used only to the extent necessary to restore order and with all due concern to minimise injury.

Since the request strongly emphasised the urgency of the situation, the Government moved quickly overnight to make the necessary arrangements. Today at 0620 hours a Royal Australian Air Force Hercules left Canberra for Vila carrying gas masks, tear gas canisters and tear gas launchers. This is standard police riot control material and equipment of the kind held by Australian police forces. The aircraft should be reaching Vila about now.

My Government has remained in very close contact with the New Zealand Government on the situation. I have spoken to Prime Minister Lange. New Zealand has also received a request from Vanuatu for assistance and will be providing equipment and material complementary to the supplies we are sending. Prime Minister Lange told me that he expected a New Zealand aircraft to depart for Vanuatu later this afternoon. I have also spoken with Prime Minister Wingti of Papua New Guinea, who expressed his support for our positive response to the request from Prime Minister Lini. I believe that all honourable members should support the Government's decision, designed as it is to assist the Vanuatu Government to protect the life and property of its citizens, and indeed others, including a substantial number of Australians. I also believe that honourable members will share my sincere hope that the equipment which we have supplied to the Vanuatu authorities will not, in the event, be required.

I am pleased to report that, according to the most recent information available to me, the situation today in Villa appears to have quietened but it does remain tense. Finally, I advise the House that our High Commission has made extensive inquiries of Australians in Vila and has reported that all Australians contacted are safe.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition supports the action that has been taken by the Government in these circumstances according to the facts related to the House in the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and separately in a briefing the Prime Minister was kind enough to give me. I do not believe in the circumstances any responsible Australian Government could have acted otherwise than the Government has done. On behalf of the Opposition, I express the hope, as did the Prime Minister, that the equipment supplied will not be required for the designated purpose and that the apparent improvement in the internal security situation reported today continues. I believe the only other observation to be made is that this event illustrates yet again the extraordinary volatility and instability of our region and the requirement that overall policies-defence, foreign and otherwise-fully recognise that inherent instability and volatility in our part of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Following the statement yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition expressing concern at the level of family migration and the skill component in our immigration program, is the Minister able to update or provide the House with information on the level of family migration and the skill component in our immigration program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Having analysed the figures which the Leader of the Opposition used in making his statement that the Opposition was considering withdrawing bipartisan support for our immigration program, all I say, in the kindest way possible, is that the Leader of the Opposition does not seem to have learnt any of the lessons of the last election and continues to have a numeracy problem. The Leader of the Opposition claimed in his statement that in the five years to 1986-87 family reunion had risen from 17 per cent to 50 per cent of migrant intake, while skilled and business migrants had fallen from 46 per cent to 17 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have come to regard figures provided by the Opposition with some scepticism, I had my Department take out the figures. The Department informed me that the Opposition's figures for family reunion in 1981-82 excluded brothers and sisters and more distant relations, over 20 per cent of the intake in that year, but they are included in the figure for 1986-87. That means that the figures upon which the Leader of the Opposition was basing a very important policy position had a 20 per cent error.

However, there is a more substantial error. The clear implication of the figures of the Leader of the Opposition and his whole statement is that family immigration brings in no skilled workers. That is not only incorrect, it is also offensive. Overall, the skill level of settler arrivals has been going up, not down. In 1981-82, 23 per cent of settler arrivals were skilled. In 1986-87 the proportion was 27 per cent.

The Leader of the Opposition talks of business migration. I remind the House that it was this Government that introduced the whole concept of a special business migration program, which has already been hugely successful. We set a target for this group of 3,500 arrivals in 1987-88. When I announced recently that the overall program for 1987-88 was increasing from 120,000 to 132,000 I pointed out that this was being done in no small measure to increase business migration. We now expect 8,000 settler arrivals under this program.

None of the figures I have cited are regarded, either by me or by my Department, as secret. They are available. They ought to be public so that all members of this House can take a fully informed position on the debate that is taking place. I therefore will table the figures and provide the Leader of the Opposition with an extract so that he will be able to understand the correct figures. I will also provide him with a simple pamphlet given to every intending immigration applicant explaining how the points test works. I invite the honourable gentleman to read it. He will therefore be in a position, hopefully, when the important debate on the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies is resumed to make some useful contribution on a matter of major public concern and importance to this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Did the Minister intend to table a couple of papers?

—He threw them at the Leader of the Opposition.
—I hope that the right honourable member reads them, too.

—Is the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of suggestions that the Government should fund the expansion of higher education by increasing general taxation? Can the Minister provide the House with information pertinent to these suggestions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to have received a large number of suggestions in recent days as to how we might fund higher education in this country. I still think that the best suggestion we have had comes from the committee headed by the former Premier of New South Wales. One of the difficulties with using general revenue as the sole source to fund higher education and, indeed, to fund the expansion of higher education is that those who contribute to the general taxation system and therefore, to any increase in taxation are not the major beneficiaries of the higher education system.

ANSWER.PARA: The Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding has two sets of statistics which I think are worth repeating today and which demonstrate the uneven composition of the student population in higher education institutions throughout Australia. For instance, 43 per cent of those who come from families with professional backgrounds enter higher education, whereas only 9 per cent of those from unskilled backgrounds have the opportunity, under the current circumstances, to enter higher education. To put it another way, 40 per cent of students in higher education, on the basis of this study, have a father who is a professional, whereas professionals make up only 20 per cent of the work force. Fifty per cent of the work force is made up of manual workers while only 20 per cent of the student population is made up of the sons and daughters of those people. There is a very uneven distribution within the student population and that is what we are trying to correct in terms of the expansion that we have in mind. Therefore, the Committee has proposed that those people who are the direct beneficiaries of the higher education system should make some small contribution to the cost of providing their courses.

I want to make one other point very clear: the funds which are proposed to be raised through ACCESS-the Australian Contribution to the Cost of Education for Students Scheme-as recommended by the Wran Committee, will go into a special, dedicated fund. The Government has already said, in the context of the Green Paper, that it would at the least maintain its current level of expenditure on higher education in real terms. This is not a proposal to reduce the current levels of expenditure by the Commonwealth on higher education; rather, it is a proposal to establish a dedicated fund of additional moneys which would primarily have two purposes-to expand the number of places within higher education and to enhance the availability of Austudy.

The two major factors which will determine whether we are able to correct the imbalance in the nature of the student population will be, firstly, whether we are able to create the additional places so that the 20,000 people who are currently unable to enter higher education, although they are qualified to do so, have an opportunity to get into a university or college; and, secondly, whether there is adequate income support for them while they are undertaking their studies. They are the two primary objectives of establishing this fund, a fund which would be contributed to by those people who have enjoyed the benefit of a higher education and who contribute to it only once their income exceeds that of the population on average.

Those funds would be sufficient not only to expand the system but also to provide additional income support. I am absolutely convinced that it is only through providing those additional funds that we will be able to have a fairer system of access to higher education in this country.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the recent report South Africa: Race and Rugby prepared by our embassy in Pretoria. Will the Minister assure the house that this report was the result of investigations carried out in an unbiased, fair and objective manner and free of any guidance from the Government as to its likely conclusions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. In response to a request which came from the Australian Rugby Football Union, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade directed the Australian Embassy in South Africa to undertake a special survey of rugby union in that country, with a view to maintaining an up-to-date assessment of how real the integration progress had been in that code in South Africa. That paper, as the honourable member is aware, has now been released. Whilst acknowledging that significant progress has been made by the South African Rugby Board in removing racial barriers, the paper nonetheless demonstrates the extent to which the sport continues to be influenced by race. The survey brings home two very fundamental points. Pressure from abroad, including the sports boycott, has led to considerable progress towards non-racial rugby. Nevertheless, barriers to fully integrated rugby and to a non-racial South Africa remain firmly in place. The legacy of racism and the ongoing realities of the wider apartheid laws continue to keep people apart on the basis of race.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is convinced that sporting sanctions such as those embodied in the Gleneagles declaration, to which Australia scrupulously adheres, deliver a powerful message to white South Africans about the need for fundamental change before normal sport can be played in a normal society. In relation to the point the honourable member raised, I am satisfied that the objectivity of the report is something in which we can be confident. Our representatives in South Africa have prepared, as the honourable member is now aware, a detailed report and I am confident of the objectivity of that report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business: What is the significance of the `gene-shears' technique in genetic engineering developed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and announced at the Congress of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science (ANZAAS) in Sydney yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Jim Peacock, the chief of CSIRO's Division of Plant Industry, referred to the new `gene-shears' technique in an address to the Centenary Congress of ANZAAS at Sydney University. Full details of the discovery are being withheld until the publication of a full report to be submitted to Nature. This is to ensure that CSIRO's researchers maintain absolute priority.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent years in laboratories throughout the world genes have been modified by adding new bits of genetic information. However, CSIRO's breakthrough-for the first time-creates a technique for targeting undesirable genetic information which is already in the organism and cutting it out, hence the idea of `gene-shears'. The research has been carried out by Dr Jim Haselhoff and Dr Wayne Gerlach. The implications are enormous and may well be the most important development in genetic engineering internationally for a decade.
I ask honourable members to listen to this: the `gene-shear' technique involves attacking the genetic messages produced by genes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to speak into the microphone so all can hear.
—Why are you talking to them?

—They are the target in a way. These people understand this, it is for reinforcement; in more technical terms, a short sequence of ribonucleic acid, or (RNA), can be modified to target and cut chains of RNA produced by a gene or a virus. DNA generates a genetic message; RNA is the communication link which transmits the message to the protein.

ANSWER.PARA: So far the technique has been developed within the test tube but it points the way to application in a wide range of micro-organisms and plants to make possible the development of avocados and watermelons without seeds, but, much more importantly, control of cereal diseases and of alkaloids and anti-nutritional proteins. Obviously-this is the most important part of all-if the technique can be applied in animals and humans, and there is a strong theoretical basis for believing that this is the case, the implications for controlling foot and mouth disease in animals and diseases based on genetic defects such as Alzheimers disease-even if it is 10, 15 and 20 years down the track-will be enormously important.

The `gene-shears' technique has been patented. I was first briefed about this discovery by Drs Haselhoff, Gerlach and Peacock on 9 December 1987. Senator Button and I have had further discussions with Dr Peacock and his co-workers about the exploitation stage. We have good reason to be proud of this achievement with its implications in agriculture, animal husbandry and human health. I shall convey the congratulations of the Government and I hope also the Opposition-indeed, the congratulations of the whole House-to the Chairman of CSIRO.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade a question supplementary to that asked by the honourable member for Gilmore. I preface my question by reiterating the continued support of the Opposition for the Gleneagles Agreement covering sporting contacts between this country and South Africa. I ask whether the Minister still asserts that the report on South African rugby was carried out with complete objectivity in light of the fact that in a cable from the Department of Foreign Affairs to the Australian Embassy in Pretoria, inter alia, instruction was given in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: We hope that a convincing report on the extent of integration of rugby in South Africa will be a useful tool in our future dealings with the ARU.
I ask whether the cable also went on to say:

Mr Hayden has asked that in the conduct of this survey and in particular in drawing up any conclusions such procedures or results should reflect the fact that apartheid is an institutionalised system reaching, in one way or another, practically every facet of South African life.

Does the Minister believe, in the face of those statements and the clear implication of this cable, which I shall supply to the Minister, that in terms of the question asked by the honourable member for Gilmore the survey was carried out with total objectivity without any instruction or direction from the Government as to the substance of the conclusions?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that there may be some misunderstanding in the way that the Leader of the Opposition has interpreted the cable referred to. I must say that it is not a cable that I was aware of until the Leader of the Opposition referred it to me. The fact is that he referred to the system of apartheid in South Africa as institutionalised. He did not appear to be casting any doubt on what is an obvious fact. In answering the question that was asked of me earlier by the honourable member for Gilmore, I made the point that we asked our Embassy in South Africa to carry out a survey looking at the extent to which the sport continues to be influenced by race, having regard to the fact that we are aware that advances have been made in rugby in that country. In the answer to the question from the honourable member for Gilmore, I said that the legacy of racism and the ongoing realities of the wider apartheid laws continue to keep people apart on the basis of race. The contents of the cable referred to by the Leader of the Opposition do not imply that we believe that the system of apartheid in South Africa has changed. It has not. The survey that was carried out was on the effect of that system on non-racial rugby. That is what we were looking at. There was no question of any change in the basic concept of the apartheid regime in that country.

—The question I address to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade concerns protection of Australian malt exports. Is the Minister aware of recent steps taken by the United States of America to sell subsidised malt in the Peruvian market under its export enhancement program? What measures are being taken by the Australian Government to protect our exports of malt to Peru?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Burke for his question. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian Embassy in Washington have made a number of representations to the United States Administration following the offer of the United States to subsidise sales of 20,000 tonnes of American malt to Peru. The Government has a particular concern on this issue because an Australian trader has contracts to supply 32,000 tonnes in an estimated market of 45,000 tonnes this year.

ANSWER.PARA: The representations made to the United States Administration have resulted in written assurances from the Administration that the initiative was, in this case, targeted at the European community and sales under the initiative were not expected to be delivered before 1989, when the Americans anticipate an expansion in the market, which they claim should not preclude Australia's traditional or expanded levels of malt exports to Peru.

The Government has some reservations about the American predictions of next year's Peruvian market. The Government is advised that it was not the intention of the United States to impede the trade of non-subsidising exporters, such as Australia, but this is another example of the disruptive effects of any export subsidy programs, regardless of whether they are totally intended.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Treasurer concerns the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) considering causing people to have blood tests and to reveal intimate details of their sex lives to total strangers. Is the Treasurer aware that only a few weeks ago the Statistician's office commenced a household survey which included a section requiring many people, by force of law and fines, to spill the beans about their bowel and bladder problems?

QUESTION.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Well may members of the Government laugh but the survey is being conducted right now. Is the Treasurer aware that in the United States of America there is one statistician for every 18,000 people and in the United Kingdom there is one for every 15,500, while in Australia there is one for every 4,411 people? In light of the bowel and bladder survey and the contemplated blood and sex practices surveys, will the Treasurer cause the Statistician to put a stop to this dangerous galloping practice of sticking the nose of government or Big Brother into what must surely constitute the private and personal affairs of this nation's citizens? In view of the comparative staff ratios in the United States of America and the United Kingdom and the manner in which the 3,500 staff members of the Statistician are spending their time, will the Treasurer commence an inquiry into the present grossly overstaffed levels of the Australian Bureau of Statistics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moreton is determined to stay on the back bench; he is not just about to stay, he is determined to stay. National health surveys are conducted at regular intervals in Australia to provide reliable national information on the health status of Australians and their health related behaviour. The last was conducted in 1982 and the previous one in 1978. One will be conducted in 1989-90.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Bureau of Statistics consultative papers that have been circulated to health experts and organisations emphasise the Bureau's concern for privacy and the need to avoid sensitive questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about these personal questions?

—I shall not bother myself with an extemporaneous reply to a question like this. Whilst the Act enables the ABS to direct respondents to fill in a form or answer questions to obtain statistical information, it does not empower the ABS to direct a person to be physically examined. No survey by the ABS will incorporate compulsory medical examinations.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a proposal that respondents might be asked to volunteer for an examination including height, weight, blood pressure and cholesterol levels, but the suggestion that the Australian Bureau of Statistics has desired to ask an array of highly personal questions, in particular about psychiatric illnesses, is entirely mischievous. Despite a series of statements by the Australian Statistician denying these claims, some people, including the honourable gentleman opposite and some areas of the media, have continued to peddle these misleading and, they hope, alarming suggestions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Defence. It concerns defence policy of particular concern to members from Western Australia. Has the Minister for Defence seen a statement by the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson, that the Chief of the Defence Force has joined the Federal Opposition in calling on the Government to study the option of nuclear powered submarines for the Australian Defence Force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have. I have also had my attention drawn to a statement by the Chief of the Defence Force on the same claim, in which he said that he today dismissed claims by the Opposition spokesman for defence, that he had joined the Opposition in calling for nuclear powered submarines. He emphasised that in his recent address he had been speculating on long term force structure options for the Australian Defence Force. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: My statement about giving consideration to nuclear propulsion for RAN submarines was made in the context of decisions which will be required about the year 2015 for the next generation of submarines which should come into service after the year 2020.

He thought that, if any option were to be considered, it should be considered, in other words, about 30 years from now, which should see out most of the members of this House. I was critical of him before. Now I realise that his stand is a gesture of total self-abnegation. He has clearly decided-and greater love hath no man than that he lay down his overseas trip in this regard!-that he will never be Minister for Defence of this country. However, he has concern for the situation of the shadow spokesman 10 people removed in the year 2015 and he will do some groundwork for him on his overseas trip so that what he will leave behind as shadow spokesman at least will be a fairly decent file!

Let me make the point that the current Leader of the Opposition says that he would not dispose of Australia Post or Telecom Australia, but that is not the policy of the true Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, the Federal President of the Party. The Federal President of the Liberal Party had something quite different to say. He was asked about this matter on the business program on channel 10 on 19 July last year and this is what the real--

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: PROTECTION POLICIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy noted some gratuitous advice about protection policies given to Australia by a person described as one of President Reagan's advisers? Will he again draw the attention of the United States Administration to its own policies in respect to the dumping of primary products and artificial protection barriers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter the honourable gentleman points to is what we often see in international discourse: people take one stand that is principled and say, `This is what our policies are', and then there is a different reaction when it actually gets down to the crunch. Of course the situation in the United States at present is that there is an administration saying very sensible things about the development of world trade-agricultural trade in particular-and a Congress which in the recent past has been highly protectionist. When we are dealing with a system such as that in the United States all we can do is address our view to the Administration, the Congress and also the public service in that country because often they are working to different forces and pressures. I think it is partially by using that approach that we have been successful in getting our view across on the trade Bill, for example, and very effectively on the farm Bill. That is the reality we deal with.

ANSWER.PARA: In Europe we deal with the same sort of reality. There is the European Commission, which puts forward certain matters, and then there is the council of Ministers or the national parliaments or some other thing that can cause an unpredictable result. That is the sort of environment in which we live. We do not believe that if we stand naked in the world without any protection whatsoever all the rest of the world will gasp and follow suit; but what spokesmen for this Government do, and what my colleague the Minister for Trade Negotiations does, is articulate the principles that should govern trade and not go for the lowest common denominator, the lowest form of protectionism or double standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Prime Minister by reminding the House that our Prime Minister is one of only four leaders of the countries of the world who have ever been invited to address the Irish Parliament. This being the bicentenary year, and keeping in mind the historical value of the founding of Australia and the people who first settled Australia, will the Prime Minister consider accepting from the United Kingdom and from the Republic of Ireland an additional substantial number of young skilled people to take their place here in Australia to fill the jobs in trades for which there are vacancies at present? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

May I say by way of preface to my response that I remember with a great deal of pleasure and indeed pride the honour which was accorded to me by the Irish when Hazel and I visited Ireland at the end of last year. The warmth of the reception that was extended to me was a combination of many things, not least the fact that-this statistic may be a matter of some surprise to the honourable member-in our population of 16 million, five million of our fellow Australians have an Irish antecedent, which is some measure of the closeness of the link between our two countries. It is said that one of the reasons for the very high quality of my Ministry is that some 50 to 60 per cent of my Ministers are of Irish antecedents.

ANSWER.PARA: However, coming to the substance of the honourable gentleman's question, let me say that over many years young people from the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland have obviously, from the statistics I have given, been immigrants to this country and many have brought the particular skills of the type to which the honourable gentleman referred in his question. Under the immigration program, which has been conducted expertly under the guidance of my Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, there will continue to be a capacity for people with these and other attributes to come to this country and continue the great contribution to the development of Australia which has been made by so many of their forebears.

Let me say this to the honourable gentleman: we do not believe that the filling of skill shortages and other types of vacancies in this country should simply be thought of in terms of immigration. One of the distinguishing characteristics of the five years of our Government-and I think one with which the honourable gentleman would agree-is the very considerable increase we have made in the funds available for the training courses and apprenticeships in this country so that, more and more, these vacancies will be filled by our own, Australian born, young men and women. Having said that, there will still be room for a significant component of people from the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland. They have in the past made a remarkable contribution to this country. The strength that we have and the fact that we are a country which is an object almost of jealousy and certainly admiration around the world reflect the contribution that they, in part, have made. I hope that in the years ahead many more thousands of them will continue to make such a contribution.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's handling of the immigration debate.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on Australia's immigration program has started on a sour note because the Government has sought to direct a debate which should be open and frank in a direction that is not appropriate. There is community concern about Australia's immigration program. This concern has been expressed in many ways. It has been expressed time and again in surveys that have been done both at large and by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. This is a serious matter that affects all Australians. The population and immigration programs of Australia affect us all.

SPEECH.PARA: Immigration levels and the growth in population affect our self-reliance and self-defence capacity. The larger our population, the more capable we are of being self-reliant. In trade, the diversity of our products and the development of new markets are significantly dependent on the composition and size of our population. Our foreign relations are significantly affected by the size of our population, particularly our relations with those in the immediate vicinity of Australia in South East Asia and the South West Pacific. Our economic performance is affected by the size of our population and our immigration program. Our industrial competitiveness, our high technology capacity, the ability to innovate, the structural adjustment that Australia is going through-all are affected by immigration and by the size of the Australian population. On a government level, the requirements of our people relating to health and education and the infra- structure factors of roads and housing are affected by population and immigration. The depletion of natural resources is affected by our immigration program and Australia's population. These are not matters that should be entered into lightly and dismissed with tags or catchcries, as the Government has sought to do. They are serious matters and a serious debate and examination of them must take place.

The Government has soured the debate by wanting to tamper with the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies-the report that is being prepared by Dr Stephen FitzGerald. The Government is also aware that the first report from Dr FitzGerald branded the Government's immigration program as a failure. The Government is also aware that that report branded the Government's program in the following terms:
The current selection procedures are ineffective in controlling numbers. They are not seeking enough skilled and entrepreneurial migrants and they are widely considered inequitable.

That is the way in which the Government's own inquiry saw the Government's programs. Not content with just muddying the waters on the final report, the Government has sought to fling around terms such as `racist', branding as a racist anyone who disagrees with its policies, a most unfortunate characteristic of this Government and one not worthy of its members. Can they point to a disagreement in policy whose differences are based on racial characteristics? No, they cannot. A bipartisan approach is what the Government consistently wants, but it wants that bipartisan approach only if the Opposition agrees with it. Never has the Government said, `That is a good idea; we will be bipartisan'. The claim for bipartisanship is made only when the Government wants the Opposition to shift its ground. Those are not good bases for this debate to commence on. If we do not agree, we are not bipartisan; if we have a different policy, members of our parties are branded as racists. The Government is failing to present the importance of this debate in its proper light.

We will not be diverted from expressing our views, for we believe that an immigration program must be of national benefit, it must be something for every Australian and something that all Australians broadly endorse, no matter what their origin or background. There must be a strong endeavour by the Government to reach agreement with the various elements of the Australian community, including the Opposition. The Government should be bipartisan about the right policies. We will be bipartisan about the right policies. But we will not be locked into something that is called bipartisan and on which the Government then proceeds to set the agenda. That is not part of the way in which we intend to participate in this debate.

The Government has changed the balance and the direction of Australia's immigration program. Whether we use the highly qualified departmental figures produced by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) today or the figures released by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) at the weekend, we can see a great shift in the direction of the Government's immigration program. The Government halved the program in its first year in office. It is suspicious of migrants, and when it came to office it basically halved the size of the program. It brought it down from a level of 93,000 in the year before, or 118,000 in 1981-82, to 69,000. Since then, to its full credit, it has gradually increased the size of Australia's immigration program.

Not only did the Government halve the program, but it entered into an agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). Under the agreed policy details, section 4 (c) of the accord, the following policy guidelines were agreed to by the Australian Labor Party and the ACTU:
. . . family reunion and refugee intake are of the highest priority in determining migration criteria.

That was the basic policy to which the Government gave its agreement before coming to office, and it has shifted its program so that year after year an increasing proportion has been devoted to the unskilled and semi-skilled migrant. The Government in fact has created a situation where migrants coming to Australia, who are largely unskilled or semi-skilled, are starting to squeeze the job opportunities for young Australians leaving school and for forced early retirees. That is the fact of the matter.

Whether we use the qualified figures of the Minister, which seek over three policy changes to keep a basic criterion and, seven years in reverse, seek to allocate people to categories that the Department is currently running-and the Department says in the footnotes on those figures, `These are qualified' and that it is an extremely difficult task to do, and they are from unpublished statistics from the Department on an undated note-which should be highly suspect, or whether we use the figures of the Leader of the Opposition, there is that dramatic shift. Whether it be a shift of 200 per cent or 50 per cent, there is a significant shift in the Government's policy. The Government needs to look at the levels of skilled employment-creating migrants coming to Australia. When one looks at the family reunion program or the independent and concessional programs of the Government, one finds that in those programs there is a skill level of only 20 to 26 per cent. The skill programs involve a skill-managerial capacity of 49 or 50 per cent. There is a dramatic difference in the types of people who come here under both programs.

The Opposition is saying that Australia needs to have a larger immigration program and that the increase in immigration under that program must be skill-based. It must involve people who can make a positive contribution to our nation and society on arrival. They must be able to fill the shortages that exist in practically every industry; they must also be self-starters. We do not care where in the world they come from because, despite some of the ragtag comments of the last few days, we have a non-discriminatory policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good.

—The Minister says, `Good'. He has known that since he became Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The Opposition has never shifted in this area, so he can keep those comments for his later remarks. The non-discriminatory policy will apply to the quality of the individuals. We are saying that Australia needs more job creators, more people who are dynamic in their attitudes, and that, as such, the family reunion program should not provide for an increase in numbers. The immigration program should provide for an increase and the extra people should be those with skills, qualifications, knowledge or an investment to make in Australia. Skill levels are the key to what we believe the future should hold for an immigration program.

SPEECH.PARA: The program is in a mess. One and a half million people from all around the world have applied to come to Australia to live on a permanent basis. We should be proud of that. This is a country that they see benefit in coming to. Therefore, any policy must be selective to gain the types of people that all Australians nationally feel will best suit the circumstances of this country. That is what we need, and that is what the Opposition has set out as its basic criterion. There is a program overrun this year; there is a 1 1/2-year wait on the review of cases; there is a one-year wait in the chase-up of known illegal immigrants, wherever they may be; the points score system is keeping out people who should be here and letting in people who should be kept out; and the number of illegal immigrants has jumped to 74,000. What a mess. The Government has a wreck of a program but challenges anybody who criticises it as having a racist attitude. The program is unbalanced and is in a mess.

The Leader of the Opposition has set down significant criteria for a program of the future. The list is not conclusive; it contains the broad principles, not to be confused with the nine principles that have been traditional in immigration. These are the basic factors: Australia's national interest must always be the overriding consideration in deciding upon the level and composition of the immigration intake. The prime influence on all post-arrival policies must be that all Australians have a common destiny transcending other loyalties. Those are commendable principles and ones that we endorse. The Leader of the Opposition said, `The capacity of Australian society to accept and absorb change must be a factor determining our immigration intake. Continuing high levels of migration are essential to a sustained economic growth and expansion'. The Government does not endorse those things. Let us hear what the Government has to say. The Leader of the Opposition said, `As a member of the international community, Australia has an obligation to play her role in the humanitarian resettlement of refugees'.

There we have what the Opposition has said. The best that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs can do is throw around tags of concern for racism. Why can the Government not be bipartisan? When pressed on the policy of the Government on family reunion, the Minister said:
I believe we can continue to handle numbers at about the same level now, but this has to be qualified about where the economy is heading.

The Minister would not commit himself. He would not give guarantees on family reunion and would not say that the numbers must be maintained or increased. Of course he would not. The Opposition is saying that family migration should be maintained but that we should also have as migrants people with skills and people of capacity. Let us have some nation builders as part of Australia's immigration program, an expanded program of capable people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —About the only thing on which I agree with the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), is that this is a poor start to a very important issue. How did it start? It was public knowledge that the Government was about to receive and has now received the report of FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. Equally it was public knowledge that the Government created the FitzGerald inquiry in order that Parliament could have before it an objective report based upon an examination of all the issues and a canvassing of opinions from the widest possible spectrum of Australian society so that we could, within the framework of a bipartisan policy, reach agreement on levels of intake and parameters of our immigration policy and establish guidelines to take us to the year 2000. I am bound to say that I feel some sorrow for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) because of the position he finds himself in. It is not a question of there being two sets of figures. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition quoted figures that were demonstrably and palpably wrong.
—No, they were not.

—They were demonstrably and palpably wrong. I advise the Leader of the Opposition that he ought to drop off trying to prove the correctness of them. I said to the shadow Minister-and I say it to the Leader of the Opposition and all members of the House-that there ought not to be disputes in this place on questions of fact concerning sources of intake. Those figures are public and are in the report of my Department. They exist and they are available.
—Do you call those qualified figures facts?

—The honourable member for Mitchell is excited because he has misled his Leader. That is his problem and we all know it. He indicated that he obtained his figures from the Parliamentary Library. It is matter for him what his source is, but the Library cannot be expected to keep up-to-date with the range of figures that emerge in this area. The honourable member for Mitchell and the Leader of the Opposition are wasting their time and the time of the House when they do not use the resources of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs so that any debate that takes place takes place on an agreed set of figures. It was obvious from statements made by the Leader of the Opposition that not only were his facts wrong but also, because the facts and figures were wrong, his conclusions were incorrect. He talked about a lack of skills. In the tables that I gave him today he would see an upturn in the skills capacity of intending immigrants.
—It is not. It is down.

—I know the honourable member for Mitchell is excited and that the Leader of the Opposition is likely to sack him-well he should-but I ask the honourable member to restrain himself. The fact is that the tables that I have made available to the Opposition indicate a general level of increase in the skills of people coming into Australia over the past four or five years. That is the reality.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition tended to say several things about family reunion. Firstly, he said that family reunion was distorting or producing an imbalance in the figures and causing considerable concern among ethnic leaders. It seemed that what he was saying was that we had to abandon the basis of the family reunion package in favour of an emphasis on skills. The mistake made by the Leader of the Opposition and his advisers was simply this: in terms of family reunion, aged parents come to Australia, and many of them bring pension benefits from overseas. Will anyone deny any Australian citizen or any person who has come to Australia the right to have his aged parents come here also? Brothers, sisters and cousins must go through the points system the same as everyone else. If they fail the points system, they do not get in. They get certain marginal concessions. To suggest, as was implied by statements made by the Leader of the Opposition that the family reunion package is somehow deskilling Australia is absolute nonsense.

The evidence available clearly indicates that many people who come to Australia under the family reunion program because they have a family network of brothers and sisters in Australia are joining people who have gone through the experience of finding employment. Therefore, they are able to direct and assist them not merely to settle but also to find work. On many occasions in the allocation of points system, it is the offer of a specific job that gives a person the necessary points to enter Australia. That is the fact. In the statements made yesterday, it was suggested-and it was suggested again by the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-that the priority of the Opposition was to cut back or restrain family reunions because they were threatening jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that anywhere.

—The Opposition claimed family reunions were taking jobs that should have been available to young Australians. The emphasis of the Opposition is that Australia needs to bring in trained and skilled migrants. The honourable member for Mitchell is entitled to have that position if that is his view. However, I say quite frankly that it is not the position of the Government.
—So you brought in 500 waiters last year.

—Order! If the honourable member for Mitchell continues to interject, I shall have to warn him. The Minister heard the honourable member in relative silence, and the honourable member for Mitchell should do the same.

—The Government has embarked upon a policy of encouraging young Australians to stay at school. It has been involved in negotiations with unions and employers to provide on the job training. The commitment of this Government in the first instance is towards the adequate training of and the provision of skills to our young people so that they will be able to take their place in areas of industrial expansion and new industry. The honourable member for Mitchell talks about the Australian Council of Trade Unions connection. The fact is that any Minister for Immigration, knowing that his Government is committed to the policies of training young Australians and producing a skilled work force-and that is the Government's first priority-must then say that in terms of employer nomination and bringing in skilled workers those two policies are not mutually antagonistic; one has to live with the other. An employer may be happy to provide on the job training. He may have an expanding business and within three years will expect to need 100 skilled workers but he currently needs five or 10 to keep the business going. That demand will be met. How absurd it is to talk about skilled migrants in the way the honourable member does and to suggest bringing them all in and not worrying about one's training obligations. After three years we would have young people who had done their training in colleges of advanced education looking for jobs and to whom the Government would have to say, `Sorry, although we told you to stay at school and get training, there is nothing for you because all the places have been filled as a result of our immigration policy'. That is palpable nonsense; I reject it and the Government rejects it. We make no apologies for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The family reunion program has produced levels of skill. Australia's immigration policies are working, and we can all be proud of them. I do not claim them as exclusively the province of this Government; Australia has a non-discriminatory policy. This year, there will be more than 1.4 million applicants to come to Australia, and the Government will take in about 132,000. We are still saying no to eight applicants out of ten and, therefore, have to determine the margins and the parameters of our policy.

Australia should be proud of its refugee policy. Over successive governments, I believe, we have maintained a level of commitment of which we can be proud. We ought to be proud of our family reunion policy, because it is based upon humanitarian considerations, a spirit of compassion and a commitment to the concept of the family. The importation of skills and the number of people that will be brought in must be measured, in the final analysis, by the capacity of our own economy to deal with those numbers. We cannot have an immigration policy that sits outside the framework of our economic parameters.

Immigration not merely assists in the development of our economy; it also has its parameters determined by the success or otherwise of our economy. We cannot say, for example, that we will bring in just skilled workers without having any regard for the commitment to train our own people. We can retain the refugee programs and maintain family reunion; we can look at those areas of skill that we need to bring in. As I indicated in my answer to the House today, the whole concept of business migration was produced by this Government. It is a major factor in increasing the numbers from 120,000 to 132,000. That program is working. We still, I might say, have a lot more work to do.

In this debate today we have heard a shadow Minister who has grievously misled his Leader and who has produced figures that are sloppy in the extreme. The announcement of the Leader of the Opposition allying those figures with the potential for abandonment of a bipartisan policy has caused grave concern within the ethnic communities of Australia. I believe this started off as a simple political exercise by the Leader of the Opposition to try to pre-empt some of the debate on the FitzGerald report and to try to get himself into a position where, in terms of what the FitzGerald inquiry is likely to recommend-and it is making many recommendations-the Leader of the Opposition could say, `You see, my position has been vindicated'.

All that this Opposition has done with its sloppy application and its lack of consideration for the real issues is to place itself into a situation that should never have occurred. I believe there needs to be a sustained commitment from the Opposition to the principle of non-discriminatory immigration, and I have indicated to the shadow Minister that at least I am grateful that today the Opposition has acknowledged that that is the fact and continues to be the fact. Of course, there will be a wide variety of issues that will have to be debated. The very nature of the FitzGerald Committee, which was established for this purpose, will provide that opportunity not merely to the Opposition, not merely to ethnic leadership, but also to the Australian community at large.

The issues that have to be considered are large and varied and they do not provide us with simple answers. Therefore, there will be plenty to debate. So long as there is a commitment within this Parliament to a non-discriminatory immigration policy, that policy can be bipartisan. It does not lose that important quality because there may be strong differences of opinion about certain aspects of the policy-how it is weighted and which way it ought to flow. That is a debate yet to come. It is a matter of regret to me and to the Government that on this occasion yet again the Leader of the Opposition has made public statements which have caused concern within the ethnic community, based on figures that were demonstrably and palpably false. If this debate is to be engaged in a serious and important way, the Opposition will have to get its act together. It will have to get itself to the position where we will not spend our time arguing about facts and details. There will be plenty to consider in terms of policy. There will be plenty of points of emphasis that could be made by all honourable members, and I have no doubt they will be made by people outside this House. I repeat publicly to other members the invitation that I made to the shadow Minister: honourable members requiring any facts or figures from my Department will have them made readily available. If they are not satisfied and they want to pursue some of those matters further they will have assistance in doing so. These figures ought not to be and are not regarded by me or anybody else as being secret. They are public and they are open. The sooner the shadow Minister avails himself of that opportunity, the sooner the Opposition gets its act together, then the sooner the people of Australia can get what they deserve, that is, a principled and informed debate on our future immigration policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to hear the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) say that we should have a principled and informed debate on immigration. I agree with him absolutely. I remind him that it was in 1977 that a document called Immigration Policies and Australia's Population was produced. I remind him of that because it was the forerunner, in a way, to the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. We are talking about the whole history of Australia-past, present and, in a sense, future. The history of Australia is the history of migration and that will continue to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The tremendously responsible thing about migration policy is that the decisions made in this area cannot suddenly be reversed. It is not like economic policy or any other policy. We are dealing with bringing into this country people from all over the world. The policy decisions taken by successive Ministers live on after them in a very tangible form. That is what an immigration debate is so important. We are not talking about the absence or otherwise of family reunion, the absence or otherwise of skilled migration; we are talking about migration policies to be pursued by future governments so that we can develop the sort of Australia that most Australians want.

I have been very depressed to see the quick way in which the Minister, who is at the table, and others in this Parliament and outside have sought to slur the motives of people who in one way or another have sought to enter the immigration debate and put views contrary to the prevailing policies of the Government. I remember very clearly the furore that broke around Professor Blainey when he made some suggestions. I am not saying for a moment that I necessarily agree with all the protagonists of one point of view or another, but we should be very careful not to tag as racist somebody who questions some aspect of Australia's immigration policy. Too often and too quickly the Minister trots out this racist tag. It is quite wrong of him to do so and it does him little justice. It is an easy thing to do, it raises that term in the public mind, and it does not really address the questions which are before the Australian people.

The simple fact is that there is a tremendous amount of concern amongst the general community about Australia's current immigration program. Why is that concern there? One of the reasons is that this Labor Government, over a number of years, has simply failed to explain its policies. We cannot change the balance of the intake, as this Government has done over a period of years, without the general public asking what this Government is up to, why it is doing this, and what is the reason for its making the changes. We can argue about percentages but the fact is that the family reunion category has gone up and the skilled category has gone down in percentage terms. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the report of the Committee entitled The National Crime Authority-an Initial Evaluation.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the report.

The occasion for this report is the lifting of the sunset clause in the National Crime Authority Act 1984 which would otherwise have terminated the life of the National Crime Authority (NCA) on 30 June 1989. The Committee supports the lifting of the sunset clause although it considers that, because so many of the Authority's investigations and the resulting legal proceedings have yet to be completed, it can only make an initial evaluation of the Authority's performance at this time. Because legal proceedings are currently before the courts or are pending in relation to a number of matters, the Committee has been obliged in its report to be circumspect and to confine itself to generalities.

Looking back on the debate leading up to the establishment of the National Crime Authority, the Committee considers that there was a clear expectation that the Authority would get results. The primary objective for which the Authority was established was, the Committee believes, to put significant criminals behind bars. In those terms the Authority is beginning to demonstrate success. It has put the Cornwell-Bull drug trafficking syndicate out of business and it has obtained convictions of significant figures under two of its other references. The terms of imprisonment imposed on Cornwell and Bull-23 years and 18 years, respectively-indicate the gravity with which the courts viewed their activities. Terms of imprisonment of 24 years and 20 years have been imposed on principals under another reference and the maximum term of imprisonment available for the offence concerned, three years, has been imposed on the principal under a third reference. Numerous other matters are before the courts at the moment.

The success of the Authority cannot be measured merely by the successful prosecutions resulting from its investigations. There was also an expectation that the establishment of the Authority would have a deterrent effect, that by its success in its investigations and, possibly, by its very existence, it would increase the fear of detection and apprehension in the minds of those who might be tempted to enter the field of organised criminal activity. It is too early to say whether the Authority has succeeded in this second objective. The Committee therefore recommends that a more comprehensive evaluation of the Authority's work and of the success of the law enforcement strategy underpinning the establishment of the Authority be undertaken in three years time. By that stage more of the Authority's investigations and more of the resulting legal proceedings should have been completed and it should be possible to make some judgment as to whether the Authority has in fact altered the climate in which organised crime operates.

The Committee does not recommend any changes to the Bill lifting the sunset clause, the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, to which the House of Representatives has already agreed; nor does it recommend any changes to the legislation constituting the National Crime Authority at this stage. It has, however, identified the present limitations on the Authority's access to taxation records as a matter which it proposes to pursue in a further inquiry. The Committee does, however, recommend some changes to the Authority's present handling of the police component of its staff. It became clear to the Committee in the course of this inquiry that there was considerable dissatisfaction in police ranks about their role in the Authority's investigations and the Authority's perceived attitude to police. The Committee recommends that the Authority give greater recognition to the expertise of experienced police officers and that they should be given a greater involvement in its investigations.

The Committee also recommends that the police component of the Authority's staff should be given contracts rather than being seconded in order to overcome the problem of officers working together but being subject to different terms and conditions of employment. It recommends that consideration should be given to the appointment of a senior and respected serving or former police officer as a member of the Authority in order that police may be assured that their views are represented at the highest levels of the Authority. Finally, the Committee has recommended that the Authority give greater consideration to the use of police task forces external to the Authority as a means of carrying on its investigations. While rejecting much of the criticism made of the secrecy surrounding the Authority's operations, the Committee has also recommended that the Authority give consideration to making greater use of its power to inform the public about the general conduct of its operations by holding public sittings and issuing public bulletins.

Certain of the fears expressed at the time of the establishment of the Authority, both as to the obstacles which might lie in the way of its effective performance of its functions and the potential threat to civil liberties which it posed, appear to date to have been proven groundless. So far from being a `ninth police force', as some have claimed, the Authority is a unique and novel investigative agency, combining elements of traditional law enforcement agencies with the powers of a royal commission and able to use the one to complement the other. The Committee believes that Mr Justice Stewart, the members and senior staff of the Authority deserve credit for having turned this experiment into a successful working reality.

On behalf of the Committee I express its appreciation to the secretary, Mr Giles Short, and his staff for the excellent support the Committee has received. As Chairman of that Committee, may I say that it must be one of the hardest working committees in this Parliament. Since the inception of this Parliament it has completed two major reports-this one and the report on witness protection which will be presented to the House next week. I think that Committee members deserve congratulations on their hard work and effort in a very short space of time.

The Committee is aware of recent judicial criticisms of the National Crime Authority concerning matters relating to Mr Grassby and the Sergis. That matter is still sub judice. There are still before the courts of New South Wales criminal matters that are unresolved. It is regrettable that some senior counsel still appearing in that case have seen fit to use the media, whilst it is still a sub judice matter, to express views which are not necessarily correct and which are in many cases guesswork. I find that to be an abuse of the position of senior counsel and potentially dangerous to the proper workings of the judicial system of this country. The Committee understands concerns regarding the judicial criticisms of the NCA. I assure the House that the Committee will seek from Mr Justice Stewart and the Authority further information as to the criticisms that have been made. I thank the House and I thank the members of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me I wish to make a couple of points, as one of the original members of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority upon its formation in early 1985. I am simply fed up with the criticisms directed at the National Crime Authority, which is bravely, and I think under severe limitations, attempting to fight corruption which is deeply rooted in our community and which has been tolerated for far too long. If the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct currently taking evidence in Queensland, unearthing as it is the links between business, police officers, legislators and public servants, were to be reproduced in other States, we would get the same result, if not worse.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I present report No. 1 of the Committee, entitled one vote, one value, incorporating a dissenting report and a supplementary paper on the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report and the supplementary paper be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-one vote, one value is the title of the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The report presents the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987. This Bill seeks to enshrine in the Constitution the principle of one vote one value by requiring that the number of voters in Federal and State electorates is as nearly as practicable the same.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill aims to eliminate malapportionment. Malapportionment occurs when electorates have unequal numbers of voters, usually through the use of a zonal system which gives greater voting power to rural areas. This is a separate problem to the much talked about gerrymander, where electorate boundaries are drawn to advantage one political party. The Committee notes in its report that the achievement of one vote one value does not stop the possibility of gerrymandering but is a necessary first step for fair and democratic elections.

The Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987 was introduced into the Senate by Senator Michael Macklin in September 1987. The Senate referred the Bill to our Committee for inquiry and report in October 1987. In examining Senator Macklin's Bill our Committee has continued the work of its predecessor, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Prior to the 1987 Federal election, the Electoral Reform Committee was inquiring into an earlier version of Senator Macklin's Bill. I wish to acknowledge the contribution which the Electoral Reform Committee made to this inquiry, particularly that made by the former Chairman, Senator Robert Ray, Sir John Carrick and past secretaries, Don Nairn and Mike Fetter. I also place on record my appreciation to all members of the current Committee, the Secretary, Trevor Rowe, and Helen Misa from the secretariat.

Today is expected to be the seventh last day the House of Representatives will sit in this chamber before moving to the new Parliament House. It is perhaps ironic that a report on electoral equality is one of the last to be considered in this chamber, because on 6 August 1974, in this chamber, the first Joint Sitting of the Australian Parliament debated a Bill to reduce the variation in number of voters for House of Representatives electorates from 20 per cent to 10 per cent. During that debate the then Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, stated:

We believe the purpose of this Bill to be a clear and honourable one. Its basic principles have been recognised by the Supreme Court of the United States for 10 years and by an all-party committee of our Parliament for 15 years. It affirms the Government's belief that every person's vote is of equal value, no matter where that person lives. It affirms our belief that all men and women should be equal in making the law, as they are before the law.

Since that debate in this chamber in 1974, there has been support from all major political parties for one vote one value for the House of Representatives electorates. The Macklin Bill, which was the subject of this report, sought to extend that requirement for equal voting power from the House of Representatives to the parliaments of the States and the Northern Territory. The Committee divided six to four on its recommendations, with Labor and Democrats members in the majority, and Liberal and National members and Senator Harradine in the minority.

In chapter 3 of the report we have examined in detail the history of electoral reform in Australian parliaments and the techniques which can be used to measure malapportionment. As stated in paragraph 1.7, the Committee concluded, that using the three accepted measures of malapportionment-the David-Eisenberg index, the Dauer-Kelsay index and the Gini index-the electorates for the Queensland Legislative Assembly, both Houses of the Western Australian Parliament and the Tasmanian Legislative Council are unacceptably malapportioned.
