TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It is unfair and undemocratic for one electorate in the Queensland Legislative Assembly to have only 8,256 voters while another electorate has more than 25,000 voters. It is unfair and undemocratic for one electorate in the Western Australian upper House to have about 12,000 electors per member while another has 40,000 electors per member. The Committee believes that the fundamental principle of guaranteeing one vote one value requires all Federal and State electorates to have less than a 10 per cent variation from the average enrolment. A 10 per cent maximum variation has been accepted at the Federal level since the 1974 Joint Sitting. The State parliaments in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia have legislated to enforce the same 10 per cent maximum variation. The Burke Labor Government was blocked by the Liberal and National parties in the Legislative Council from implementing one vote one value in Western Australia. In Queensland, despite Labor, Liberal and Australian Democrats support for one vote one value, the National Party has refused to eliminate the zonal malapportionment which allows it to govern in its own right with less than a majority of the vote. The Committee therefore concluded in paragraph 1.14 that the Federal Government has a clear responsibility to act to overcome this infringement of the individual rights of electors in Queensland, Tasmania and Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Committee is unable to accept the 1987 Macklin Bill as a model for implementing one vote one value because of a number of inherent defects. The Macklin Bill would allow electoral boundaries to be overturned if enrolments were not `as near as practicable the same'. The United States Supreme Court has used the exact words to overturn electoral boundaries having a variation of less than 0.43 per cent. The Committee strongly believes that any constitutional alteration should include an explicit maximum tolerance of 10 per cent rather than the vague concept of `as near as practicable the same'. I note in passing that the referendum proposal of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) explicitly sets the maximum limit at 10 per cent.

The Committee's report contains a number of other criticisms of the Macklin Bill in chapter 4. Having studied the Attorney-General's proposed Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, it is my view that none of these defects are present in the proposed referendum. I am therefore at a loss to understand the position taken by Opposition members of the Committee. Given the bipartisan support for House of Representatives electorates having equal numbers of voters, I cannot accept that they are against equal State electorates.

The Opposition has argued that the Senate is malapportioned and that therefore State electorates should be allowed to escape the test of fairness. I would have thought that no member of this Parliament could oppose electors having an equal say in which party forms their Federal or State government. How can the electors of Queensland have equal voting power when one electorate has 191 per cent more voters than another? How can the electors of Western Australia have equal voting power when one Legislative Council electorate has 232 per cent more electors than another? How can the electors of Tasmania have equal voting power when one Legislative Council electorate has 245 per cent more electors than another? A tolerance of 10 per cent for this House is accepted by every party and it is time that a tolerance of 10 per cent was the standard for all Australian parliaments. I wish to conclude by quoting paragraphs 1.35 and 1.36 of the majority report:
1.35 The Committee concludes that: The final question in achieving one vote, one value is one of State government's rights versus individuals' rights and that the latter is of paramount importance.
1.36 The Committee strongly recommends that: The views of Australian voters on one vote, one value be tested by way of a referendum.

In early September the men and women of Australia will have the opportunity to enshrine one vote one value in our Constitution. It is my hope that this report will contribute to healthy debate on this important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My remarks will be made on my own behalf and on behalf of those honourable members who signed the minority report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. We felt it necessary to bring in a minority report because we felt that there was a degree of inconsistency in the majority report and a degree of sophistry in the argument that has recently been expounded by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). I wish to address the question of consistency and the concept of one vote one value. The majority report argued that a 10 per cent tolerance should be applied to State electorates and for that reason, without knowing at the time the details of the Government's referenda proposal, argued that this matter should be put to a vote by the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the report was prepared we have had the benefit of seeing the Government's proposal. The first point that must be noted is that the Government's proposal does not address the question of gerrymandering; it simply addresses the question of malapportionment. The second and most significant point to note is that it does not address the question of malapportionment as it exists under the Federal Constitution. A significant malapportionment exists within the Federal Constitution. It is based on the same arguments on which the present malapportionments within the States are based.

Let me take a moment to explain this. It is argued that there should be a 10 per cent tolerance for House of Representatives electorates, and within each State there is, but between States that is not the case. I cite the classic example of Tasmania, which is protected by an original provision of the Constitution. The Government had the opportunity in drafting its referendum proposal to address the inconsistency within the Federal Constitution but it chose not to. It chose only to draft a change which would affect State electoral laws. That, I believe, is inequitable and an indication of the Government's approach. In presenting the report of the majority of the Committee, the Chairman made reference to the degree of malapportionment that exists within electoral boundaries. One significant figure that he did not address was the degree of malapportionment that exists within the Senate. I refer to a document which I will not seek leave to incorporate because it is part of the Committee's report. It is important to note that the degree of malapportionment for State legislatures ranges between 1.04 per cent and 3.32 per cent. The degree of malapportionment in the Senate is 11.82 per cent. The Government's proposal for the referendum does not address that malapportionment.

When we examine in detail the impact of the referendum proposal, which is implicitly supported by the majority report, we note that it will make no difference to any State system of boundaries except Queensland's. It is important to understand the exact position of State boundaries in Australia at present. We have recently seen an election in New South Wales where the Opposition parties were required to achieve over 52 per cent of the two-party popular vote in order to defeat the Labor Government. For the Liberal and National parties to defeat the Hawke Labor Government in Canberra, with that Government's great commitment to one vote one value, we are required to obtain 52.3 per cent of the vote. The Labor Government can currently govern with less than 50 per cent of the vote-the same crime that the Chairman of the Committee has accused the Queensland Government of perpetrating. Yet the Government's referendum proposal will make no impact on the Federal boundaries. The situation continues for all Labor Government States throughout Australia. I am told that for the Opposition to win in South Australia it is required to achieve more than 54 per cent of the vote. A recent redistribution in Western Australia, the figures for which are incorporated in the Committee's report, requires the Opposition parties to achieve 53.1 per cent of the vote. The figures go on in similar vein right around Australia.

The great problem with the majority report is that it does not address the true problem of electoral boundaries in Australia but allows some parties when in power to achieve a result which allows them to govern with less than 50 per cent. It simply proposes to attack the zonal system but not to attack the most popular method of gerrymandering-that is the only word that can be used-electoral boundaries in other States predominantly governed by Labor governments at present to allow government to be achieved with less than 50 per cent of the vote. That is the minority report's major concern.

We are concerned with a number of other principles that are breached by the majority Committee report. Firstly, it is not appropriate to have a constitutional proposal without it going to a constitutional convention. At the time the report was prepared, we did not know the provisions of the proposed change. I believe the Opposition has amply demonstrated today that the proposal, no matter how it is framed, would not guarantee fair and democratic elections. The figures I have quoted support that.

The Opposition is concerned that the Commonwealth Government is prepared to force on the States conditions that it will not accept for itself and, as such, it is tearing up the basis of our Federal Constitution as embodied in sections 106 and 107. The Australian Constitution does not provide for one vote one value. It is important to understand how that operates. Each original State is guaranteed 12 senators, irrespective of population, so the voting power of a citizen entitled to vote in Tasmania is considerably greater than the value of a vote of a citizen voting for the Senate in New South Wales. The only way to remedy that is to change the number of senators elected from those States.

The Government is not prepared to do that yet it is prepared to force that principle on the States. The Commonwealth Constitution says that the States will be recognised as different within the Australian nation, yet the Commonwealth is saying that State governments cannot recognise different areas within each State as being different and entitled to different representation because of population, remoteness, communication difficulty or some other disadvantage-the same argument as is enshrined in the Federal Constitution. I find that considerably inconsistent.

The Opposition has a number of other problems with the majority report. The major problem is that the Government is prepared to tolerate a continuation of malapportionment at the Federal level. The Government's referendum proposal will not address this malapportionment at the Federal level, yet it seeks to force on the States change that it is not prepared to accept for itself. If I may draw the political conclusion from that, the proposal of the Government will have an impact in only one State, significantly the State of Queensland, yet it will do nothing to ensure fairer and more democratic elections in Labor Government States-Western Australia, South Australia or Victoria. Had the Unsworth Government not been defeated by a groundswell of public opinion in New South Wales this referendum proposal, No. 2 in the Government's batch of four, would have done nothing to force the Unsworth Government to redraw the boundaries in New South Wales to make them fairer.

The great problem is that the whole proposal is a sham; the referendum proposal is a sham. I am pleased the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is in the House, because the proposal will not achieve fair and democratic elections in Australia. The Government knows that. The majority of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters knows that, yet the Committee is prepared to lend its name to a report that perpetrates a misstatement.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Tim Fischer-I desire to raise a point of order under standing order 213 relating to the referendum legislation before the House. Standing order 213 states:

I refer to the first Bill listed, which has as its short title Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bills 1988. The long title for the same piece of legislation is:
A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to Provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

The point I wish to raise in no way debates at this time the merits of the Bill or otherwise. However, I recognise that the House, the Senate and the people must canvass and determine the fundamental issues involved. I submit to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and, inter alia, Madam Speaker, that it is for the Chair to determine the correct construction of the Bill in accordance with standing order 213 and the relationship of the long title of the Bill to its contents. I submit that the Bill has two major ingredients. Firstly, it provides for a four-year term for members of the House of Representatives and for members of the Senate. Secondly, under clause 4, it specifically provides for a separate matter, namely, the removal of the Senate election timetable from the Constitution and the insertion of a provision for simultaneous elections for the chambers on the same polling day. Briefly, the second ingredient is not merely a functional adjunct to the first ingredient; it is a separate question. The matters embraced by the second ingredient of the first referendum Bill were deemed to be so important as to be the subject of separate legislation and referendums in May 1974 and May 1977 and again in a related Bill and referendum in December 1984.

In conclusion, a precedent exists for the Chair ruling under standing order 213. In 1984 a Bill was withdrawn because it contained clauses that were not covered by the long title. Therefore, I ask the Chair to rule that under standing order 213 this first referendum Bill contains a clause not in accord with and not covered by the long title of the Bill. I submit that clause 4 is foreign to the Bill and, as such, is out of order in terms of its construction as currently presented to the House. In short, I respectfully submit to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the long title is misleading in the extreme and breaches the Standing Orders of this Parliament. Naturally, I am concerned about all four referendum questions, to which I am opposed. However, I confine my remarks to the first referendum Bill and ask the Chair to rule that the long title in no way refers to the second and separate major ingredient of the Bill, the aspect relating to simultaneous elections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Monday, 9 May 1988 was one of the great moments of our Bicentenary. The opening of a new and permanent residence for our Federal Parliament was symbolic of the importance to all of us of our democracy. Opened by Her Majesty the Queen, the new Parliament House looks across Lake Burley Griffin to the War Memorial as a reminder of the sacrifices of so many to forge and safeguard our democracy for generations to come. It was an occasion to recommit ourselves to the betterment of our society and an occasion to remember, as Her Majesty put it, the fragility of democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate that resumes today is on the four Constitution alteration Bills, dealing with the four referendum questions to be put to the people later this year. The Australian Labor Party (ALP) wants to change the Constitution. Fortunately it can do that only if the people agree. Since Federation, the Australian Labor Party has tried 21 times to change the Constitution and, on those 21 occasions, it has been rejected 20 times. Labor Party proposals are usually put for the convenience of the Government and rarely for the people. This occasion is no different. These proposals are for the convenience of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and I have no doubt they will be rejected by the people.

Our Constitution has been an outstanding success. It was the product of years of thinking, drafting, meetings and negotiation by the founding fathers. It is one of the world's most successful written constitutions. It is, of course, not without flaw; the product of human endeavour rarely is perfect, if ever. However, it has fulfilled the expectations of its producers. It brought six colonies together in a great federation. It established the High Court of Australia, one of the premier common-law courts in the international community, and it established our federal parliamentary democracy. It established the framework of a system of government that has added immeasurably to the rights of our citizens. In essence, Australia has a strong Constitution. Therefore, those who seek to amend it must discharge a heavy burden of proof. They need to satisfy a majority of Australians and a majority within at least four States that the proposals are, beyond reasonable doubt, beneficial to our democracy. Not only do these proposals fail that test, but also they do not even fulfil the prima facie rule: they are clearly not in the interests of the people of Australia and they must be rejected.

Before turning to the referendum questions, it is appropriate to note the way these proposals have been formulated. Until 1985 we had always discussed possible changes to our Constitution at meetings of the elected representatives. In that way, the people were predominant not only at the last stage but also at the formative stage of any possible changes. In 1985 the then Attorney-General abandoned that sensible idea and set up his own hand-picked Constitutional Commission. It has been an extravagant waste of $6m. Some of its members are eminent Australians, and I do not question their motives. However, the whole exercise has been based on a wrong premise.

The Constitution is all about politics and it was naive in the extreme to try to suggest that politics and the Constitution could somehow be separated. The members of the Commission and its committees have views about politics, but they are personal views only. The trouble is that the Commission has never had a mandate from the people and its report carries no more weight than the views of any other so-called experts. The Government will certainly and obviously rely on the Commission to support its proposals. That reliance will lack credibility except in one major respect. The Commission has kowtowed to the Government, and for evidence of that fact I refer to the Commission's first report where it notes that on 27 January it was directed to provide a report. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) did not just tell the Commission when to report, he even told the Commission the specific issues that he wanted included in the first report. Instead of providing the Government with a set of recommendations that revealed its independent consideration of priorities, the Constitutional Commission has meekly toed the line and given the Government all the ammunition it asked for. The one exception relates to parliamentary terms, and its fortitude on that issue was explained by the fact that an earlier report was released by the Commission last October before it got its marching orders from the Government.

Before leaving the subject of the Constitutional Commission, I seek an assurance from the Attorney-General. The law in this country is that the Government may spend only as much on the No case as it spends on the Yes case. The Constitutional Commission is legally a part of the Attorney-General's Department. One of its roles is to educate the public. Now that the Government has introduced the referendum Bills, and given the Commission's partisan support for five of the six issues, it would be quite wrong-and I put it to the Attorney-General that it would be possibly even illegal-to use the Constitutional Commission as a backdoor means of providing extra funding for the Yes case. I seek the Attorney-General's assurance that there will be no attempt to use the Constitutional Commission to subvert the relevant sections of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act.

Finally, as we start this $35m exercise, let it be put on the public record that this Government has not once attempted to find some bipartisan support for constitutional reform. The few discussions we have had have been initiated by the Opposition. The Government abandoned the constitutional conventions which comprised elected representatives, the best-known mechanism for seeking to obtain some common ground. The Government went ahead and set up its own group of non-elected experts. It then directed the Commission what to say. It pre-empted the first report of the Constitutional Commission-its own adviser-and it still does not have the Commission's final report. This is a good example of how not to seek constitutional change. The Government has no overall strategy; it has no effective consultation processes; it has adopted a completely unilateral approach and it has a complete mishmash of motives.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for consensus.

—The Victorian Premier is reconvening the abandoned Constitutional Convention executive and Labor backbenchers and members of the public are asking why we are having these referendums. The Government has picked the one option for obtaining a four-year term for the House of Representatives which it knew would produce and has already produced, a wall of resistance from the Liberal and National parties around Australia. The only questions that remain unanswered are when the referendums will be held and when the Government will announce defeat. It will be some time between now and the Sunday after the referendums are held.

SPEECH.PARA: Four questions are to be put to the people, and I shall now deal with each one. The first question will ask voters to approve a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. This question is the focal point of the Labor Party's campaign, and it will be the rallying point for the Opposition's resistance. The Government says that the effect of the question would be to give greater stability to our parliamentary system, increase the term of the House of Representatives to four years and reduce the number of elections. If anything, it will mean more elections and not fewer. Currently, a term of the House of Representatives is up to three years and the term of senators is fixed at six years. The senators face the people at the expiry of their term or earlier when parliament is dissolved following a difference of opinion between the House of Representatives and the Senate within the meaning of the Constitution. In other words, apart from the expiry of a six-year term, the senators must face the people only when their actions put them at variance with the House of Representatives which is, of course, controlled by the Government.

The referendum proposal removes the fixed term of senators and establishes a system of permanent double dissolutions. It removes the one fixed element in the system. Under this proposal the Prime Minister will be able to call an election for both Houses at any time whatsoever. Currently he can submit the House of Representatives to an election at any time but, as was recognised by the founding fathers when drafting the Constitution, if a Prime Minister does so, he still has to face a half-Senate election. The proof that that has been a strong factor in limiting the number of half-Senate elections is the fact that there have been only four half-Senate elections since Federation.

In addition to raising the prospect of more elections, the proposal gives the Prime Minister the additional political leverage of being able to threaten to dismiss the Senate and force it to an election at any time of his choosing. This puts the Senate under the Prime Minister's hammer. The proposal also abandons the system of rotation of senators. Currently half the senators face the people every three years. This system of rotation is common in Australia in most of the upper Houses in the States. In local government in Victoria, for example, where there are nine councillors, three are elected every year for three-year terms. It is also common in a number of other Western democracies. The best known of these, and the country which provided the example which our founding fathers looked to, was, of course, the United States of America where the Senate has terms of six years and the House of Representatives members have two years. Similarly, in many of the American States they have different terms, usually four years in the upper House and two years in the lower House.

Other countries that have different electoral cycles for their upper Houses and similarities with our federal system are Austria, Brazil and Canada. If Australia were to adopt the Government's contemporaneous four plus four system, Australia would be joining Bolivia, Colombia, Jordan and Yugoslavia, to name but a few; and among those having contemporaneous five plus five terms, Australia would be in the company of Czechoslovakia, Zimbabwe and Russia.

The fact is that the system of rotation for terms of members of the upper House is a good idea. The mandate is the same but is given at a different point in time. The Senate is a House of review. The fact that half the senators do not face the next election buttresses that feature of review. It means that half the senators are that one step removed from the political heat of the moment. That encourages the review of precipitate legislation emanating from the lower House. It is a system designed to discourage hasty decisions. This is a fundamental aspect of our system, and it is a sensible system. It has worked well.

In recent times, the Government has encouraged the claim that our Constitution is out of date. That is just misguided. No-one could foresee Labor's plans to keep a computer-based dossier on every Australian, but it was the Senate's threatened use of its power that stopped Labor's ID card-a testimony to the importance of a strong House of review. I will mention later in greater detail the Bill of Rights. If it had been adopted, it would have limited and restricted rights. We in the Opposition called it the `Bill of wrongs'. The founding fathers would not have foreseen Labor's Bill of Rights, but the strong Senate created in our Constitution stopped the Bill of Rights, another testimony to the importance of a strong House of review.

The motives for this change are varied. For the Attorney-General, it is a finale for his retirement. For the minders in the Prime Minister's office, it is a low cost, low risk diversionary tactic. Labor's strategists are looking for an appeal to its heartland to counter the rejection of Labor's cronyism, rich mates, privatisation, and now the tertiary education tax. Australia is in for a hard year, with even greater falls in living standards which have exacted their toll in New South Wales in numerous by-elections. Of course, for some in the Australian Labor Party, the motives are all rooted in 1975; they never accepted the people's verdict in the 1975 elections. Lastly, there are the ideologues like Mr Whitlam, who as far back as 1959 and now as a member of the Constitutional Commission, has wanted to destroy the power of the Senate. When the Senate opposes legislation, the ideologues describe it as obstructionist; and when the Senate supports legislation emanating from the lower House, it is superfluous. The extreme language betrays the extreme views. For example, Senator Walsh was reported in the Press on 5 December last year as saying that he supported the view of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), that the Senate was the swill of Australian politics. Is that any way to talk about the upper House, a House in which the people are represented?
Senator Evans betrayed his views in his maiden speech. Let me tell the House what he is reported as saying on the next day in the Canberra Times. He said:
The way to abolish the Senate, or at least muzzle it, is to white-ant it from within.

That is the real view of people in the Labor Party. The bottom line is that Labor's proposal does not mean fewer elections; on the contrary, it raises the prospect of more elections. The real motive-the fine print-is just a blatant attack on the Senate and our bicameral parliamentary system. The Labor Party loves to attack Queensland. Of course, the irony is that the upper House in Queensland has been abolished-and even the Attorney-General, in his generous smile, acknowledges the history of that fact. I say to the Australian people that Australia has a strong Senate. Why weaken it? Vote No to question No. 1.
I now turn to question No. 2. We will be asked to vote on the question:
Do you approve of a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia?

It sounds fair enough but, like the other questions, when one reads the fine print one finds it does not really mean what it says. This proposal is just misleading. I would expect that it would breach the law against false and misleading advertising.

I note that even today Mr Gary Morgan of Morgan Gallup Polls, when addressing the ninth Australian Statistical Conference, described the manner in which these questions have been framed as `blatantly biased'. The fact is that this proposal does not provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections. It does not stop-it does not even try to stop-the fixing of electoral boundaries. If this proposal is meant to set a minimum standard-and let us not forget that this is a proposal to put something into our Constitution, the number one law in this country-I say to the Attorney-General that it will encourage governments around Australia to fix their electoral boundaries to suit themselves.

I shall give some examples. New South Wales has a system of one vote one value. However, Premier Nick Greiner needed more than 52 per cent to win. Is that fair? The same applies in South Australia. Federally, the coalition needs 52.3 per cent of the two-party preferred vote to win office, and the Government will stand up and tell us that we have one vote one value at the Commonwealth level!
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Flinders will manage quite well without the assistance of other honourable members.

—Thank you for your support, Mr Deputy Speaker, and we look forward to seeing you cross the floor when this matter comes up. The proposal is indeed a nonsense, because it is based on the false premise that the drawing of boundaries will be fair if undertaken on a purely rigid numerical basis. How one defines `fair', of course, is open to debate. However, it has certainly been long established in Australian politics that it is appropriate to recognise the validity of the need for the representation of interests. That arises from the sheer size of Australia, the reality of the diversity of our communities and, of course, the establishment in the mid-nineteenth century of the separate political entities, the six colonies.

SPEECH.PARA: The structure of our national polity is a federal polity because the desire to have a national political structure was accompanied equally by an acknowledgment of those differences. Our Senate is one of the most powerful upper Houses ever established because it reflects the importance that our predecessors placed on a federal as opposed to a unitary system of government. Each State, regardless of its geographical size and regardless of its population, has an equal number of senators; thus Tasmania, rightly, has the same number of senators as does New South Wales, our most populous State. The principle of the recognition of interests was not just applied to the Senate; it was also applied to ensure a minimum of representation in the House of Representatives from each of the original States, so that Tasmania has always had five MHRs regardless of its size. The concept of recognition of interests has not surprisingly been acknowledged in the States. The irony is that question No. 2 imposes a standard for the States, particularly in their upper Houses, that this proposal does not accept for our own upper House, the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hypocrisy.

—As the honourable member for Parkes says, it is a question riddled with hypocrisy. It also imposes a uniformity that closes off the options of State parliaments or the people of the States to change their parliamentary systems to meet their local circumstances. For example, in some countries upper Houses are used to reserve positions for the representation of minority interests. In some places people in the upper House are actually appointed. In other places the upper House is deliberately so constituted as to give special emphasis to rural areas. For the purposes of my argument I do not advocate such options but merely refer to them to highlight the fact that there are other substantial arguments that cannot be lightly dismissed in the embrace of the rigid and inflexible system proposed by question No. 2.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make four other points about this question. Firstly, this proposal in itself recognises its own inherent weakness. It has a tolerance figure of 20 per cent. There is no way that anybody could guarantee a strict one vote one value election, even if it were desirable on its own. Secondly, by amending the Constitution the proposal may increase the involvement of our High Court in what is a very controversial issue. The United States Supreme Court has had to deal with a lot of litigation on this subject. I believe that where the proposal is otherwise wrongly founded, as it is in this case, it is unfortunate deliberately to embroil the High Court in such issues. Thirdly, it is not true that our Constitution is silent on this issue. In 1975, in McKinlay's case, the High Court made it clear that the Commonwealth does not have an unlimited right to draw electoral boundaries as it sees fit. Fourthly, question No. 2 raises fundamental issues about our Federation. Section 106 of our Federal Constitution states that the Constitutions of the States-and they all have their own-would not be altered by the coming into force of the Federal Constitution. Electoral laws are incidental to the Constitutions of those States and thus fall within that section. In my view, section 128 makes provision for the alteration of any part of the Constitution but a breach of the spirit of section 106 is clearly a major attack on our Federal system.

Nothing is black and white in politics, and that is certainly the case with the definition of a federal democracy. It is, however, a fact that since Federation the Commonwealth has massively accumulated power and influence at the expense of the States. The section 92 decision handed down two weeks ago by the High Court is a recent example. In the same way that free markets disperse economic power to consumers, the great appeal of a federation is the fact that it is a system of dispersing political power. Question No. 2 undermines the federalist nature of our system and for that reason alone it should be rejected. The question is, of course, aimed at Queensland, but it will certainly affect Western Australia's upper House and its lower House and, as I understand it, the Tasmanian upper House.

The ALP does not come to this issue with entirely clean hands. In April 1986 Arthur Tonkin, the former ALP Premier of Western Australia, resigned because his successor, Brian Burke, was not prepared to fully reform Western Australia's gerrymander. Mr Burke, the former Labor Premier, is on the public record as opposing this question. There is a fifth point and that is that Australians have long recognised the right of access to their representatives and the impact that this has on equality of representation. Australia has a strong democratic parliamentary system. Why weaken it? Vote No to question No. 2.

The third question asks voters to approve of a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government. The proposal is just a trick to con the local government vote. I, like so many on this side of the House, am a strong supporter of local government. I am a third generation local councillor. For three generations my family has served in local government. This proposal borders on the contemptuous. It is absolute tokenism. It is meaningless. I am not in favour of putting meaningless things in our Constitution. Our Constitution is too important to be used as a carrot to attract the votes of just any section of the community that the Labor Party wants to woo at any particular time. The proposal provides no guarantees against wrongful dismissal, no guarantees against enforced amalgamations and no guarantees against the abolition of local government in parts of States. It is a deliberate tactic to divert attention from Labor's plans for enforced amalgamations, for the cutbacks in road funding, and the abolition by the Labor Party of the system whereby local government used to receive a fixed percentage of income tax revenue. That is the reality.

Let me say that, whilst on the face of it the wording is merely symbolic, the existence of the clause will probably exacerbate a long time problem for local government. That is a problem well known to anybody who has served in local government in Australia. The problem occurs when the Federal Government gives local government some new function. We find that it will be funded in year one but in year two it will withdraw the funding and local government will end up holding the baby. This provision, meaningless as it is, will simply encourage Federal governments to continue that practice.

I note that there is no definition of local government in the proposal. Most people will assume that it is limited to municipal government-the local council-but that is not clear. The clause may include sewerage, water and electricity councils or authorities, some of which may currently have some members appointed by their respective State governments. The Government has failed to address these unintended consequences. The question also sidesteps the fact that local government is established under State law and already has constitutional recognition in most of the States. Let me read the actual wording of the proposed new clause. Proposed new clause 119a states:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.
As you can see, it is meaningless, worthless. Australia has a strong Constitution. Why treat it as a vehicle for tokenism. To question No. 3, we say vote No.

I now turn to question No. 4. It contains three separate proposals. Voters will be asked whether they approve of a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any government. This question is a rerun of Labor's Bill of Rights, which instead of giving rights would have limited and restricted rights. At that time we opposed that Bill, with strong support from the community, and with the support of the community we again will oppose this latest mini-Bill of Rights.

There are good specific reasons for opposing each proposal but there are also strong general arguments against the question as a whole. Additionally, opposition to any one sub-question will require voters to vote against the remaining two sub-questions tainted by the one which they oppose. The three sub-questions are completely unnecessary. We already have Federal constitutional measures on these subjects and no-one can seriously suggest that these freedoms are currently under threat in Australia. (Extension of time granted) I thank the Attorney-General and the House for their courtesy in granting an extension of time. The three sub-questions in question No. 4 are completely unnecessary. The whole concept is ill founded, as was said by one of our former Chief Justices, Sir Harry Gibbs, on 12 December 1984. I quote from the Sydney Morning Herald:
If society is tolerant and rational it does not need a Bill of Rights. If it is not, no Bill of Rights will preserve it.

The Russians have a finely worded Bill of Rights. That comes as a surprise. But of course it is worthless. One of the strong objections to the Bill of Rights-it applies equally to question No. 4-is that by making very general statements the job of defining the statements is left to the High Court of Australia. This wrongly places the High Court in the position of having to define, refine and interpret motherhood statements. This is a policy function of the elected representatives in the Parliament; it is not a function suited to the unelected judges on the High Court. The fine print is that by defining rights they can be limited, and such an approach is contrary to our Westminster traditions.

Lastly, as a general point, our Constitution is a document to regulate the forms and jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Parliament and to provide a framework for our federal system. It is not a vehicle for a Bill of Rights and it was never intended to be used as a vehicle to control the legitimate legislative responsibilities of the States. For these general reasons, the proposals should be opposed. But there are, of course, specific objections to each of the sub-questions. The first sub-question proposes to extend the trial by jury guarantee. We have had the existing constitutional guarantee since 1901. The founding fathers put that into the Constitution. At the time one of them got up at a convention and said, `We all know this is worthless. It will never provide anything but no-one has been able to think of a better form of words for it'. Numerous conventions of elected representatives have tried to find a better form of words but without success and the Attorney-General has not succeeded either. He already has some drafting problems. The Constitutional Commission considered different proposals from two advisory committees and now the Attorney has differed from his own advisers. It is not even clear that the Bill actually does extend the guarantee to the States and the Territories, and for some reason the Attorney has rejected the advice of Messrs Finemore and Ewens, QC, and omitted the requirement of trial by jury for capital offences.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no.

—I have read the Attorney's second reading speech and I think he has a lot of explaining to do to his constituency about why he would not want to extend the right of trial by jury to those offences which may in the future carry the death penalty. The States already have statutory trial by jury provisions and the Attorney has given no reason why the Federal Constitution should impose itself into the running of the criminal justice systems of the States. The form of the sub-question will allow the States, if so inclined, to establish juries of fewer than 12 jurors. Most people think of trial by jury as trial by 12 jurors. That is not what is contained in this proposal. The provision also allows for majority verdicts. Does the Attorney think that a conviction on the basis of a decision of a majority of two out of a jury of three is the right standard to enshrine in our Constitution for trial by jury in Australia. Additionally, the sub-question does not guarantee trial by jury where the only penalties are very substantial monetary fines. The Attorney has failed to explain why such defendants should be denied this fundamental protection.

SPEECH.PARA: The second sub-question is to extend the guarantee of freedom of religion. This sub-question, if it became part of our Constitution, would open a Pandora's box. The Attorney is just playing with fire. The sub-question widens the existing provision to cover not only laws but also Executive action and to extend it to the States and Territories. Again the sub-question is ill founded. The original intention of the existing provision was basically to prevent the establishment of a state church and to prevent discrimination within the Public Service. This proposed clause has the problem not only possibly of validating extreme practices conducted under the guise of religion but also of limiting or preventing normal religious observance in many aspects of our Australian way of life. There is absolutely no explanation as to how this will affect the management of our government school systems, let alone the difficult issue of funding of non-government schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't affect it.

—The Attorney-General can sit there and make his interjections but the reality is that he can give no guarantees about what his proposal may mean because it will be left to the High Court to interpret its real meaning. The Attorney is retiring early and if this question is carried he will leave behind him a real time bomb.

SPEECH.PARA: The third sub-question provides for just terms for persons whose property is acquired by any government. `Property' is not defined. However, at law, `property' has a very wide meaning: it is not only real estate. The title in the Bill and the question refer to `fair terms' but should read `just terms'. This change in words appears to be a ploy to enable the Government to peddle its questions under the false description of `a fair deal for Australia'. It is phoney to say that this will ensure people a fair deal. It will not stop governments acquiring for wrongful purposes. It will not even require a uniform standard. At best there will be a minimum standard set by the High Court. The provision will be full of unintended consequences because of the wide definition of `property' and it will not stop governments zoning land to limit land use and enjoyment. Such activities will not attract compensation regardless of this proposal. There is no guarantee of appeal procedures and no guaranteed protection of the rights of third parties. It is a minimal provision and again, as with the other proposals, the Attorney has failed to explain the necessity to apply this proposal to the States.

The most common example used will be the Coal Acquisition Act in New South Wales. People in that State have undertaken the best remedy possible: they have elected a Greiner government. The reality is that the existing constitutional guarantee in respect of Commonwealth acquisitions is grossly inadequate, as the Government is well aware. That is why the previous coalition Government called for a report on the issue from the Law Reform Commission. The Commission's report has called for a detailed legislative response from the Government. In recently announcing the intention to introduce a Bill to implement the Commission's recommendations, the Government has admitted that the constitutional guarantee is totally inadequate in itself to achieve a proper framework for compensation. Obviously the proposed guarantee does not put in place at the State level this sort of detailed legislative framework without which the proposal is of little real value.

We have examined these proposals very carefully. Our Constitution has served Australia well and the Government has failed miserably to validate its case for change. I am genuinely disappointed at the way in which the Government has handled the debate. It has not even been prepared to seek common ground and it has flatly rejected our attempts to find some bipartisan approach.

The Attorney-General, in summing up his very brief address when presenting the referendum Bills, said these proposals would not mean any increase in Commonwealth power at the expense of the States or of the people of Australia. As I have shown, this is patently wrong. These questions would give more power for the Executive, more power for the Prime Minister, less power for the Parliament and, in the end, less power for the people. That is the bottom line. When one reads the fine print one finds that there is nothing in these proposals for the people. The referendum proposals are for the benefit of this Labor Government. The questions are misleading. They contain drafting ambiguities and, if carried, would not enhance our Constitution.

Let it not be said that in proposing four No responses to the referendum questions put by the Government the coalition parties are taking anything but a positive attitude to our Constitution. On the contrary, it will be apparent to all fair-minded Australians from what I have said today that the coalition has carefully considered each of the proposed measures in detail and on their merits and has found them to be deficient on both policy and technical grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my first speech on the back bench of this Parliament for 20 years. I am proud to join my colleague the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in supporting the four proposed amendments to the Australian Constitution. All four proposals are moderate and reasonable and should be supported by all reasonable people. I will not waste my precious minutes expressing how negative and moribund the Federal Opposition's attitude to these proposals is. Because of my experience and background I want to concentrate on one of the proposals before the House. I am particularly pleased to support the proposition that local government be recognised in the Australian Constitution. Since before Federation local government has been an integral part of the Australian system of representative democracy and public administration. That fact needs to be acknowledged. Local government deserves to be recognised. The Constitution should be more accurately reflected in the real Australian federal system.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the early 1970s local government has been evolving from its traditional roads, gutters and garbage mentality into a sophisticated and multifunctional level of community government. In many areas it has now undertaken a diversity of social and economic development tasks. In that process local government is making a significant national contribution to meeting the local needs of the Australian people.

Despite the fact that local government is performing a variety of functions on behalf of the Commonwealth and the States-functions which the Commonwealth and the States could not so readily and effectively perform-local government remains either ignored or taken for granted in decision making about policies and programs. The absence of any reference to local government in the Constitution has permitted the neglect of local government, deprived it of status as a partner in the provision of public services and denied it the opportunity to make a fuller social contribution.

Constitutional recognition of local government will have two far-reaching consequences. Firstly, it will establish the status of local government as a party with which the Commonwealth and the States ought to consult and negotiate. This should enable local government to participate more fully in the design and implementation of policies and so improve the responsiveness and cost-effectiveness of the nation's public sector. Secondly, constitutional recognition will extend to local government the application of principles of natural justice. Whilst this will not shield incompetent or corrupt councils from dismissal, it will ensure that due process is followed and that local electors are not disenfranchised, which will strengthen our democratic system. My personal view-and I have expressed it many times-is that local government should not be dismissed by anybody other than those people who elected the municipality. But my personal view is not the issue here. This constitutional amendment does not interfere with a State government's right to dismiss an incompetent or corrupt council.

As a Labor member of parliament, as a former Minister for Urban and Regional Development in the Whitlam Government and as a former Minister for Local Government in the Hawke Government, for seven years I have been associated, as a Minister, with the administration of local government. I have seen it evolve and broaden its base, as I described earlier. I am proud of local government that is evolving at that grassroots level. I am proud to be associated with this proposal for the constitutional recognition of local government. I have been an anti-centralist all my political life. I have always wanted people to have greater power over their lives and to be able to have a say in decisions which affect them where they live and work. Even within the Australian Labor Party I have struggled against those who have sought to centralise power within an elite.

In supporting this proposal for the constitutional recognition of local government, I stress that I am not adopting a party political stance. I am supporting the local representatives of the Australian people. Constitutional recognition is wanted by local government. It is not being imposed by the centre of government. The pressure comes from the grass roots. It comes from local government representatives across the political spectrum. I remind my colleagues opposite that it has the support at the grass roots level of the National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia, the Labor Party and of Independents. Local government is claiming with one voice its legitimate right to be recognised. In this place we have, beyond party politics, an obligation to put to the people the aspirations of their local representatives.

I recall the situation in 1974 when the Federal Labor Government initiated a referendum to enable the Commonwealth to make direct grants to local government and to borrow money on behalf of local government. At that time we sought to tell local government what was good for it. We were overzealous-I might add that is an understatement. Local government was suspicious and divided. It was one of our major opponents at the time. The referendum proposition was rejected. It was carried only in New South Wales. But 47 per cent of the Australian people supported the proposal. Today, 14 years on, we are responding to local government. We are responding to a momentum which has been building up within local government from the time of the Hobart Constitutional Convention in 1983 when a subcommittee was set up under the chairmanship of Doug Lowe, a former Labor Premier of Tasmania.

I recall meeting with Doug Lowe and Greg Percival, a Liberal member of the upper House of New South Wales-both members from different sides of the political fence-as members of the structure of government subcommittee of the Constitutional Convention. They put to me a series of possible measures for effecting the constitutional recognition of local government. Their `maximum' position involved the insertion of a clause in the Constitution formally to recognise local government. Their `minimum' position concerned the adoption of a draft declaration of principles to be attached to the Constitution.

Initially I was advised that local government representatives favoured the `minimum' position. But, when I put that to the test, I found overwhelming support from local government for the `maximum' position, right across the nation. At the 1985 Brisbane Constitutional Convention the `maximum' position was put by Greg Percival-a Liberal member of parliament, as I said-on behalf of the Local Government Association of Australia. I, on behalf of the national Government, seconded the proposal. The position was argued and carried across party lines. It was the decision of the 1985 Constitutional Convention which was first submitted to the Constitutional Commission. Subsequently the Australian Council of Local Government Associations gave additional support to that proposition in submissions to the Constitutional Commission. I instructed my Department, particularly the Commonwealth Office of Local Government, to submit a supporting case from the perspective of the Australian Government.

The report of the Constitutional Commission recommended recognition of local government along similar lines to the proposal adopted by the Brisbane Convention. The Australian Government, consistent with its position in 1985, has accepted the recommendation of the Commission relating to local government. It is a modest but significant recommendation. It is a long overdue proposal. It is a bipartisan proposition. It is recommended by people of integrity from both sides of politics. It is supported overwhelmingly in local government by representatives of all political persuasions, and it deserves support.

Finally, I say to my friends in local government, irrespective of their political persuasion, `Between now and the time that the Australian people vote on the referendum, get out into the highways and byways, stir up the possum, tell your story and leave no stone unturned to make sure that the proposal for which you have been fighting for so many years is supported by the Australian people'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) addressed his remarks to the Constitution alteration proposal relating to local government, I would like to start my remarks by referring to that same proposal-that is, the third referendum proposal to insert in the Constitution a provision which is described in the heading of the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill as a provision to recognise local government. Nobody could doubt the sincerity with which the honourable member for Reid promoted his case. It is true that for many years he has been an unswerving advocate of the interests of local government and an unswerving advocate of having local government recognised in the Constitution and generally given its proper recognition in this country. What I want to say to the honourable member for Reid and to the House by way of reply is that the constitutional amendment proposed by the Government does not achieve any of those things.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me address two of the points made by the honourable member for Reid. Again, I emphasise that he put forward his arguments with great sincerity. Firstly, he maintains that the Bill proposes a referendum question which will give constitutional recognition to local government. What the honourable member means by that and what local government organisations during this long debate have meant by that is some recognition by the Federal Government of local government, some obligation to deal with local government directly, and some provision along the lines that the Federal Government hereby acknowledges the great worth and value of local government. The point must be made simply but clearly that the Bill, the proposed change to the Constitution, does not do that. All that it does at best is to make an obvious proposition, namely, that local government is the creature and the responsibility of the States. The question can be asked: Why is there any need to write into the Constitution such an obvious and self-serving proposition as that? To state the obvious, local government bodies are created by State parliaments. They are financed-although partly by revenue which the Commonwealth raises-by rates which are imposed under State government legislation. It must be said at the outset that the Constitution, when and if it is amended, will not recognise local government in the way that the honourable member for Reid and some of the local government advocates have believed.

The second point that must be made in reply to the honourable member is as follows: he said, `When this amendment is carried it will force the Federal Government to consult with local government'. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker: Is there a word or a syllable in this proposal which will oblige the Commonwealth Government to do that? The answer is no. There is not a word, a syllable or even an implication that the Commonwealth Government will have to do that. Those who herald this proposal as imposing on the Commonwealth some new obligation to consult with local government, bow down the knee before it and weigh up in its deliberative processes what local government wants are really deluding themselves. If they really want that sort of robust provision in the Constitution they should vote no to this proposal and put up some alternative proposal.

There is one other point that must be made about his proposal with respect to local government. It gives the lie to the whole exercise of the present government so far as these proposals are concerned. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to bear with me while I read-and it has been read in this debate already-the exact proposal that is being put forward. It is set out in the following words:
Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected . . .
How will they be elected? This is the answer:
in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

Having gone through this whole exercise about one vote one value-the importance of enshrining it in the Constitution-and having gone through the whole exercise of the rhetoric of so-called democratic elections, what do we find when we come to the third proposal? Do we find that these great principles of one vote one value are to be enshrined for local government? No; second best is good enough for local government. Let me repeat: local government bodies, according to this Bill, are to be elected `in accordance with the laws of the State'. The Australian Labor Party apparently believes it is all right if State A establishes local government bodies to be elected on a property franchise basis, but State B has local government bodies elected on a franchise basis determined by whether the voter is an owner of property, an occupier of property or a white adult male owning property worth $100,000 or more. Under this proposal those entitlements, those obligations, and those rights to vote-whether it is compulsory voting or voluntary voting-will differ from State to State, if that is what the individual States provide in their laws.

Is it commonsense to change the Constitution so that embodied in the Constitution itself is the entitlement of States to have varied franchises for the election to local government bodies? It is absurd and impractical, and it is simply one more reason why we on this side of the House say that this proposed amendment to the Constitution will achieve nothing at all. As I have shown, it not only simply enshrines a self-evident proposition, namely, that the State parliaments are responsible for local government, but it also goes further than that and has within it the seeds of inconsistency between one State and another with respect to the franchise. That seems to me by itself to be the end of the argument. To suggest that we should put into the Constitution a so-called guarantee of local government and at the same time say that the States can differ as to the franchises for election to local government bodies is, by itself, enough reason to oppose this proposal. For those reasons, amongst others, we say that people would be well advised to vote no with respect to this proposal. It achieves nothing and it has within it a formula for absolute chaos. I put that at the beginning of my remarks because the honourable member for Reid spoke about the local government issue.

Having said that, I go back to the first proposal, which is the proposal so misleadingly described in its title as being to provide for four-year terms for the House of Representatives and the Senate. It is misleading to describe it as simply a Bill to provide an amendment for four-year terms, because the proposal itself goes much further than that. It goes so far that it overturns one of the very basic principles of our federal structure. We can have an argument, if we want, about the need to have State governments and parliaments. We can have an argument, if we like, about the need for a Senate. But, if we agree-and I think we all agree in this House-that there is merit in having a system of States, and if we want those States to continue in some harmonious relationship, we must have a House of the Parliament where the interests of the States are balanced. After all, that is why the House of Representatives is elected on the basis of having electorates of roughly equal numbers, and therefore a different number of seats or electorates from each State, and why, in contrast, each State sends to Canberra the same number of senators as the others irrespective of the population of that State. So it is at the root of our system.

When the founding fathers wanted to establish this Federation, they decided quite rightly that they had to provide some element of the parliamentary system where the interests of the States were balanced, and they came up with this sensible solution of having a bicameral system and, in the upper House of that system, each of the several States, irrespective of their populations, electing the same number of senators as the others. That is why-it is not widely known-the Senate was originally proposed not to be called the Senate but the States Assembly, and in the early drafts of the Constitution the Senate was so described.

The founding fathers went on-and this is not simply ancient history; it is something which is alive today as much as it was then-to decide that, if they wanted continuity, if they wanted to provide stability and if they really wanted the Senate to be a proper House of review, to have a serious second look at legislation and at the same time to keep a balance between the States, they had to have a rotation of senators. The reason why the Government is being so misleading about this whole proposal is that it seeks to hide the fact that it is abolishing this very foundation of the federal system, the rotation of senators-that they do not all retire at the same time, as we do at every House of Representatives election, but rather that there is a rotation and only half of them retire each time and therefore there is more continuity. That guarantees that the States have a solid insurance policy to preserve their rights and that the individuals living or residing and voting in those States can say to themselves with absolute conviction, `Yes, we have a House of review which is going to have a second look at legislation and which is going to make sure that the smallest States are not ground into the dirt by the larger and more populous States'.

Let me put the importance of this rotation of senators not in my own words but by quoting to the House what Professor Geoffrey Sawer said on the rotation of senators and how important it is. Professor Geoffrey Sawer, of course, is acknowledged as having been one of our great constitutional lawyers. At the time of the hearings of the Select Committee on the Constitution Alteration (Avoidance of Double Dissolution Deadlocks) Bill in 1950, Professor Sawer said:
. . . there is no point . . .
I repeat:
. . . there is no point in having a House of review unless you have some degree of difference between the points of view of the Houses, and you get that more with the staggered system of election.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could not be clearer.

—It could not be clearer, as my colleague says. As Professor Sawer says, there is no point in having a Senate, a House which claims to keep a balance between the States, if we are simply going to have in the Senate a pale shadow, an echo, of the House of Representatives. We may as well do away with the Senate altogether. We may as well do away altogether with any pretence that the States are protected by this balance that is created in the Senate if this proposal put up by the Government is passed.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, if we are honest about it, we should then get on to a serious debate about whether we really need a Senate at all, or whether we really need States at all. I happen to believe that we do. I believe that a system of State governments provides a very sensible dissemination of power. But, if we are going to be honest about it and say that we support this proposal that the Government is putting up, we should be completely honest and say, `Henceforth, if this proposal is passed, there is no point in having a Senate at all. It is simply going to be a pale shadow of the House of Representatives. Indeed, there is no point at all in having States'. For that reason that proposal can fairly be described as being utterly destructive of the whole federal system which we not only support, I hope genuinely, but also have given acknowledgment to and recognition since 1901.

Time is limited and I must press on. I say simply that the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has really demolished the second proposal, the so-called one vote one value proposal, and in my view there is very little more that can be said about it. The only additional thing that can be said is that, even if the seond proposal of one vote one value, as it is called, is passed, it will not do anything to remove the so-called gerrymanders. A State will be quite lawfully entitled to say, `You criticised the boundaries of our State electorates. We have done what you have asked. We have State electorates of roughly equal numbers and therefore they are very democratic. But look at the way we have drawn the boundaries. We have drawn them for our own convenience'. So, anyone who thinks that this measure will get rid of gerrymanders is simply deluding himself, as this proposal is not going to achieve what its advocates maintain.

I come back again, as I must keep coming back, to this: we have a federal system. It is no role of the Federal Parliament or the Federal Government to rectify what it sees as defects in a State system. It is up to the States. If we depart from that principle, I say again, we must start honestly to argue this question as to whether we need State governments and whether we want them at all. We cannot have it both ways. If we accept a federation and if we accept the desirability of States and State parliaments, we must leave to the States those matters that are properly within their province. So, that proposal likewise must be rejected.

I want to address a few very brief remarks to the fourth proposal. Who could argue against freedom of religion? Who could argue against the importance and necessity of compensation when governments acquire property? Who could argue, in most cases, about the necessity for jury trials? Nobody on this side of the House argues against any of those propositions. When we had the big debate about the Bill of Rights we ourselves were great advocates of basic freedoms; for instance, the freedom not to join a trade union if that is what one decided. Of course the Government never went along with that basic principle. We are not opposed to these basic rights. What we are opposed to is dressing them up as constitutional guarantees and putting them into a written constitution, forcing them into a mould and then giving way on all responsibility and saying to the judges, `You fix it up. There is freedom of religion for you; put that into practice'.

When we assume responsibilities, we do it properly, because if the people do not like what we do they show us the door at the next election; they kick us out. I have left this Parliament on two occasions, but then come back. That can be done. I have no complaint about that. That is called democracy. We are elected if the people approve of us and we are defeated if the people do not approve of what we or our party have been doing. Let us not pretend that we are representatives of the people if we put propositions such as these into the Constitution and then say to unelected judges who remain on the bench until they are 70 or 72-or in some cases until they die, if they want to stay there that long-`You fix it up'.

This is the way the world has gone. It is very sad. We can divide judges these days into lawyers on the one hand and trendies on the other. They pick up causes and say, `This is a fashionable cause. We will expand this right; we will do this, we will do that. This Government has gone beyond what we as judges think is proper for it.' They never have to answer to the people. Judges are never answerable to the people on that sort of test.

We say that if people believe in these basic principles-as you do, Mr Deputy Speaker, and as we in the Opposition do-they should do something about it; they should put their principles into practice. But they should not go through this bromide nonsense of writing them into the Constitution and then washing their hands of the whole thing and leaving it to the judges. That is the easy way out and will achieve nothing. If it does anything, it will make the whole process much more complicated. How do we tell the judges what they are to read into freedom of religion, compensation, just terms? How do we tell them that? We leave it all to them. The Government will be sowing a harvest of chaos and uncertainty of enormous dimensions if it proceeds with this legislation. For those reasons we are opposed to all of the proposals before the House.
