SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill, I wish initially to pursue a theme supported by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). When it became clear late on election night in July last year that the Hawke Labor Government had been returned for a third term, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in congratulating the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the win, commented that, despite our differences, the things which unite us as Australians are greater than those which divide us. It is a sentiment which all Australians share.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite differences in background, education, income, faith and political view, there are certain common underlying views which all Australians share-things such as confidence in free speech, the rights of each person to a fair go, and the inherent value of each individual. Many other nations, such as the United States of America, share these assumptions and have them recognised in their Constitutions. Other nations pay those values lip service, while others again are not ashamed to deny them altogether. In Australia, despite the fact that these rights are not espoused in any legal document-not even, as some mistakenly assume, in the common law-we have been fortunate indeed that, for the most part, Australian governments have exercised their powers within those associations.

It therefore bewildered me when, after a phenomenally short period, the Opposition decided to oppose all four questions posed by this legislation. I find it puzzling because, with the possible exception of one, all four questions reflect elements of those underlying assumptions about the way we are governed to which all Australians would subscribe. I can understand why the Opposition would be opposed to the one vote one value principle. It is all right for the Queensland branch of the Liberal Party to cry out in support of true democracy in that State-after all, it has been unceremoniously dumped from any say in government by its National Party colleagues, who can govern on little more than 30 per cent of the vote-but its Federal counterparts must try to keep the coalition together at all costs, and the price of that alliance in this case is that they must compromise their integrity. I can understand that as a political necessity, even though I do not condone it. It is obvious that the Liberal members of this House will sell out their principles to hold together their shaky coalition with the National Party at any cost.

The question of four-year parliamentary terms has widespread community support. The electorate has favoured it for the majority of State governments for some time. Business groups have expressed support since the suggestion was first mooted, and the Opposition itself even made positive noises about it. However, as we discovered last month with the media ownership rules, the Opposition does not always mean what it says. The Opposition is opposing this legislation because, it claims, we have tried to diminish Senate power at the same time as introducing four-year terms-this because full Senate elections will take place at the same time as House of Representatives elections.

Before dealing with that problem, let me just look at an example of the real concerns that the Liberal Party has with overseeing the integrity and authority of upper Houses. There seems little need to recall its 1975 coup, when it abused the powers of the Senate to block Supply. This was not because it objected to any features of the Budget; no, it passed the Budget immediately it received word that it had what it wanted. Its real reason was that it wished to force an election at a time unfavourable to the Government. That is the Opposition's concern for the Senate. To the Opposition it is not the House of review but a means of forcing elections and thwarting governments.

We do not need to go back 13 years to see the Liberal Party's true feelings for upper Houses. Only last month we saw the Opposition make a feeble attack upon the authority of the Legislative Council in New South Wales. Having failed to gain a majority in the Council, it proceeded to attack the President, Mr Johnson, calling for his resignation. Did years of precedent matter to the Opposition then? Did the tradition that Presidents serve their full term unless guilty of misconduct even enter the minds of members of the Opposition? The pathetic attempt to remove the President was made even more ridiculous by the arguments of Mr Pickering, the Government Leader in the Legislative Council. In a speech that sounded more like a testimonial to Mr Johnson's qualities of fairness, impartiality and integrity as a President, Mr Pickering could find nothing in the Constitution or in State history which would support his argument. `Nevertheless', he said, `Mr Johnson must go'. The Opposition did not have the numbers to achieve this, but if it did it would have successfully kissed goodbye to a precedent of Legislative Council management that the Labor Party had honoured when it first took power. That is the extent of the Liberal and National parties' concern for upper Houses. Their insistence on the authority of a House of review is paramount only when they control it. When they do not they sing a different tune altogether.

The Leader of the Opposition has argued that he opposes the change because he does not want to see the Senate reduced to having its mandate controlled by the Prime Minister. If he honestly believes that, he is sadly out of touch with the practices of government in this country. The Prime Minister may control when an election is held, but he does not control who will win it. If this question succeeds, the only change to the Senate will be that the full Senate will be subject to the choice of the people at each election. There will be no hangers-on in the other place from a previous election. The people, not the Senate or even the Prime Minister, will determine who shall govern and with what impositions in the House of review. This must inevitably lead to the question: What are the conservatives frightened of? Why are they worried about extending the power of the people themselves to decide? As with the question of fair elections, we must ask: Are the conservatives really committed to the ideals of democracy?

When we read the statements on this score by the President of the Liberal Party, Mr Elliott, we quickly see that the question is not merely rhetorical. The aspiring leader of the parliamentary Liberal Party is not enthusiastic about the people's say in government, to say the least. He has espoused the view at more than one public gathering that elections and franchise should be limited and that power should be concentrated into the hands of the few.

It is this factor which makes the theme of the present Leader of the Opposition all the more puzzling. One would have thought that, in the desperate battle to be seen as a real leader, the honourable member for Bennelong might have been more attracted to proving his commitment to democracy. But he has lost his chance now. In making his pathetic plea for the powers of the Senate, powers to which I believe he and his colleagues by their actions have proven they are not committed, other than to exploit them cynically at opportune moments, the Leader of the Opposition has aligned himself with the old born-to-rule attitude of his conservative masters. I hope that the Australian electorate will see his sentimental appeal to the sanctity of the upper House for what it really is.

The recognition of local government is another area which I would have thought enjoyed the universal approval of all Australians, not because it represents a fundamental human right to which all people subscribe but because local government is an intrinsic part of the history and political make-up of Australian society. A Constitution should reflect the attitudes, aspirations and institutions of the society which models it. Local government is a vital element in our society, dealing with the bread and butter services that directly affect people's living standards: kerbs and guttering, libraries, roads, fences, noise and, of increasing importance, the welfare areas. Certainly these may be less glamorous areas of interest, but they are vital nonetheless. Constituents may have strong feelings about Australia's links with Pacific nations, but the things that will bring them to action are whether their roads are properly sealed or their garbage cleared. Fail at the local level, and one can forget about winning the hearts and minds of the people at State and Federal levels.

I cut my political teeth as an alderman on Canterbury City Council and finally had the privilege of serving as that council's Mayor. In that time I fought many a battle with conservative aldermen and when I think of the quality of people with whom I locked horns then and the type of people with whom I sometimes deal on the three councils that are within the borders of the electorate of Banks I wonder what those Liberal aldermen think of the Opposition's rejection of this question.

Those who work in local government as elected representatives know only too well the time and effort they must devote to this service. Only they know of the irate callers at midnight complaining about neighbours' dogs, the deluge of calls every time there is a flood in the area and the time spent away from family and friends on council business. Honourable members not acquainted with the demands of being on councils might like to reflect that it is extremely demanding work with little monetary reward. To oppose this Bill shows a distinct lack of support and consideration for the job done by more than 8,000 elected representatives and 180,000 employees who serve our 836 local councils. It shows a certain mean spiritedness against this institution which guarantees that the people have representatives to provide them with basic services. In recent times in New South Wales there has been a tendency for Liberal Party candidates to advertise themselves as Liberals when they run for council and this is a welcome change from previous years when they ran under the veil of Independents. I should think now Liberals will be even less likely to declare their political affiliations to the voters. By its opposition the Liberal Party has told the Australian electorate, in no uncertain terms, that it does not think local government is worthy of constitutional recognition.

It is not as if the conservatives can argue their way out by saying that the new provision will endanger present rights. If corrupt councils need to be eliminated by State governments, they can be. If amalgamations are needed or if boundaries should be redrawn, they can be. All this provision does is make local government a guaranteed institution under the Constitution. At present local councils are the creatures of State government legislation, able to be created, changed or eliminated at the States' pleasure. We, on the Government side, would like to make their position more permanent and prestigious.

There is no question of the right to local government being threatened. There seems to be a belief that a constitutional amendment should be put forward only where a right is under threat. That is not my understanding of what a constitution should be. A constitution should not only protect rights; it should also be a statement to all the world of what we are, of what we cherish and of what we stand for. An excellent case in point concerns freedom of religion. It is undeniable that the principle is one of the underlying presumptions that unite us, of which I spoke before, yet the only reference we find to the belief of Australians in the principle is in section 116 of the Constitution, which provides inter alia in rather unenthusiastic language that the Commonwealth Public Service will have no entry examination based on religion and that no public holidays shall be imposed on the ground of religion. Apart from the fact that we offend this section every Christmas and Easter, surely this section does not go far enough. It does not adequately express the tolerance and respect for the faith of others that is a hallmark of Australian society. If we accept that a constitution should reflect what we are and what we aspire to, surely something more needs to be said.

The same can be said of trial by jury. It is a right that all Australians take for granted. This should not be so when one considers the fight that took place to secure it. From the earliest days of the colony of New South Wales, free settlers and convicts were subjected to the same process of military justice. As more and more settlers in New South Wales became free, the home Government refused to change the system. Far from carrying with them the laws of their home as they applied to their new environment, which the common law presumed, these settlers were subjected to the rigours of rough military justice. With each new charter of justice, the people of the colony called for three things in particular: their own elected government, the elimination of the old court system and the establishment of trial by a jury of peers.

The trial by jury represented to the colonists a recognition of their legal and political maturity. It was proof that they were responsible enough to deal justice out themselves without the imprimatur of the home Government. When finally granted, it was greeted with more enthusiasm by most colonists than the decision to allow for elected members of the council. By the same token the present Bill attempts to give constitutional validity to an institution that is a proud and valued part of the Australian legal tradition. We seek its incorporation into the Constitution not because it is under threat but because we want its value fully recognised.

When one takes all the referenda questions together, one common thread appears-the commitment to increase the power of the people and the quality of government. By fair election, we would have all Australians voting with equal power, eliminating the farce of the Queensland zonal system. By longer terms we would give governments more opportunity of executing policy in accordance with their mandates while making the Senate far more representative of the views of the people. By recognising local government we are merely acknowledging the valuable contribution of that institution and ensuring in the Constitution the right of all people to have a say in the running of their lives at this basic level.

Finally, the rights and freedoms Bill acknowledges principles and institutions valued by all Australians. The Opposition may do well to consider its stance on these issues, which I believe Australians as a whole support. It would be a tragedy if the questions raised by these referendum Bills were to be defeated because I believe they go to the heart of legally recognising the aspirations of all Australians. Opposition members who are opposing these measures will be seen as hypocrites by the Australian community. They will be seen as selling out on important democratic principles. We, on the Government side of the House, support democratic principles and, therefore, wholeheartedly support the Bills before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1215 and Magna Carta, through the Bill of Rights to Simon de Montefort's first Parliament in the halls of Westminster, the British common law tradition has established the basis from which we, in this Parliament, exercise the responsibilities that are part of the Parliament of Australia. In 1901 the compact between the federating States was such as to give to the Commonwealth for the first time an independent status. Since 1901 there have been few changes to that Constitution by way of referendum. This is not because there has not been advocacy for change but because the people of Australia have not been in a position where they have been able to see justification for the adoption of recommended changes.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true not only that changes have been made by way of referenda-in a moment I shall say a little about the process of constitutional change through the courts-but also that the people of Australia know that when the Australian Labor Party is in government it, far more than any other party, seems to seek constitutional change. In 1973 under the prime ministership of Gough Whitlam the first Constitutional Convention was convened in Sydney. It brought together the three arms of government-local government, State government and Federal government. Through constitutional Conventions held over the years and through their committees, opportunities were provided for full and proper scrutiny of the provisions in the Constitution which were either anachronistic or not considered suitable for modern day requirements.

The process of change through the conventions that allowed those who were the direct participants in exercising the responsibilities of government in this country were not good enough for the Hawke Government. It decided that it was not for those involved to have a say in determining change so the Government constituted the Constitutional Commission. In 1985 those few selected Australians were designated not because they represented a broad breadth of Australian opinion, for who among them represented the ordinary men and women, who among them represented the ordinary voter? However, they represented a diverse range of opinions and nearly $6m later they have produced a mass of verbiage. That is a reflection of it; it has produced three, six, eight volumes and the final report is still to come. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) did not even bother to wait for the final report before presenting to his Cabinet colleagues proposed legislation for the Constitution Alteration Bills.

It is true that some modifications were taken into account as a result of the first proposition, which I shall come to in a moment, and that the Attorney-General has informed the House that he has taken note of the Constitutional Commission. But let us be realistic. The Constitutional Commission was selected by the Government to consider what it thought was the most appropriate means of changing the Constitution. The Attorney-General has not even been able to persuade it that the form of the referendum to be put to the Australian people in the first question is the right form. If he cannot persuade the Constitutional Commission that he is right, why the devil should all those Australians who will be called upon on the first or second Saturday in September to vote on these questions suddenly believe that the Attorney-General has it right and, therefore, that they should affirm the first proposition?

I am concerned that the whole things smacks of Labor expediency. The Labor Party does not like the existing Constitution because of the checks and balances provided within it. The Labor Party does not like the fact that within the existing Constitution there is a capacity for a bicameral system, including the Australian Senate, which is probably one of the most independent Houses of review within the whole Westminster system. Australia's Senate is different from the Senate of the United States of America. Our Senate is different from the House of Lords; our Senate is different from each of the legislative councils where they exist around Australia. In our bicameral system, our Senate has particularly allocated for it specific powers and rights. Through it, each of the States of the Commonwealth is given an equal voice, although the Territories, of course, because they are Territories rather than originating States, have slightly different representation.

The genesis of these proposals must generate suspicion in the minds of electors in Australia. There is no doubt that the Labor Party's intent to change the Constitution must generate in the minds of anybody a concern as to the validity behind it, not only on the basis of that intention but also in the way the proposed legislation is currently being pursued. As the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) said when he introduced the Opposition's case on the proposed legislation, the fact that the Government, immediately after the opening of the new Parliament House building, introduced the legislation in a special sitting and the fact that in the penultimate week in which we will meet in this House of Representatives chamber we have been called on to debate it smack yet again of the Labor Party's non-preparedness to allow adequate and full consideration of each of the proposals.

I am quite sure we will have a fairly full debate tonight, but it will not be a debate that will allow every member from both sides of the House to participate. It will not be a debate where the people who will be affected will have any input. It will be a debate about a proposal that the Labor Party has put forward and which, as a result of consultations between the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), we know that the Government was not prepared to modify to accommodate what the Opposition parties believed was a valid point with respect to the first question. I refer to the proposal to extend from three years to four the term of the House of Representatives. The Government is not prepared to modify its present stance. This is a take it or leave it proposition and I believe, yet again, that the Australian electorate is being sold short and it needs to be careful when examining these four questions.

From the point of view of the National Party of Australia, I have spoken to all its State parliamentary leaders around Australia; I have spoken to representatives of our organisation and not one of them supports any of the four propositions. In the brief time available to me tonight, I say to the people of Australia that if there is to be constitutional change, the objectives of that change must ensure that the electors of Australia will in some way see that government will be better and that the guarantees of their individual liberties, rights and privileges will be enhanced in some way. If not, there can be no reason for constitutional change. Constitutional change is not good just because it is proposed; it can have a valid basis only if it gives the people of Australia something that they do not now enjoy. I say to the people of Australia that as a result of the adoption of not one of the four proposals are the individuals within Australia-women, men or children-going to be any better off. If they are not going to be any better off, why on earth are we spending this large sum of money? Why on earth did we have the accelerated process of a special sitting of the House of Representatives? Why on earth are we going to have a special Saturday where, right around Australia, people will be called on to vote on proposals that will not enhance their rights and privileges or in any way improve their lifestyle or help to overcome the fundamental problems that affect their way of life in 1988?

The reality is that, in the protections of our Constitution, and in the protections accorded by the British common law, we are already able to enjoy the privileges that this Government suddenly says in the fourth question we must somehow enshrine in the Constitution. Those three principles are already in the Constitution. All the Government seeks to do is to change their application. I want to say to the people of Australia that it is necessary that they understand that the Opposition does not accept that the short titles to each of the Bills-which will be the form of the questions to which they will be called upon to respond Yes or No-explain the contents of the Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are misleading.

—As my colleague says, they are misleading in the extreme. They do not reflect the contents of the Bills. Because the propositions themselves might sound in some way plausible, in no way do they reflect what will happen.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Flinders mentioned earlier, in a paper delivered by Gary Morgan and Michele Levine at the ninth Australian Statistical Conference at the Australian National University today, the following comment was made:

There is no doubt that the proposed referendum questions are biased to try to obtain a `yes' vote. In addition the questions do not honestly convey the issues being asked. With the questions in their present form, the referendums will be rejected . . . The issue will become the questions not the content. Any public opinion polling company who asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility.

With that as the basis for consideration of this debate, I say to the House that there is little doubt that the people of Australia need to be made fully aware of the nature of the questions and what lies behind them.

In my brief time, I will attempt to do something about that. First, we should understand with respect to the first and second questions that the idea of the centralisation of power has always been alive and well in the Labor Party. Honourable members might recall that the former Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, has expressed his point of view in a number of papers. As I understand it, that remains fundamental to the attitudes and stance not only of the Labor Party's constitution but also its platform and its policy. Regardless of whether that is the organisational platform and policy or the parliamentary platform, it is true that what Gough Whitlam has said on successive occasions remains true. For example, on 12 October 1961, with respect to new States, Gough Whitlam said:
The Australian Labor Party is not averse to new States. It is however, averse to sovereign States.
In a paper entitled `The Constitution Versus Labor', in the Chifley Memorial Lecture delivered in Melbourne in 1957, Gough Whitlam said:

Labor finds itself confronted at every turn by a Constitution framed in such a way as to make it difficult to carry out Labor's objectives and interpreted in such a way as to make it impossible to carry them out.

That is why the Labor Party wants to change the Constitution. We all know that there are problems in the application of the first question because it seeks to reduce the term of the Senate. Any reduction in the term of the Senate will inevitably generate a circumstance where there will be a double dissolution on every occasion that there is an election. That will certainly put the senators into a more subject position with respect to the will of the Government of the day than they have been in the past and it will meet the requirement of the Labor Party that the senators House or the States House, as the Senate should perhaps best be known, find itself subject in exactly the same way as the House of Representatives every time there is a campaign before the people.

The National Party rejects the first proposition, for it does not believe that a reduction in the term of the senators, which is contrary to the recommendations of that expensive Commonwealth Constitutional Commission recommendation, should be endorsed. It will make the Senate more subject to the ordinary political factors affecting the day to day votes in this chamber. It will destroy much of that independence that has given to the Australian Senate the character which I think we all respect and which has given to it far greater independent status than most upper Houses. Accordingly, it is a question which the National Party certainly opposes.

The second question is really designed, more than anything else, to apply to the States of Australia laws that the Commonwealth is not prepared to accept as being applicable to itself. If the same laws were to be applicable to the Senate and the House of Representatives, as all honourable members know, every State except New South Wales would have fewer senators, if the number of senators were to be based on the number of people, and, of course, Tasmania would have fewer than five members of the House of Representatives. Therefore, the principle behind this constitutional alteration does not apply to the Commonwealth; it applies to the States alone.

As my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) said earlier tonight, it certainly will not ensure in any way that there will be fair elections, yet that is the question that will be put to the electorate. It will not prevent gerrymanders. It may ensure some apparent numerical equality, but that depends on the time at which one achieves that equality. As my colleague the honourable member for Richmond said, it will not remove the position where, for us to win the next Federal election, I am told, we will have to get better than 52.3 per cent of the vote and where, in New South Wales, the Liberal and National parties will need to win better than 52.7 per cent of the vote.

The reality is that this Bill and this referendum question are not designed to do anything other than meet the requirements of the Democrats for their continued support of the Government in the Senate. This question does not provide for fair elections; it does not remove gerrymanders. What it does is ensure only the perpetuation of a system which this Government wishes to impose on the States of the Commonwealth. It is not a law relating peculiarly to Queensland; it is a law that will certainly adversely affect Western Australia and Tasmania, and probably other States as well. The reality is that this particular Bill, the referendum question supposedly for fair and democratic parliamentary elections, is to enshrine anything but fair and anything but democratic election processes around this country.

The third question is in respect of local government. I had wanted to say a little about this. I was interested to note that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) contributed to debate earlier on this question. It is the very fact that when the honourable member for Reid was Minister for Local Government he tried to introduce amalgamated regional councils that makes us apprehensive of the consequences of this particular referendum question going through. We are not opposed to constitutional recognition of local government. Indeed, most States already have that. The point, as the Bill itself states, is that there is no enhanced authority.

The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, said that it would not give local government anything that the States do not give them now. What it is designed to do is to generate a climate where, yet again, I can see regional local government bodies-with the States reduced in their power-being built up in the way that the honourable member for Reid tried to do as Minister for Local Government in the Whitlam days-States being reduced in power and the whole structural balance of our three-tier system of government being prejudiced.

In the National Party-and, indeed, in both conservative parties-we have a very real respect for local government. Anybody who suggests that in some way this will enhance the powers of local government ought to examine the City of Brisbane Act of 1924, which gives extraordinarily wide powers. I do not have time to read them to the House tonight, but the council can make ordinances on an extraordinarily wide range of responsibilities. Therefore, it is not a matter of giving power to local government; it is not a matter of constitutional recognition of local government. What is it? I suggest the Labor Party sees this as a very good opportunity to aggregate power through some new amalgam of local governments, perhaps in the manner of local government in the past.

The fourth Bill relates to three questions. The fact that the three questions are put together makes me suspicious. In each instance, these rights are not new rights. There is already a right to trial by jury; it is in section 80 of the Constitution. It is not a question of ensuring freedom of religion. Freedom of religion is absolutely sacrosanct so far as every Australian is concerned. Nobody can say that in Australia today the provisions of section 116 of the existing Constitution have, in any sense, meant that people are prejudiced in their opportunity to practise whatever religious faith they wish. Contrary perhaps to the inclination of some of us on this side of the House, at the opening of the new Parliament House the other day we saw opportunities for the expression of attitudes towards the conduct of affairs in that new parliamentary building by representatives of faiths that were not represented at the time of the 1927 opening of this Parliament House. Nobody can suggest that in any way that will be changed. Indeed, I am very apprehensive that, because of the application of this particular law, it is likely that the freedom of religion will be inhibited and not extended.

Finally, the acquisition of property on just terms, similarly, is within placitum (xxxi) of section 51 of the Constitution. I say to the Australian people: this whole referendum proposal is a hoax, and I urge everyone who is a voter in the referendum proposal to vote no four times to the four referendum questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tone of this debate has unfortunately been heated. That is sad because it seems to reflect what commentators are now saying is `confusion, sophistry and snake oil' about the nostrums that have been peddled by the Opposition in the debate. I shall quote from one of the most conservative commentators who write in the national newspapers. Speaking of the Opposition's problem in this debate, Paul Kelly in the Weekend Australian said:

SPEECH.PARA: The problem was revealed by the National Party guru, John Stone, in his recent column in this paper. Stone betrayed the constitutional mania of the Coalition by saying that he had read the proposals, that he didn't usually believe in conspiracy theories, but that there had to be a `hidden agenda' somewhere. The trouble was he couldn't find it.

That is the reality. There is no hidden agenda in these propositions. They are simple, straightforward and commonsense. I suppose we need to start by looking at why we have a written constitution at all. Who better to quote in respect of written constitutions and why they are important than the founder of the Liberal Party of Australia, Sir Robert Menzies. He said:

A written Constitution is an expressed scheme of government designed to give a basic structure in a changing world; not designed to inhibit growth in a growing world, nor to make the contemporary world subject to the political, social, or economic ideas of a bygone age.

Starting on that basis, to give a framework to the way we think and operate within our political structure, the proposals reflect some of the most basic understandings we have about important elements of our democratic life. It is necessary to place those important ingredients into the written Constitution. I am aware that the former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Harry Gibbs, has been quoted in this context. If I might paraphrase his remarks, he said that a written constitution cannot guarantee rights in a society which does not respect those rights. That may be so. Indeed, if we were a banana republic where the troops could move in and bail up the legislature and put it out under a coup, of course no written constitution could prevail. But those are extreme arguments, extreme situations. In the ordinary day to day world we are commonly faced with, we, like Sir Robert Menzies, say that we need a basic framework of laws upon which we can establish our basic conventions that make for our constitutional framework. It is not good enough simply to say that the common law will somehow make good the defects of not having these rights and understandings in the written Constitution. Sir Anthony Mason, the present Chief Justice of the High Court, said:

. . . the common law system, supplemented as it presently is by statutes designed to protect particular rights, does not protect fundamental rights as comprehensively as do constitutional guarantees and conventions on human rights . . . The common law is not as invincible a safeguard against violations of fundamental rights as it was once thought to be.
The passage from which I have quoted is from Sir Anthony's article `The Role of the Constitutional Court in a Federation' in the Federal Law Review, Volume 16, 1986, at page 12.

Given that we want a written constitution to embody some of our fundamental understandings about what makes for a democratic and peaceable civil society, what are the proposals which the Government has put up? Are they extreme? Are they outrageous? Do they conflict with our understandings? Let us go through them. Firstly, we have a provision to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. It is a provision, I believe, that is supported by a majority of electors sickened by too frequent elections. Secondly, we have a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. It is not an extreme proposal. It is a simple spelling out of the basic democratic understandings we all have. Thirdly, we have a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government, which is hardly a socialist proposal. I will come back to that later. Fourthly, we have a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion, and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any government.

These are not proposals which are the stuff of socialist dreams. These are the proposals that ordinary electors in Australia would regard as part of the commonsense ordinary running of government. What then do electors think of these proposals? The electors seem not to share some of the sophistry and snake oil nostrums that have been put up by the Opposition so far. Today in the Australian the referendum questions are said to have won wide approval. The article on the front page of the Australian states:
Each of the four questions on constitutional reform to be put to a referendum on September 3 has received at least two-thirds support among Australian voters.
Support was greatest for the change to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia, with 74 per cent approving of the change.
In the Newspoll, each of the four questions received at least two-thirds support, with majority support for each question in every State.

That is not surprising because these proposals reflect commonsense. We have seen in the debate today the difficulty the Opposition has had to find arguments that might be mounted against these proposals. That also is not surprising. Some of the proposals are, in fact, Liberal Party policy and were put to the people of Australia not 15 years ago, nor 10 years ago, but 10 months ago. They were offered to the people with promises that these very proposals would be put by way of referendum-Liberal Party initiatives. But, of course, when the proposals come from the Labor Party, suddenly, like Senator Stone, they smell a rat. There is no rat. They cannot locate a rat. But somehow, according to the Liberal Party, these must be suspicious proposals; they must be tainted in some way, because they come from the Labor side. That is very unfortunate because we do not have a good history of passing referendums in Australia. There is a real prospect that some of the beat-ups, some of the distortions, some of the lies that have been peddled about these proposals, might actually affect the way people vote. An opportunity for sensible constitutional reform could be lost. These are not just my views; these are views that have been expressed by some of the most conservative institutions in Australia. I have already referred to the article by Paul Kelly. I shall read again from his article which appeared in the Weekend Australian of 14-15 May. He said:

The Hawke Government's referendums are modest, simple and lack ulterior motives. This is no Labor Party political fix. Labor may even lose in the Senate in the short term if the main question is passed. The proposals are a bid to secure moderate constitutional reform around a set of propositions that should have wide support.

He went on to say that in the coming months we will see some of the most outrageous arguments possible mounted against the proposals. The editorial of the Australian of today, Tuesday, 17 May, has the heading `Coalition unity put before principle'. I read from that bastion of left wing thinking, the Australian editorial:

It seems that the Liberal Party is so terrified of the prospect of upsetting the National Party that it is prepared to oppose the constitutional amendments that would strengthen liberal democracy and safeguard private property.

Those are not my views; they are the views of those who make honest, proper judgments about the most callous approach by the Opposition to the truth on these referendum measures. Indeed, it is sad to see the debate degenerating in this way. The tone of the debate seems to be designed to distract people from the merits of these proposals and to turn the argument into one of Labor against Liberal. That should not be the way. We are looking at proposals to reform the Constitution-simple, sensible, ordinary proposals. They are not ones that have been put forward without consultation with a wide range of persons throughout Australia but are ones that have come forward after the most detailed consultations through the public processes and through the Constitutional Commission; they reflect the will of the majority of Australians and reflect their will in a way that unfortunately splits the Liberal Opposition. For example, in the Melbourne Herald of 16 May the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), is quoted as saying that the decision to urge a No vote to the extension of the right to trial by jury and the right to compensation contradicted the Liberals' existing law and order policy. When asked why this had happened the honourable member said, `I am damned if I know'. That is a very apt response because I am damned if I know and I am sure fellow Australians are damned if they know why the Liberals are opposing policies which they put to the Australian people as little as 10 months ago.

Let us turn to some of these so-called `dangerous' proposals. Let us look at the local government proposal, which I think reflects how low this debate can go. This proposal was initially put forward not by the Australian Labor Party but by Mr Greg Percival, MLC, a member of the upper House of the New South Wales Parliament-a Liberal. He put it forward on behalf of the Australian Local Government Association. The proposal has the full support of the Australian Local Government Association and the Australian Association of Lord Mayors. In my State of Tasmania Mr Jim Mooney, the Chairman of the Municipal Association of Tasmania, has condemned the Liberals for their shortsighted approach to this very important issue of recognition of local government.

Who is Mr Jim Mooney? He is a former Liberal member of the Tasmanian House of Assembly for the seat of Bass. I had the pleasure just three days ago of attending a meeting chaired by Lord Mayor Doone Kennedy of the City of Hobart. She said plainly that these proposals reflect a degree of cynicism and distrust of the ordinary people. She said that the proposal on constitutional recognition of local government ought to be passed. These are proposals that command the widest support throughout local government. It is not surprising that in this debate my Federal colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) is not listed on the speakers list. He is a former warden of the Clarence municipality. Senator Paul Calvert also is a former warden of that municipality. I would be very surprised to find them in support of proposals that failed to recognise the important role of local government in our community.

Indeed, I call on the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to do the right thing. He has recognised that the Liberal Party in Queensland cannot bring itself to advocate a No vote for fair elections because in Queensland there is a rampant gerrymander, an unfair system of elections which the Liberals themselves are the victims of. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to exercise the same degree of democratic openness, to allow Tasmanian members of his Party to campaign for recognition of local government, to allow those who hold to the Liberal Party but who do not want to be stifled by this `confusion, sophistry and snake oil' that have been put about to campaign for what I am sure they believe in in their hearts: the right of the Constitution to recognise the important role of local government. I call on the Leader of the Opposition to release his Tasmanian members. It is one of the proud boasts of the Liberal Party that its members have a conscience vote. On this issue we have already seen the leadership of the Liberal Party rolled. The Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) have advocated Yes votes in the confines of their party room. They have not succeeded. But let us at least allow back bench Tasmanian members to go out and campaign for the recognition of local government, a proposal which is not politically controversial. I believe any fair and reasonable minded person would strongly support it.
Finally, I turn to the one vote one value proposition. I am sure that will be distorted greatly. Electors in the south-eastern zone of Queensland--

—I take the point. It certainly is a very distorted system. There are 19,357 electors in the south-eastern zone divisions. For a seat in the northern or western divisions the number is 9,386. Why does a voter in one division have a vote of far greater value than that of an elector in another division? In the Tasmanian Legislative Council there are also distortions. SPEECH.PARA: In the north of the State, in the seat of Tamar, there are 11,951 voters and in South Esk there are 12,641. That means a voter in Pembroke has a vote worth 50 per cent less than the value of the vote of someone in those northern seats. Why should these citizens in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Franklin who vote in Legislative Council seats in Pembroke be treated as lesser citizens than those who live in Hobart, Queenborough or, in the north of the State, in Tamar or South Esk? How can the honourable member for Franklin represent his people fairly without standing up for these people? Honest and concerned electors would say that this is not a fair situation. It is important that there are regular redistributions and fair electoral boundaries to make sure that Federal or State seats contain a similar number of electors.

I remember that when I was a young man I made a contribution in a school competition by reciting a poem about the founder of the Australian Constitution, old Henry Parkes, riding in his carriage. But we do not live in a carriage age any more. Why should not our citizens in the States, for example, have the same rights to fair compensation if their property is acquired as they do if the Commonwealth acquires their property? Why should we not have equal rights to a fair vote? Why should not our politicians have the opportunity of serving a four-year term rather than the rapidity of elections that we have now? I urge all members of this House to adopt, as commonsense, the four sensible proposals that have been put forward. They are not political. They are straightforward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever four referendum proposals should be rejected by a vote of the Australian people it is these proposals. They strip the power of the Senate and emasculate its function. They violate States rights. They bring in a Bill of Rights to this country by the back door. The wording of the questions is fraudulent. It is different from the wording in the Bills, which is quite deceptive. We on this side of the House will be recommending a No vote to all four propositions.

SPEECH.PARA: The poll that came out this morning showed that two-thirds of the people surveyed were in favour of the referendum proposals. That augurs well for us. I cast my mind back to the ID card proposition. Originally about 80 per cent of people were in favour of the ID card. As the weeks and months rolled by, people came steadily over to our side as they realised what was behind the proposition. We will see that happen again.

Virtually all the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission are in line with the constitutional reform objectives of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) adopted at its last conference in Hobart in June 1986. The Constitutional Commission was established in December 1985. If one looks through its list of members one soon sees that it is stacked with ALP sympathisers, people such as Whitlam, Dunstan, Donald Horne, Jack Ferguson-for heaven's sake-Wheeldon, Beazley, Sir John Moore from the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, Rex Patterson, Peter Garrett and various other trendies, academics and trade union officials. There are a couple of token members from our side of the House but no National Party member, of course. One would not expect that. I was interested to read the comments of the Chairman, Sir Maurice Byers, on the front page of the Melbourne Herald yesterday. The article states:
The chairman of the Constitutional Commission, Sir Maurice Byers, accused the Opposition of political motives in their decision to oppose all four referendums.
`Their response to all questions is unfortunate. I'm suggesting the opposition to these proposals is prompted by some other motive' Sir Maurice said.
Perhaps Sir Maurice Byers ought to spell his surname `Bias'. It is totally inappropriate for the Chairman of the Commission to be using this intemperate language.

I turn to question No. 1, which proposes four-year terms for the House of Representatives and the Senate. We welcome four-year terms for the House of Representatives, but certainly not this proposal. The Constitutional Commission recommended that the terms of senators be twice as long as those of members of the House of Representatives. That recommendation was ignored. It also recommended that the term of the House of Representatives be extended to four years with a minimum term of three years. That proposition was ignored. The Government is proposing that senators' terms be reduced from six years to four years and that the term of the House of Representatives be increased from three years to four years, but with no minimum requirement. All senators will go to election every time the House of Representatives goes to election. In other words, the fixed term for the Senate will be totally abolished. To me, that emasculates the Senate's role as an independent House of review.

The rotational system, which has served us well since Federation, is now to be smashed down by this Government, which means that every election from now on will, in effect, be a double dissolution. We may as well do away with the Senate altogether if that is to be the case and extend the House of Representatives. I believe that the Senate has a vital role to play in this country. It has done some great things over the last year or two in stopping the Bill of Rights and the ID card. It is much needed as a watchdog for the people of Australia. This Government constantly talks of the will of the people. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) forgets that the people elected half the senators only in July last year for six-year terms. The Government is now asking the people to vote to reverse their decision, without the Government having to call a double dissolution.

Question No. 2 proposes fair and democratic elections. At face value everybody in Australia would approve of fair and democratic elections. It is only when one looks at what is intended in the Bill that one sees how fraudulent is the wording. The ALP has stooped to using a dishonest device to implement a change in our Constitution to transfer more power to the Commonwealth in respect of State elections. As well as that, it is going to lay down terms and conditions for the States which it is not prepared to apply to its own Commonwealth elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute hypocrisy.

—Indeed. It is hypocrisy. Apparently, what is good for the goose is not good for the gander. These matters are properly matters for the States. But if the people vote this proposal in it will change how the State elections are held, particularly with regard to the upper Houses. In the Labor State of Western Australia the ratio is 11 : 1 in the upper House and 8 : 1 in the lower House. The Federal Government should get its own act together first. The Federal Government will not apply to itself the principle which it trumpets so loudly for the States because it knows the principle to be an absolute nonsense. If it applied this principle to its own upper House, the Senate, Tasmania would be reduced to having one or two senators and would even lose a member in the House of Representatives. In fact, every State would lose senators, with the exception of New South Wales.
—Do as I say, not do as I do.

—Indeed. That sums it up exactly. The proposal will not stop gerrymandering or the rigging of electoral boundaries which the Labor Party has developed to an art form. I remind Government members that the Opposition in Queensland can attain government if it wins 51.4 per cent of the vote. That is not perfect. At the last State election in New South Wales we needed 52 per cent of the vote to get there. At the next Federal election we will need 52.3 per cent of the vote to get there. I am told that in South Australia we will need close to 54 per cent of the vote to attain the Treasury benches. If the Government is trying to stop cheating it should get its own house in order first before it starts imposing these things on the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Question No. 3 proposes local government recognition in the Constitution. There are about 836 local government bodies in Australia which elect in excess of 8,000 members and employ some 170,000 people. The Government applies its own selective principle. It wants to apply to local government in the States what it will not apply to itself where it has jurisdiction, in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. It is instructing the States to write this recognition into their constitutions which is a clear infringement of States rights. I remind Government members that four out of the six States already have local government recognition in their constitutions, anyhow. What this proposal is all about is whether the Commonwealth Government is going to be given power to force Tasmania and Queensland to write this into their constitutions. What Tasmania and Queensland do in this regard is their own business. If they do not want to do it yet, that is up to them. The Federal Government will not do it in the areas over which it has jurisdiction. What right do I have as a New South Welshman to vote on a referendum proposal that is not going to affect the people of New South Wales at all because it is already in our Constitution? What I will be voting for is whether I should have the right to force Tasmania to do it. That is totally wrong. The Government applies double standards.

The ratepayers of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, who already have this principle in their constitutions, have no greater or lesser rights-nor do the councils have any greater or lesser rights-than the people in Tasmania or Queensland because it does not mean a thing. New South Wales wrote it into its Constitution in 1986, Victoria in 1979, South Australia in 1980 and Western Australia in 1979. Local government councils really want adequate and secure funding, which they will not get under this Government. They also want protection against unfair dismissal and some sort of protection against amalgamation or regionalism, which this Government has tried to impose on them. All of these principles have been violated in recent years under a Labor government. None of these concerns are addressed by the referendum proposals to be put to the Australian people.

I remind people of the record of the coalition Government. That Government introduced personal income tax sharing. This Government has changed those arrangements and has introduced another less favourable formula. It was the previous Government, under the ministry of the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), which introduced the 2c a litre bicentennial road funding policy. This Government has tinkered with that scheme. We also introduced a forum so that local government could have a say. We did positive, meaningful things. We did not indulge in the sort of tokenism evidenced by this referendum proposal.

Tasmania and Queensland do not want this referendum proposal. The Australian Labor Party has a long-standing aim of centralising power in Canberra and administering that power through regional councils. When Tasmania put forward its proposal to the trade and national economic management committee of the Constitutional Commission it said that it did not want the proposal because it was a State matter. Queensland also said that it did not want it, for a similar reason. It said that the Federal Constitution was supposed to be concerned with Federal matters and that what was not listed in that Constitution should be left to the States. It said that the proposal would also encourage the Commonwealth to bypass the States and deal directly, and that that would weaken the States. It was concerned about High Court interpretations which might be contrary to the original intentions. It also pointed out that local authorities already have a very strong statutory basis, that their existence is not under threat and that, therefore, it is difficult to justify an alteration to the Constitution which is only symbolic. Local governments are created by the State parliaments and, therefore, recognition of them should come from the State parliaments. Local governments derive their existence, powers and responsibilities from State governments and they are, legally and in practice, a subordinate form of government. We on this side of the House support recognition where it properly belongs, namely, in the State Constitutions, if the States want to put it in their Constitutions. It should not in any sense be forced on them.

This local government proposal opens up a minefield of challenges in the High Court of Australia. We have already seen that, in the United States of America, as soon as these types of things are written down there are challenges. The courts in the United States are clogged with these sorts of challenges. This factor is totally unknown to us in Australia. The Australian Council of Local Government Associations has already flagged its intentions by saying that it does not see this recognition as symbolic and will try to expand it. It said that recognition will not be a purely symbolic gesture. It pointed out that, as Australia has supported the international declaration of local self-government in the United Nations, we should follow that up with constitutional recognition here. That opens up another minefield when we remember what happened with the external affairs power in the Franklin Dam case. There was a 3 : 2 High Court decision to give the Commonwealth power, via the external affairs powers, over States rights. States rights were smashed when that decision was brought down in this country by unelected High Court judges. More recently they have changed the clear meaning of section 92 of the Constitution. When people voice concern in this area it should be taken notice of.

I would like to see the Attorney-General spell out clearly what happens to areas in Australia where there is no local government. Areas in my electorate of Parkes that lie west of Wanaaring have no local government at all. The people do not pay rates; they make their own roads and get about their business without a local government authority. If the States are forced to write this into the Constitution, could it be interpreted that they will be forced to create local governments in areas where they do not have them now? There is also a worry concerning what powers will be extended to Aboriginal local councils. There is some talk that when the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is brought down later this year another 52 Aboriginal local councils will be set up. It is not spelt out in the Bill what this will mean for them. It is a totally unknown area of which we should be mindful.

It is informative to look at the evidence given to the distribution of powers committee of the Constitutional Commission. It received many submissions. One was from the Local Government Association of New South Wales, which wanted a separate chapter on local government in the Federal Constitution to provide for its existence-which this referendum is providing-as well as the exercise of certain powers, protection from unjust dismissal and a redistribution of powers between the three levels of government. None of those things has been granted. The Australian Council of Local Government Associations also endorsed a more expansive approach. I was pleased to see that the Country Women's Association of Australia and the Environment Law Commission opposed recognition because they believed it would lessen the power of State governments. The distribution of powers committee actually brought down a recommendation that there should not be any recognition because it was concerned about how the High Court would interpret this being written into the Constitution. It felt that the support for this referendum virtually came only from local government people and from no-one else. It also felt that the State should initiate it and that there was no threat to local government whatsoever. It also raised the point that there are in Australia some areas that do not have local government. It was also worried that the appointment of administrators could be made more difficult if this recognition was written into the Constitution. We on this side of the House are worried that, if this proposal is passed, local government could end up with more functions but without the necessary financial support to implement them.

Lastly, I wish to deal with the fourth proposal, which is nothing more than a mini-Bill of Rights. We have been through this argument over the last couple of years. The Government is now trying to introduce by the back door what was clearly thrown out by the people of Australia. We already have the right to trial by jury and the right to practise religion. The right to just compensation is to some extent protected by common law.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about justice?

—If the honourable member wants to talk about just compensation, perhaps he ought to give a copy of this Bill to the ex-Federal President of the Labor Party, who ripped coal rights off the people of New South Wales. They had to throw out that Government in the end so that people could get compensation. Just because governments include these things in constitutions does not necessarily mean that they will be carried out. One has only to go to Russia to see that it has some very fine sounding things in its Constitution, but that the rights of the people in that country are trodden on by the Government. We should also remember that, once these things are written down, they are actually limited. It is best if they are protected by common law and not written down. As I said, if they are written down, they will not necessarily be observed. It is instructive to look at what is left out. For example, there is in this Bill no provision for freedom of association. No doubt the Government is worried that compulsory unionism, which this Government supports and which we oppose, would go by the board if the freedom of association provision was included.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me briefly look at trial by jury. As the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) pointed out, this would allow the States to specify the number of jurors and to allow majority verdicts. This could mean very small juries, which may not be consistent with the concept of trial by jury. As to the proposal for just terms, there is no mention of appeal processes, which are very necessary. The freedom of religion proposal may actually validate extreme religious action in this country and could even be interpreted to restrict prayers in schools and prayers on public occasions, as has happened in the United States of America.

In conclusion, the National and Liberal parties believe these referendum proposals are totally unnecessary. The cost of the Constitutional Commission and of holding these referendums is going to be $40m, which this country cannot afford. We believe that the Australian people should reject them. I urge everybody to vote no to all four proposals when they are eventually put to the Australian people later this year.

Of course the shadow Cabinet wanted to split two Yes, two No, so of course he has covered himself. I think he is going to help us.

I notice the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the chamber. I think we have a lot of Liberals on our side on this issue and I think these referendum proposals have the best opportunity of being passed by the Australian public of any of the referendums that have been put over many years.

The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) also came out publicly with the statement that he was considering crossing the floor to vote with the Australian Labor Party. At least it is good to see that there are some men of principle in the Opposition, because this is only about political opportunism. It is a question of tactics. I will talk about constitutional recognition and local government later but, as I say, it is great to see that at least there are some people of principle. I suspect that as we go on we will not have the experience that we had in the identity card debate, like the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) said, where the Opposition ended up getting all its members back. I think more and more Liberals will defect and eventually the clone of Senator John Stone in this House, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), will have to turn his thoughts around and think about it again.

These Bills represent a genuine attempt by the Government and by the Attorney-General to update the Constitution, which is now almost a century old. None of the proposals benefits any particular political party. This is not about States rights or getting rid of the Senate. Those are simply furphies which the Opposition is putting up because it knows it is so divided that it has to grasp at any straw it can find. Any suggestion that this will in any way advantage the Labor Party throughout this country is pure and unmitigated rubbish. The hypocrisy of the Opposition in this matter is frankly beyond belief.

Let us look at the proposals. The four Bills address certain fundamental democratic rights. The first relates to the four-year terms. It relates to people's rights to a more effective registration of the mandate they give at elections through greater stability and responsibility of both Houses of parliament. What is sinister about that? The other one talks about free elections, about one vote one value. What is sinister about that? Where is the hidden agenda there? The next talks about recognition of local government. Again, what is wrong with that? There is talk about the fact that there is no necessity for it. If there is no necessity for it and if we want to make it a little clearer by putting it in the Constitution, what is wrong with that? It just shows the absolute hypocrisy of the Opposition's stance on this matter. Then to talk about trial by jury, and to say that people should vote No to that and No to fair compensation for land acquisition, is absolutely absurd. I ask those people listening to this debate, who will subsequently read about this in the paper, to take note of that. The fact is that those arguments are absolute rubbish. There is no good reason to say No to these referendums-none whatsoever.

The two proposals I particularly want to speak about tonight are the questions of fair elections and the recognition of local government. A headline in the Age newspaper of December 1987 sums up the situation of unfair boundaries in Australia by saying:
Western Australia has the worst gerrymander . . . but Sir Joh can claim that he has the best.

That is in fact the position. Sir Joh is no longer there, and it will not be long before the other fellow that took over from him will not be there either, because I am sure the people are going to vote yes to these proposals. That will give us the mechanism to ensure that that gerrymander is gone once and for all. Queensland's hopelessly rigged electoral system is notorious. At every election six out of 10 Queenslanders effectively vote to end the gerrymander but the value of their vote is diminished by the very system they are protesting against.

I shall give some facts on Queensland's gerrymander. As at December 1987 the seat of Logan had 25,398 voters, the highest number, and the seat of Roma had 8,256, the lowest number. The ratio is 3 : 08. In my electorate, the seat of Manly, which is the second largest, has approximately 24,000 electors. That is, the people of Roma have their voices heard three times as loudly as those of the people of Logan on the southern outskirts of Brisbane-a seat that is represented by the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Wayne Goss. Of course, they have three times the voting voice of the people in the State seat of Manly.

To illustrate its effectiveness, four of the six largest electorates in the State are Labor held. The five smallest electorates are all National Party seats. Yet the National Party tells us in this House that there is nothing wrong with the boundaries in Queensland. The National Party won 55 per cent of the seats while polling only 39.6 per cent of the vote in the 1986 elections. The Australian Labor Party won 30 seats with 41.3 per cent of the vote. It would have needed 53 per cent of the two-party preferred vote to win government.

Although it is true that the Australian Labor Party while in office many years ago-approximately 30 years ago-introduced a zonal system, in fairness I point out that at that time zonal systems existed in most other States. That is no excuse but, if there is such a thing as perfecting a gerrymander, it has been done by the Queensland National Party and that has kept it in office for almost 30 years. It is all right to have excuses. The Nationals advance two main excuses for the gerrymander: the first is that it is a legacy of the Labor days; and the second is that the system reflects the principle that the country requires better representation.

The fact is that people do not get fairer representation from having members sitting in the Parliament in George Street in Brisbane. We could say that the Labor Party voters in the industrial areas need to have three times as many votes as the people in country areas because of the particular concerns they may have. When our founding fathers drew up the Constitution almost a century ago there were no planes, no fast means of transport. The Constitution was written for the needs of those days and not today. Now one can travel to Brisbane in one hour whereas when the Constitution was drafted it took approximately six days by horse and cart. The Constitution needs to be changed and these moderate proposals are a way of doing it.

I want to give one other stark example. If the problems of distance are really the reason for the zonal system, why is the town of Mount Isa in the provincial city zone, which gives it reduced influence, when it is larger than many rural zone electorates and further from Brisbane? Another example is that of the town of Warwick, which is within two hours drive of Brisbane and has an enrolment of approximately 12,000. Townsville, which is as far from Brisbane as Melbourne is, has an enrolment of 21,000. This problem could be solved easily by a number of physical measures such as increased office facilities and that sort of thing.

One aspect that really concerns me is the refusal of the National Party particularly, which has spoken most strongly on this matter, to recognise local government. In my electorate of Bowman the Redlands Shire Council has been lobbying me since I became a member of this Parliament. The Council has said, `Mr Sciacca, you have to support us in the constitutional recognition of local government'. In case my friends in the National Party say, `Big deal', I inform them that the Council is held by conservatives. I am sorry to say that at the recent local government elections the Labor Party ran a team but not one of the 12 was elected. There is no question that the Council members are Labor Party inclined; they are conservatives.

I should like the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Parkes and other members of the National Party who will speak on the Bill, to go to Queensland and Tasmania. If they visit the local shires they will be eaten for breakfast. There is almost no opposition to the constitutional recognition of local government certainly throughout Queensland and probably throughout the whole country. The Liberal Party has buckled under to the National Party in this case. Senator John Stone is now calling the shots so far as the Opposition is concerned, whether it be on the question of immigration, a consumption tax, or these referendums. Senator John Stone is getting his way. It is a case of the tail wagging the dog.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you worry about that.

—The honourable member should not worry about that either because the members of the National Party are not doing too badly. The Leader of the Opposition is doing exactly what John Stone is telling him. I should not like to be in the shoes of the present Leader of the National Party because things are not going well for him.

SPEECH.PARA: Even the Liberal Mayor of the City of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson, has said that she strongly supports the question on the recognition of local government. I have many quotes but I do not have time to read them now. However, the international conventions on political rights all say that we should have one vote one value. There is no question that that principle should be implemented in this country and put into the Constitution. That way we could get rid of the gerrymander in Queensland once and for all. It could right the wrongs. We all know there is a problem in Western Australia. That has not stopped the Government from introducing this Bill. It will advantage other parties as much as it will advantage the Labor Party. It will advantage everyone. It is fair.

In conclusion, I point out that the Newspoll is already saying that approximately two-thirds of the population will vote Yes on these proposals. The Government will have support from the Liberal Party and from much of the National Party and conservatively controlled councils. We will win this fight, irrespective of whether the National Party and some of those that are left who still want to support the No vote continue with their campaign. I ask people to be rational about this question and not to be scared by the States rights argument or by the curtailment of Senate rights. I ask them to listen to the arguments quietly and patiently because they are voting for the right thing. I advocate a Yes vote. I congratulate the Attorney-General for introducing these moderate proposals. They deserve to be supported.

Government members-Oh!

Government members interjecting-
