—I am showing to the people of Australia the fact that this Government wants to divert their attention away from the real issues that should be addressed and that we should debate in this Parliament, issues such as homelessness, people who are sleeping in refuges and who need homes and the 700,000 people who have been forced into poverty. Parliament should be debating those issues rather than the issues that are before the House tonight, which have nothing to do with civil liberties, updating the Constitution or providing better government.
—The honourable member for Braddon may certainly draw a comparison, but he must not go into a debate on such issues because the House is debating the Constitution alteration Bills.

—I appreciate that. The Government knows it has its back to the wall. Look at the strategy the Government has adopted to get out of this situation. Firstly, it has said to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he must get out and meet the masses. Secondly, it has passed its financial responsibility for its problems on to the State Premiers, and that was done last week. Thirdly, it has said that it must get the Press right. The Government has pressurised journalists, requiring that they be members of a union to report the Australian Labor Party Conference. Fourthly, it has developed legislation that will create a diversion, and that is what honourable members are debating-legislation that is a diversion from the real issues currently facing the Australian people. That is why the legislation is before the House. It is pure, unadulterated political manipulation with members of the Government saying, `Create a diversion; let's get the heat off the Government's record of burgeoning overseas debt, increasing poverty and high taxation'.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the purpose of spending $6m on a commission whose report is basically obsolete and $34m on taking the people to a referendum based on political self-interest? That is what we are debating tonight-self-interest. The four Constitution alteration Bills are characterised by a reduction in the power of the Senate, centralisation of power in Canberra and strengthening constitutional law in contrast to common law. When the States were federated, a compact was established that the Senate would be a House of review established to protect the interests of the States and to ensure a continuity of experience.

The first Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill, establishes that a parliament could run for four years instead of three years-and I emphasise the word `could'-and that the term of the Senate should be reduced to four years. It does not mean that Parliament will run for four years; it does not guarantee four years in which governments can concentrate on running the nation without an eye to the next election. If the Government were serious about four-year parliaments, it would provide for a four-year fixed term. Instead of showing any conviction about four-year terms for the House of Representatives, the Government has shown its true colours by continuing its undermining of the powers of the Senate.

Ever since 1975-and we have heard it again tonight-the Labor Party has steadfastly refused to accept the umpire's decision. It has maintained the rage. It is dedicated to breaking the power of the Senate because of revenge. The honourable member for Bowman mentioned that there are many furphies about the effect of the Senate. If the Australian people want to see the hidden agenda I implore them to get a copy of the Australian Labor Party platform, resolutions and rules, turn to page 36 and look under the heading `Constitutional Reform'. It is all about doing away with the powers of the Senate and, ultimately, doing away with the Senate. That is the agenda. The Labor Party's prime concern is not about updating the Constitution; it is not about having moderate government at all. If it were, the Government would hold a referendum for four-year fixed periods with maintenance of the nexus between the House of Representatives and the Senate. Where previously power had effective checks and balances by being distributed between the people's House, the States House, and the courts, if this referendum is passed, the role of the Senate will be significantly reduced. The goal of the Labor Party is to use the ancient dripping on a stone principle and gradually move towards the abolition of the Senate.

The second referendum, if passed, would set the scene for the final phase of the strategy to be rid of the Senate. The Senate would then be the only House of parliament in Australia not elected on electorates of equal numbers. There are 13 major Houses of parliament in Australia and, if this proposal were passed, the Senate would be the only House of the 13 that would not be elected on electorates of basically equal numbers. It would then be only a matter of time before the people within the Labor Party put the argument that all Houses of parliament in Australia should be elected on the same basis. The days of the Senate as protector of States' interests would be numbered. Under those circumstances, the smaller States would be overwhelmed, outnumbered and ignored. I say to the people of Tasmania that, ultimately, 10 or 15 years down the track, the purpose behind this proposal is to give Tasmania two senators, South Australia six senators and Western Australia six senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least we will get more than Tasmania.

—The honourable member who mentioned that is from South Australia. The Newspoll in today's Australian fascinates me. I have been through the debate on the Australia Card and the debate on the Bill of Rights. Each time just after the proposals were put out, what did we find in the papers? It was only last night when I was preparing this speech that I wondered when we would see the first poll put out basically on behalf of the Government to try to mould the Australian people. A poll is out today indicating that the overwhelming majority of Australians at this stage are in favour of the proposals, even before they have heard the debates. When one looks at the way the questions have been put to the Australian people, of course they would favour them. However, honourable members should wait until the work has been done and the conservative people, the Liberal and National parties and their supporters around Australia, get to work and make sure the people understand what is involved. I assure the Labor Party that it will not win four States in Australia on these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: Setting the scene for a bitter and divisive debate between the small and large States is not what we should be doing in our bicentennial year, but that is what we are doing in this debate. It is not a legacy we should leave for our children. Not only is this Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, indicative of the craftiness and social engineering techniques of the Labor Party but also it illustrates the Labor Party's double standards. The second referendum is directed only towards obtaining equal electorates in the States and not the Commonwealth. Why does the Government not apply the same rules to the Commonwealth as it does to the States? There is no answer. There is dead silence. There are no interjections. Why not? It is because Government members know they cannot take the risk. If the Prime Minister really believed in equal sized electorates as a fundamental principle of democracy he would apply it to the Senate at the same time. He is trying to override the States. Surely the electoral boundaries of a State are a matter for the people of that State. They are not a matter for the Commonwealth.

How many constituents-certainly none in my State-have been complaining about the upper House? In Tasmania there is not a peep out of anybody about it. Only next week candidates in the smallest upper House electorate will be going to the people, that is, the people on the west coast of Tasmania, of whom there are about 6,000 in that electorate. I can tell the people on the west coast that if this referendum goes through they will not get an upper House representative for the west coast. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) did not want to tell them that. Nobody is clamouring for a reorganisation of boundaries in the upper House electorates of Tasmania.

In September, Australians will not be making a decision primarily about the size of electorates. They will be making their voices heard on whether they want to give more power to Canberra or whether they would prefer government to remain close to the people in the States. A Yes vote is a vote for centralism. A No vote is a vote for strong States within the Federation. We must make a decision as a nation. Do we believe that we are a Federation or not? If we do, we will vote No against these proposals.

Contrary to the rhetoric that this referendum proposal would stop the gerrymander, it would do no such thing. Why is it that at the 1987 Federal election the Government gained 58 per cent of the seats but only 45.8 per cent of the votes? No explanation is forthcoming from the Government. Not only that, the Government gained fewer votes than the National Party and the Liberal Party, yet it still won government; and yet Government members come in here complaining to us tonight about gerrymanders. It is absolutely ludicrous. We have the constant barrage of nonsense that this Bill would stop the gerrymanders. As I said earlier, the Government's first goal is to put in place an electoral structure that leaves the Senate as an oddball. That is what these proposals are all about. This Bill will not stop the gerrymander; it is not designed to, and it certainly will not do so.

The third Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill, is typical of legislation brought forward by this Government. It wants the High Court of Australia to have more constitutional grounds to make rules on which it can continue to make judgments that weaken the power of State governments. That is what has been going on for years and years now: judgments being made by the High Court to weaken the power of State governments. It wants people to be more under the thumb of governments. Recognition of local government will ultimately mean higher taxes. That is the basic story that we will be telling the electorate: it will ultimately mean higher taxes, and a playing off of State government against local government. Not only will there be a Premiers Conference, but also there will be a lord mayors conference, followed by a mayors conference, followed by a shire presidents and wardens conference, each haggling for its share of the tax. There will be more government, more tax. I thought we had gone past that stage in Australia and that people had turned the corner and wanted less tax and less government.

Instead of streamlining government, if passed, this referendum will create a financial, administrative nightmare. At present, the Commonwealth deals with State governments and State governments control local governments. That is how it should be and that is how it should remain. Why place in the Constitution the recognition of a third tier of government, the implications of which will be left to the High Court to determine? What will be the unintended consequences of this Bill? Will they be less government and lower taxes? Certainly not. Each time new government bodies are established or added recognition is given to government, there are bureaucrats who will find increased responsibilities that ultimately require more money. The people of Australia want smaller government and lower taxes. They will vote No to this third proposal.

Finally, I turn to the last Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill. As one of the people who campaigned vigorously against the Bill of Rights, I shall do the same on this proposal. I shall campaign vigorously against it, because the freedoms of the Australian people in regard to religion, their concept of having a right to a fair trial and the right to fair terms of compensation will not be protected by words in the Constitution or by governments. We have moved past that as a society. The reason why we have rights and freedoms in Australia is that the people in Australia are brought up on them. They believe them, they are part of their conscience, and we do not want governments parading around with nice sounding words, saying they will protect the freedoms and rights of Australian people. They certainly will not. Governments have never done that throughout the world and they will never do it in the future. In Australia people know what their rights are. The proposed legislation is redundant. There is no need for it, and I am sure the Australian people will vote against it.

SPEECH.PARA: All those people who have listened to this debate have heard the honourable member for Braddon say that if this goes through, the people in some western corner of Tasmania will lose their representation. For a long time I have believed that the Constitution ought to be taught in secondary schools. It ought to be a compulsory part of a citizenship course. I now certainly believe that it ought to be taught to the Liberal Party and National Party members; they ought to start an in-parliament school immediately.

The honourable member for Braddon said that we can, suddenly, somehow change the representation of Tasmania. Section 128 of the Constitution prevents that, unless the State agrees. Unless the State is willing to have such a change, it cannot be done. Therefore, it is blatant nonsense for the honourable member for Braddon to come forward and say that. To all those people listening to the debate, he then said that the proposed legislation does not affect the Commonwealth. I am amazed that the honourable member for Braddon would come in here and stand up and say that, yet the very first question on that part of fair elections says, `To provide for fair elections'-not just for the States but also-`for the House of Representatives'. Yet, the honourable member has the audacity to stand up in this place and try to tell those listening to this debate that somehow this is a misconstrued, misinformation piece of legislation that is determined to wipe out the States and which has no effect on the Commonwealth. What nonsense! What a lie! What a blatant untruth it is that the honourable member for Braddon should stand up here and say that when he knows it is untrue, when he knows that the Constitution protects the States, as I said, in section 128.

I take up my point that the Constitution ought to be taught in schools, because it is not the politicians' Constitution as many people believe; it is not the lawyers' Constitution, as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said when he introduced the proposed legislation. It is the people's Constitution, and it cannot be changed unless it is the will of the majority of the people and it is also the wish of the majority of the States. That has been proven since 1901, where there have been 38 referendums and only eight have been passed. It has been the will of the people when that has happened. I believe that the will of the people in 1988 will tidy up the Constitution to ensure that there are basic rights and freedoms.

What we have from Opposition members is a statement that they do not want the Constitution changed. They do not want the Constitution changed, and so we must take it, and we can only believe, that they are opposed to the propositions. One of the propositions is to ensure trial by jury. As honourable members appreciate, trial by jury is binding on the Commonwealth. In fact, section 80 of the Constitution requires that, where there is a trial and the trial is on indictment for any offence against the Commonwealth law, there must be trial by jury. This proposition is to ensure that where that trial relates to State or Territory law there shall be trial by jury. So we take it that the Liberal and National parties are against trial by jury.

The second point about freedoms is that there ought to be just terms for any acquisition of property. Again, had the honourable member for Braddon read the Constitution he would have known that section 51 (xxxi) clearly states that, where the Commonwealth is involved, there must be just terms. This will bind the States. I take it that the Liberal and National parties do not believe in just terms of compensation when acquisition takes place. That is what they are opposing. That is what they are against. Let members go out and say, `Where a State acquires your land we do not care if there are not just terms. We stand by the High Court decision that said that the States may acquire property on any terms which they may choose to provide in a statute, even though the terms are unjust'. The Liberal and National parties stand by that. They say, `We do not care'.

I see in the chamber an Opposition member who I know is a practising Christian. He will vote against the right to freedom of religion. He will vote against the States not having power to prohibit religious practice. He knows that section 16 of the Constitution prohibits the Commonwealth from having any sort of religious test for applicants for a job. But it does not prohibit the States. The States can have any sort of test they want. The honourable member is now saying that he opposes freedom of religion, that he opposes the practice of people pursuing their own religious beliefs. That is what he is going to do by voting against these matters. I say that it is disgusting. It is disgusting because time and again he has gone out on a platform talking about the rights of individuals, the rights of families and the rights of the churches; but when the time comes for him to put up, we find that he shuts up. I believe that Australians will vote against him.

The same applies to local governments, which are not recognised within the Constitution. The Labor Party believes they ought to be. The 850-odd local authorities throughout this country believe they ought to be. The 134 local authorities in Queensland, mainly National Party controlled, believe they ought to be. But the Opposition says no. I ask Opposition members to go out and tell the elected local authorities that they should not be recognised within the Constitution even though it is the Local Government Conference position and the local government position right across this nation. If those opposite say that they do not believe it, I believe the people will treat them as they ought to be treated-with thumbs down.

I move on to the issue that really interests me, that which relates to fair elections in which the people in country areas have a vote, not the sheep and the trees. That is what happens in my home State of Queensland where we have such a diversity and contrast in electorates that one starts to wonder why. It is not hard when one realises how the system works. There are four zones in the State: the south-eastern zone where there are 51 members; the provincial city zone where there are 13 members; the western and far northern zone where there are eight; and the country zone where there are 17. One only has to see the last election figures to realise what took place. At the last State election the National Party of Australia received 553,997 votes, or 39.6 per cent. For that it won 49 seats, which is 55 per cent of the Parliament. Under those boundaries a party can win 55 per cent of the seats with less than 40 per cent of the vote. The Labor Party received 577,000 votes or 41.4 per cent-and for that it got 30 seats and 33 per cent of the Parliament.

It amazes me that the Liberals will oppose this proposal because they are in a worse position. The Liberal Party of Australia got 230,310 votes, or 16.5 per cent of the vote, but won 10 seats, which was 11.2 per cent of the Parliament-a gerrymander that works against the wishes of the majority of the people. We have a combination of almost 58 per cent of the vote being given to the Liberal and Labor parties, yet they won 40 seats out of a parliament of 89. Yet the Liberals in this House have the audacity to say that they will stand by that position. How disgusting! How politically immoral!

There needs to be a change because of the way the system works: when an election begins the National Party starts off with at least 20 seats. The reason is that it has divided the State into four zones. There is a country zone, where the seats have been wound around the provincial cities. There are 17 seats in that zone. If we look at the number of people who vote in these areas we will find that they number 12,000, 13,000 or 14,000 voters. It is 25,000 voters in Brisbane, so a party needs twice as many people to elect someone in the city area as it does in the tiny boroughs that surround the provincial cities. Is it any wonder that the National Party wins?

The total Parliament is 89 seats. A party needs 45 seats to have a majority. The National Party starts with 20. It starts with 20 because the 20 seats are so structured, so drawn, that they pick up all the strong little National Party voting areas and bring them together. I do not mind so much that in the far western and northern areas we have a great disparity in the vote because I know, having an electorate with 53,000 square kilometres, how difficult it can be, even with the support of the competent staff I have, to service such an electorate. I know what it is like to go out to Warrego and to the far west of Gregory and the far northern parts around Mount Isa. I can understand having a disparity there, a tolerance; but not in these little boroughs around the capital cities where most are within 50 to 100 kilometres of cities such as Townsville, Mackay, Rockhampton and Bundaberg. They are a stone's throw in terms of distance in Queensland, yet the seats are so structured that no-one but the National Party can win them. It is wrong; it must be changed.

The only way in which it can be changed is through a referendum, because there is no way that the National Party of Queensland will want to change it. The only way in which it shall be changed is by changing the Constitution and saying to Australians that there ought to be fair elections at the Commonwealth level-which is something the honourable member for Braddon does not know about-fair elections at the State level and, I hope, one day fair elections for local authorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on probably one of the most important packages of Bills brought before this House in its history. It is interesting that these Bills should be brought before the House in the closing stages of our occupation of this old Parliament House. I wish in my comments on this package of legislation to address three questions which are central to clarifying the context, politics and substance of the Government's constitutional reform proposals. I wish to place on record why I believe these referendum proposals have been drafted, why I join with my coalition colleagues in opposing each of the proposals, and why I believe there has been such a concerted attack on the coalition's decision by media commentators.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be a mistake for voters to ignore the question of motive behind these propositions. The Government has a motive. In considering these proposals the first question any concerned voter should address is: Why has the Government pursued with such determination an agenda of extensive and fundamental revision of our Constitution? The reason is twofold. Firstly, socialist governments, no matter how moderate, find intolerable the constraints of constitutional government, bicameral parliaments and the rule of the law. Secondly, a government with the Fabian schooling and leadership which this Government boasts-there can be no denying that-has as a permanent agenda item the nurturing of an electoral mood conducive to the revision of the checks and balances of political power in Australia.

Should people think that I am unfair in this regard, I refer them first to the 1979 Boyer lectures by the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In that carefully considered articulation of political ideology he described our constitutional arrangements as `anachronistic lunacy'. He declared that there was no justification for `perpetuating this dangerous anachronism'. In regard to the States, he first confessed, `I do not have any idea what ``States rights'' are'; then he argued that the concept of States rights was not positively relevant to our economic realities; and finally he called for the elimination of the States. I then refer them to the Prime Minister's description of his Government's `more general and deeper, long-range task' in an address to the Fabian Society four years ago tomorrow. That task, he said, was `the establishing, in the mood and mind of the national, pre-eminent acceptance of the naturalness and inevitability of change and reform, as the authentic way of life'.

So the answer to the question of why there is this determined pursuit of constitutional revision via the Constitutional Commission is this: the Government would prefer to be free of the constraints of constitutional government in a federal system, with a bicameral parliament, and it hopes that the Constitutional Commission strategy will produce an electorate which values constitutional revision as an end in itself. It becomes perfectly obvious, in this light, why these particular proposals have been put to the people as the first instalment.

The reason these four proposals have been chosen from the comprehensive set of recommendations from the Commission is that they can be packaged as motherhood statements, opposition to which would expose one as reactionary and obstructionist. These proposals are the ones most likely to maximise opportunities to misrepresent opponents of constitutional revision. These proposals, therefore, are the best means of establishing a foothold for the process of extensive alteration of the Constitution still on the Government's agenda in this term of government. It has not finished yet: these four referendum Bills are only the beginning. I ask the questions: Who could possibly be against fair elections, especially in Queensland? Who could possibly be against fewer elections? Who could possibly be against giving local government the respect it is due? Who could possibly be against trial by jury? Now of course the question is not whether anyone is for or against such principles or goals; the question is whether constitutional alteration is the most appropriate or prudent means of supporting or achieving such principles and goals. Of course the answer is no. That brings me to the question of why my coalition colleagues and I are opposing these proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are opportunists.

—That is a very cheap comment. The Constitution of Australia was designed by prudent, wise and therefore conservative statesmen, both Labor and non-Labor, whose judgment 87 years of Federation, stability and prosperity have proven was sound. It should not be altered for trivial reasons. The balance of power which it establishes between the Federal and State governments, between the parliaments and the judiciary, and between the House of Representatives and the Senate should be revised only with extreme caution, and I do not believe this has happened on this occasion, nor should ambiguities with uncertain consequences be introduced into its language, and that has happened. These are the grounds which the coalition has considered and which have convinced us of the weight of the No case. The local government recognition proposal amounts to dangerous tokenism and interest group pacification-nothing more and nothing less. The specialist Constitutional Commission committee, appointed by the Government to examine this proposal, was honest enough to say so.
—It said no.

—It said no, but it was ultimately ignored by the Commission and the Government, both of which apparently felt it politically advantageous to win the praise of the local government lobby. Voters who want the role of local government strengthened or who have been concerned about the attacks of State governments on councils should be clear about this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: It will not prevent enforced amalgamations, wrongful dismissal or abolition of local government in parts of a State, for example, in the metropolitan business district of a capital city. But, as with any clause in a constitution, one never really knows how creative a reformist High Court Bench could be with even this token reference to local government. We might one day see the annual Premiers Conference followed by the mayhem of a mayors and shire presidents budget conference. At the moment, however, this proposal is designed for emotional effect rather than for strengthening local government or with any thought about future High Court hermeneutics.

The so-called fair electoral systems proposal involves an intervention of the Federal Parliament in the electoral affairs of the States. It attacks the fundamental principle of State autonomy, championed, for example, by Labor Premier Brian Burke in 1985 when he opposed Federal intervention to alter Western Australia's electoral system. It pretends to deal with gerrymanders but deals instead with malapportionment, clearly indicating that it is intended for use against Queensland and therefore is a matter of pragmatism rather than principle.

The four-year term proposal was introduced by the Attorney-General as a means `to a more effective registration of the mandate . . . through greater stability, responsibility and contemporaneity, in both Houses of the national Parliament'. That justification, in its specific wording, is important. Consider, for example, the Government's talk of its ID card mandate and its talk about the irresponsibility of a Senate which did not reflect the most recent electoral result. What this proposal aims at is the greater likelihood of an upper House mirroring politically the lower House in order to make life easier for the government of the day.

The Government could have had a four-year term proposal without attacking the Senate in this way. It claims that the dollar costs of separate Senate elections and the longer term for senators would be the unacceptable result. But the dollar cost of our bicameral parliamentary democracy should not be given as a serious reason to weaken that form of democracy. And by the Government's own argument the past suggests that senators would serve in practice, not eight years, as the Government claims, but six years as intended by the founding fathers. In any event, the purpose of the Senate was not to reflect current majority opinion but to provide accountability of the Parliament to the States and the long term interests of the nation. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you ask me, what is worse-an eight-year term for senators and the dollar costs of Senate elections or an ineffectual Senate which politically mirrors the House-I would suggest the latter. The Government risks that latter possibility in its proposal and I therefore will not support it.

The purpose of the bicameral arrangement in our Constitution is to provide a check on temporary majorities, momentary passions and short term electoral pressures. In the words of James Madison, architect of the American Constitution, which so influenced our own, the intention of our perhaps sometimes inconvenient bicameral Parliament is to secure the public good and private rights against the danger of a temporary majority and at the same time to preserve the spirit and the form of popular government.

Finally, the mini-Bill of Rights proposal suggests, as did the original Bill of Rights, that a deficiency exists in the common law protection of our rights, when it does not. It would introduce concepts whose interpretation would vary from High Court Bench to High Court Bench. For example, should High Court judges like the late Lionel Murphy be given the power to define `religious observance'? Finally, it champions rights compatible with current government priorities, but not rights whose constitutional recognition might embarrass it, such as the right to freedom of association in the face of compulsory unionism.

Before moving to my last point, let me raise one question which highlights the dangers of the mini-Bill of Rights proposal in the last clause. Is not the prayer Madam Speaker prays each day to commence our business a Christian religious observance? Could Madam Speaker assure me that it might not be challenged in the High Court if this proposal were carried in a referendum?

My last point concerns the concerted criticism by media commentators of the coalition decision to oppose all four proposals. The No cases for each of the proposals, considered separately, are reasonable, I believe, even if one disagrees with them. Why is it unreasonable, therefore, to decide to oppose them as a group? Many media commentators have simply revealed their own bias in their hostility to the coalition decision. They have suggested that political motives have overridden reasonable consideration of the merits of each proposal simply because they cannot accept that any reasonable person would not share their view. I assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and all those in my electorate of Macquarie that that was not and is simply not the case. The debate in the coalition was fair, comprehensive and lengthy. The decision to oppose these proposals was taken in full knowledge that it would be politically difficult to oppose, for example, what appeared to be motherhood statements. The media commentators share the ideological bias of this Government and should be ignored. The frightening aspect of their commentary is their inability to recognise intellectual disagreement and their decision to interpret an opposing judgment as mischief.

The coalition believes that these superficially attractive proposals are in fact imprudent and dangerous. We believe that they form part of a process designed to produce an extensive revision of our Constitution to fit the political needs of a Labor government. That is why we oppose this legislative package. That is why we are calling on people to give a great deal of time to considering the debate on these proposals before voting. That is why my colleagues and I will be campaigning tirelessly to achieve a No vote on each proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), a person for whom on a personal level I have a certain amount of respect, also peddled a lot of nonsense. He issued a Press statement today which happened to fall into my hands. He repeated some of the arguments in the speech that he has just made. The Press release stated:

I did not know that the people in cockies corner had so much power. I take off my hat to them. This is a desperate attempt to hold the coalition together at whatever cost. Stripped of all the cant, that is why the Opposition is urging a No vote and is opposing these proposed amendments this evening. The editorial in today's Australian stated:

It seems the Liberal Party is so terrified at the prospect of upsetting the National Party that it is prepared to oppose constitutional amendments that would strengthen Liberal democracy and safeguard private property.

It really is a sad comment on the Opposition. We hear a lot about the freedom of Opposition members to vote as their conscience dictates. They trot out this old line all the time. He indicated how much freedom Opposition members have on this issue, as did the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who said that any dissenting voters would be very quickly drawn back into line. I really cannot believe that all of those opposite-as I say, I have a fair amount of respect for most of them-are supportive of this stand. The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) in his contribution made much about how people's minds could be changed. We have seen a few examples of this. I have absolutely no doubt that the Nationals will run quite a strong scare campaign on these issues. I was interested to find out why they are opposed to them.

The first proposal is contained in a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. Most people would agree that it seems reasonable for the House of Representatives to sit for a four-year term. We hear much about the Senate being a States House and a House of review. I actually wish that the Senate would occasionally exercise some of that power of review that it is supposed to have. Do they think that the Senate should not go to the people and should not be answerable to the people for its actions? Is that their interpretation of democracy? A lot of rubbish has been spoken in this chamber this evening-unfortunately it will continue during the evening-not least of which was by the honourable member for Parkes. SPEECH.PARA: Let us deal now with the second question:
Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic Parliamentary elections throughout Australia?

In effect, that really means more power to Canberra. I must congratulate the Attorney-General on the drafting skill he has displayed. At first glance I would also vote Yes for question No. 2. Of course, who is against fair and democratic parliamentary elections? No-one that I know, and certainly no-one who has a commitment to parliamentary democracy in this country. That question really means that there will be one vote one value.

There are two major arguments against this: the first is that country electorates need some tolerance of votes between the number of voters a country electorate incorporates and the number in a city electorate. A few urban members of the Government tried to interject on that point, but I ask them to try to drive for six or seven hours, as I have to, from one end of the electorate to the other. The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) drive much further. What quality of representation can they provide to constituents who never have an opportunity to visit them? Members of the Government who represent urban electorates can drive from one end of their electorates to the other in five minutes and their constituents have easy access to them. So long as we keep enlarging country electorates to keep an even number of voters, the quality of representation of country people decreases. In any event, one vote one value is mostly observed at the Commonwealth level.

The second major objection that we have to this is that the Commonwealth is outrightly hypocritical because it is not requiring the Commonwealth electoral process to reflect the one vote one value principle. Tasmania with a population of 350,000 has 12 senators, the same number of senators as every other State, for example, New South Wales with its population of five million. Tasmania has five members in the House of Representatives, as guaranteed by the Constitution. I do not seek for one moment to upset that balance. I believe the smaller States need protection against the larger, more populous States, as was envisaged by the founding fathers. The Attorney-General cannot have his cake and eat it as well. He cannot require the States to have one vote one value, and not the Commonwealth.

Let us differentiate between malapportionment, which is the differing of numbers between separate electorates, and gerrymanders. The Attorney-General should not try to tell us that the Party with which he is associated is not a past, present and probably future expert at gerrymandering seats. The Liberal-National Party coalition in New South Wales had to achieve 52 per cent of the vote to defeat the Unsworth Labor Government. At the Commonwealth level the two conservative parties will need to poll 52.3 per cent of the two-party preferred vote to defeat the Labor Government at the next election. We will do it! Referenda questions like these will assist us and make our task somewhat easier. Gerrymandering is very different from malapportionment. We need to separate them. The mere fact of one vote one value does not guarantee an equitable voting basis.
Let us move to the third question, which reads:
Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government?

As previous speakers have said, this is a matter of some controversy within the representatives of the third tier of government. No-one on the Opposition side underestimates the importance of local government, but local government must understand two things: firstly, like it or not, it is a creature of State governments; secondly, this motherhood statement to be inserted in the Constitution does nothing to appease its basic concerns, which are protection against dismissal, forced amalgamation or the achievement of guaranteed financing such as for road funding.

The honourable member for Throsby is delving into the realms of the ridiculous when he claims that local government regards constitutional recognition as its most important battle. It is not; it is road funding. The honourable member speaks about members on this side of the House being out of touch. I suggest that he go back and ask representatives of local government which they would prefer: some proper entitlement to road funding or constitutional recognition. This Government, in the five years it has been in power, has frozen road funding to approximately $1.2 billion. So over those five years in real terms road funding has decreased by 25 per cent, or $300m. How any member of the Government can offer this sop to local government and keep a straight face is beyond me.

There are other worries associated with this question, such as the minefield it is opening up to legal interpretation. We do not know whether it will end in the High Court of Australia. However, given the experiences of the past few years, the High Court, relying on the foreign affairs power, is more than likely to extend the powers of the third tier of government in a way that will encroach on either State or Commonwealth governments. In any event, the concerns that the third tier of government has about being under threat-and to my knowledge it is not under threat from the Government; it is certainly not from the Opposition-and any fears it has about guaranteeing its future existence should be directed towards State governments, most of which have recognised local government in their own constitutions.
I shall now refer to the fourth and final question:

Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by the Government?

Regrettably, I have run out of time. As a lawyer, I would like to debate these issues with the Attorney-General-where they fit into our common law system and how they are an attempt to insert in the Constitution a Bill of Rights which has already been overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian people, as the Attorney-General knows only too well. He was not the Attorney-General at the time, but he was lukewarm-in fact quite dismissive, if the truth be known-when that proposal was first put. In essence, these supposed rights already exist, firstly, within our common law-they are under no threat-and, secondly, within the Constitution.

In summary, the Opposition will attack these referenda questions with great fervour because it believes strongly in the No case. Anyone who votes for any of these four questions is voting for a centralist government far removed from the daily concerns of all ordinary Australians.

—The political drama of 1983 in Queensland is only just being avoided here in 1988. In other words, the split between the Liberal and the National parties in Queensland in 1983 is only marginally being avoided here, because the National Party of Australia has won the day on these propositions. It has convinced the Leader of the Opposition that he should vote No on all four propositions, even though he does not believe in that No position. It is simply a matter of the tail wagging the dog.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party has won the day and, for a short while, a split has been avoided. That did not happen in 1983 in Queensland. The National Party and the Liberal Party split. There is still great bitterness, and the Liberal members in Queensland will be supporting this proposition. I think it might be sweet revenge for Terry White, in particular, and I will be an interested observer, I must admit. If our one vote one value proposition succeeds in Queensland, as it surely will, those political turncoats, Don Lane, Brian Austin and Beryce Nelson, who initially sat in the Parliament of Queensland as Liberals and now sit as Nationals, will be defeated once we are able to redraw the boundaries in Queensland.

I have done my best to search for arguments to defend the notion of the gerrymander or, indeed, to criticise our proposition. It has been somewhat difficult because there is not always a great deal written down. I suppose it is hard, when one is simply rationalising a position of political interest, to produce arguments of some substance. Nevertheless, I can draw from the minority report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters One Vote, One Value. That minority report, which was introduced earlier today, raises seven arguments which are supposed to be against the notion of introducing a referendum on one vote one value. I will also draw on extracts from a book by Alan Metcalfe entitled In their own right: The rise to power of Joh's Nationals. Alan Metcalfe, however inadequately, attempts to put some arguments in favour of malapportionment, so I shall peruse those arguments with some interest.
Firstly, I come back to the minority report from the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The first proposition is that the minority believed:

it inappropriate for any constitutional referenda to proceed without it first being considered by a conference of elected representatives of the Commonwealth and the States, i.e., a Constitutional Convention.

It is well known that we tried, and that it was Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen who took his people out of the last Constitutional Convention, ransacked it, ruined it and refused to sit down and negotiate reasonable proposals to be put to referendum. It has been tried before. It does not appear to have worked. What the Attorney-General was able to do for the people of Australia was to arrange for a Constitutional Commission. That Commission was able to move widely around Australia, and I understand that it took over 4,000 submissions. I believe that it is a far more powerful mechanism for understanding the needs, wishes and desires of the electorate than are even the elected members of various State parliaments and the Federal Parliament. I say that because we already understand the views of Federal and State parliamentarians. Therefore, the first point in the dissenting report is simply out of date. We tried the Constitutional Convention and it did not work; it was ruined by the National Party of Australia. We took the alternative line and produced some excellent propositions arising from the Constitutional Convention.
The second point of the dissenting report is:
It is not appropriate to recommend a referendum on a matter which would alter not only the Commonwealth Constitution but also the relationship between the States and Commonwealth . . .

In this case, we come up against this old proposition that somehow we are interfering in the Federation-the relationship between the States and the Commonwealth. The truth is that the question of one vote one value-that is, changing electoral boundaries in a State-has no impact whatever on the relationship between the States and the Federal Government. It is a proposition to place State elections on the same basis as a Federal election. So the second point of the dissenting report is wide of the mark.
The third point states:
The proposal will not ensure fair and democratic elections.
That is followed up in the fifth point:
The majority report of the Committee acknowledges that:

(i) the enactment of electoral laws limiting enrolment differences between electorates to an arbitrary 10 per cent would not prevent or eliminate the gerrymandering of electoral boundaries for the political advantage of one group.

We all agree that we may not knock out gerrymandering by this proposition, but we can certainly knock out malapportionment. Nobody would pretend that we can solve all the problems of providing fair boundaries through the means of one vote one value, but we can certainly go part of the way. And I still have not heard from the Opposition a proposition that would enable us to knock out gerrymandering.

The fact that the Opposition does not put forward such a proposition reveals its true position: it is simply not interested. Therefore, it should not criticise us for not doing enough. We are doing the best we can. We have put forward the proposition of one vote one value, and it will stop malapportionment. If the Opposition has a better idea, it should tell us, but I suspect that it will not tell us as it is not at all interested. As for our trying to solve all the problems relating to fair voting with the proposition of one vote one value, we never claimed that we would do so.

A point mentioned before is that it is possible to have an imbalance between the number of seats held by a party and the percentage of the vote. We all know that. Under a single member electorate system it is possible for a party to hold a bare majority of the vote but have a greater majority of the seats. There is no doubt about that. My Party has been fortunate enough in the last three elections, despite the fact that our popular vote has decreased a little, to have the number of seats we hold increase. That is not a problem. The fact is that we are able to hold critical seats at the margin. Under a fair system of electoral boundaries, if the Government holds a majority of the vote there is no problem if it perhaps holds more than a majority of the seats. The fact is that when a party slips marginally below that majority of votes it almost invariably loses government-the majority of seats.

So we do not pretend that the one vote one value system will solve all the problems of gerrymandering, but it will certainly solve the problems of malapportionment. Point 5 (ii) of the dissenting report states:

The Australian Constitution itself does not provide for one vote one value in that each original State is guaranteed 12 senators and at least 5 seats in the House of Representatives, irrespective of population . . .

It is argued that this has introduced some sort of malapportionment for the Senate and the House of Representatives in Tasmania. I hope that the conservatives are not arguing that we should have fewer seats in Tasmania as they would be at a serious disadvantage if that were so. We understand that there is a guaranteed number of seats in Tasmania. We understand that there is a guaranteed number of senators for each State, but that is part of the Federation, that is the way it is. That is the agreement that was written many years ago and we are not seeking to change that now. It would simply be too much. Again, the Opposition teases us to do the impossible when, in fact, we seek to do the possible and the right thing. Is it an argument that we should be changing the federal system and the Senate system when we are seeking to bring the States, as far as possible, into line with the important House in this system, the House of Representatives.
I would like to present a few points made in Alan Metcalfe's book. Metcalfe attempts, very bravely, to put the essential argument in favour of malapportionment. About one vote one value he says:

At first hearing, it sounds a totally fair proposition to the average, not-so-interested voter. Everyone's vote should be equal; that's what democracy is all about. The reality of life in sparsely and unevenly settled Queensland . . . makes it impossible for votes to be equal in value. It is true that each vote can be counted only once. It is not true, however, that the value of each person's vote can be the same in Queensland if based on demographic grounds alone. It is simply not true to suggest that the value of the vote of a person living in a remote area of the state such as Burketown, Windorah or Coen is equal to the vote of the person living in the suburbs of Brisbane or the Gold Coast. It is akin to saying that a hundred hectares of land in Burketown is worth a hundred hectares of land in Queen Street, Brisbane, or downtown Surfers Paradise. Both are the same size-
this is the key bit-

but the return from each area is vastly different. Built-in economic protection for these areas such as adequate and indexed zonal tax concessions and across-the-board compensating additional expenditure to equalise the degree of disadvantage, would alleviate the disparity . . .

Here is the essential confusion between political weighting and economic weighting. There is already a myriad of cross-subsidy between the city and the bush. We have subsidies on all sorts of things such as roads, telephones, postage stamps and petrol. That is a question for the economy but we do not weight political considerations based on economic considerations. We have the Loan Council and the Inter-State Commission, the concern of which is to equalise on the basis of economic disparity. Who could possibly answer the question of who should determine political weightings? If political weightings are made equal we will all have an equal opportunity to influence the polity. But economic weighting should never be built into the Parliament itself. I will quote again from Metcalfe's book what I suspect is the underlying rationale for the Opposition's argument. Metcalfe says:

With most to lose from the implementation of such a system the National Party has been beaten hands down by the Labor and Liberal parties media-sell campaign on the ``gerrymander''. In the areas that it affects must, such as central, northern and western Queensland, it should have been a crushing electoral winner for the Nationals. These areas would lose several parliamentary seats to the heavily populated south-east corner of the state and, as every politician worth his salt should know, you don't win votes taking things away from people.

So Alan Metcalfe, a very senior member of the National Party in Queensland, puts the true proposition, that it does not want to miss out. It is all about self-interest. It has built itself a cosy little system which gives it a head start and it will make sure that it hangs on to it. That is what it is about. Forget the rationalisations and the attempt to make debate; it is about self-interest. Let me complete my speech with a final extract from Metcalfe's book. Metcalfe argues:
. . . it is obvious that under any democratic system of Government some consideration has to be given for the less fortunate.

Who are the less fortunate? Are these the people that he said created all the wealth out in the rural areas? Are these the less fortunate people? Surely the less fortunate are among the unemployed, the migrants, the women and the Aborigines. Perhaps we should give two votes to each person in those groups. Would that be fair weighting? They cannot have it both ways. On the one hand they want to receive weighting because they claim to be the most productive people but, on the other hand, they claim to be less fortunate and therefore in need of political weighting.

Let us look at the proposals and the questions that have been developed. Even today Mr Gary Morgan, who has spent a lifetime developing questions to obtain the right answers, has questioned the slanting of the questions and their preparation for the referendum. Mr Gary Morgan places great emphasis on the way that questions are asked in his public opinion polling to obtain the correct answers. He raised today the issue that the very simple questions that are going to be put to the Australian people in fact prejudge the outcome. The first one refers to an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for a four-year maximum term for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. The little word `both' is in there. It does not refer to the Senate. The question asks people, `Do you approve of this proposition?'. It is all very simple, straightforward and encouraging.

The second question refers to an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. Again, it is all very simple and straightforward. I am sure many people throughout Australia would accept this on face value as being a reasonable proposition. The third question refers to an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government. Again, this is a straightforward sort of proposition: it seems reasonable enough. Of course, the fourth question has a few points in its hidden agenda, which I have referred to as the Bill of Rights type approach. They all seem quite reasonable and straightforward until one looks at the arguments behind them.

Of course, the Opposition has no qualms with the proposition that four-year terms would be good for the House of Representatives and for government in general. Indeed, a great deal is to be said in favour of four-year terms, as was outlined by other members and in the report of the Constitutional Commission, which claimed that the extra year would give government more time properly to implement economic policies and not to be continually recovering from or preparing for an election. That is reasonable, especially having in mind that since 1946 the average term of government has been 2 years and 2 months. The Constitutional Commission stated that the short electoral cycle tends to place pressure on governments to adopt expedient short-term measures for the purposes of electoral success.

However, we have repeatedly reminded the Government that we support the corresponding increase in the term of the Senate. The coalition opposes the same four-year term for senators instead of, under the bicameral system, extending the term for senators to eight years. To introduce a four-year term for senators would reduce the power of the Senate, exactly what the Government is trying to do. It goes against the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission. This proposal effectively enforces permanent double dissolutions and removes restrictions on a Prime Minister from calling early elections. Other members on this side of the House have referred to this in the debate tonight. Half-Senate elections with an election for the House of Representatives require a quota of 14.3 per cent of the vote for election to the Senate. In a double dissolution, brought about by the blocking of Supply or a multiple rejection of Bills, the quota required for election to the Senate is reduced to 7.7 per cent. Again, these two figures have been referred to by members on this side of the House.

It is a proven fact that a double dissolution favours minority parties, which do nothing but stall the legislative process. Take the last election for instance: the Australian Democrats were rescued from political oblivion by the calling of a double dissolution at the last moment. They were able to recover their electoral position. The argument that the public would never accept eight-year terms is quite ridiculous. In Victoria, members of the Legislative Council, the upper House, are elected for eight years after the change of terms in government in 1985. Personally, I see some problems in having senators elected for such long periods, but if the Government wants to put forward the proposition that the parliamentary term be extended to four years it has to go along with the proposition that senators be elected for eight years so that the role of the Senate is preserved as a House of review in a bicameral structure and that the Senate not change automatically on the change of the House of Representatives. Of course, the role of the States would be preserved under the Opposition's proposal. It must be remembered that the diminution of the power of the States is a slap in the face for them. TALK.START.PARA: —It is still there.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the one vote one value proposition. Most of the arguments in this chamber tonight have been directed at Queensland. If one looks at the historical perspective in Queensland, one sees that it was the ALP that set up the zonal system back in the 1930s in order to gain electoral advantage. Of course, it was not one vote one value that was the key element in that proposal; it was the boundaries within the zonal system which allowed parties on both sides of politics to gain advantage. The National Party in Queensland is taking advantage of the ALP's earlier electoral arrangements to gain the advantages of government. It is interesting to note also that the Labor Party abolished the upper House in Queensland. It is paying the price for this lack of control of one House in that State.
