The 10 per cent variation, which has been referred to by other members, is acceptable to all political parties in order to take account of community of interest, geography and the ability of members to service their areas. If, by chance, we agree to this strange proposition, I wonder how the Federal Government will implement the one vote one value through every State electoral commissioner. Under what mechanical, legal arrangement could this Parliament, for the implementation of its constitutional requirement, force the State electoral commissioners to implement its particular proposals? Would every redistribution by State governments be challenged in the High Court of Australia on the basis of the boundaries and the voting patterns? There is enough argument anyway about redistributions in every State and in this place. I challenge the Government to explain to the people of Australia how we could implement this change.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the Bill.
—Yes, but I am interested to know how we will do it on a practical and mechanical basis so that every State government will be able to meet those requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to local government. I support the view that this is a token proposition and that constitutional recognition will do nothing for local government. The section 119 which has been put forward does not even mention the word `Commonwealth' and the design of this amendment is to look after two States which are not mentioned as being operated under their own State government administrations. Everyone in this Parliament is aware that State governments administer local government and they organise the way in which they operate under local government Acts. The funding arrangements and the extra powers are State obligations. In Victoria, would the amalgamation proposals that were rejected by the people come under Federal jurisdiction? That is most unlikely. The Federal grants that have been directed to local government through State governments are matters for State authorities. If this proposal were agreed to, there would be considerable argument as to the legality of the Federal Government's role in local government. I support local government-it does a very good job at the local level-but I see no merit in this proposal and can find no argument to support it.

Moving to the fourth question, again a range of arguments worries most people. Trial by jury has been with us in Australia for a long time. It goes back to Magna Carta in 1215. Every Australian presumes that trial by jury is his automatic right and privilege. There is no need to have it incorporated in the Constitution. The religious freedom that everyone enjoys is a right enjoyed without legal definition, and that is the way it should be. As with the Bill of Rights, the drawing up of legal constitutional rights brings with it difficulties in interpretation. Everyone in Australia enjoys religious freedom. There is no question that this is the way it should remain-under the present arrangements. In regard to property rights, the Federal Government wishes to legislate that State governments do the correct and proper thing in paying due amounts in property acquisitions. This constitutional change will not help to overcome the difficulties in arbitrating the value of the property of landowners when either State governments or the Federal government acquire land for public purposes.

Finally, I add my support to the Opposition's position. We will vigorously oppose these referendum proposals. We will fight them everywhere in Australia. We will win the fight because our arguments are sound. People understand that if these changes take place their lives will be affected, the power of the Senate will be reduced, and the centralisation of power to Canberra-a long term Labor Party aim-will be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have ever heard a weaker case put against reform than the case that has been put in this House tonight and is being put in the community, unless it was on the last occasion when these same questions were before the Australian people. This is not the first occasion. What does the Opposition really find objectionable in guaranteeing all Australians, through all parliaments, the right to freedom of religion? It is guaranteed by the Commonwealth Constitution that the States have no such inhibitions and could pass, if they were so minded, legislation to establish a religion, to ban a religion or any other practice which they so desired. Members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia are in this House tonight. They have told us a dozen times that they will vigorously oppose the right to freedom of religion in Australia, for all Australians under all jurisdictions.
—Incredible.

—It is quite incredible. The Commonwealth Constitution provides the right to trial by jury, but no such inhibition exists in respect of the State parliaments. This would entrench in the Commonwealth Constitution the same binding right of a person to a trial by jury as now applies to Commonwealth legislation. The Liberal and National parties are opposed to the Australian people having this right.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) said that it is a right that we have. It is not a right that we have. It is a right which we have currently in alterable legislation within State jurisdictions. It is not an entrenched right in Australia as it applies only to the Commonwealth Parliament. The Liberal and National parties say that this is a disposable right, like a paper towel. If a government which happens to be elected at some future time decides to dispose of that right in the States and to change the freedom of religion provisions which we would think are permanent but are not necessarily so, the Liberal and National parties say that that is all right; we should not have in the Constitution any provision which guarantees that right under State law. I should remind this House that the great body of law covering the Australian people in respect of matters of that nature is State law, not Commonwealth law.

The Commonwealth Constitution also provides a right to fair compensation should the Commonwealth seek to acquire or take over a person's property. No such rights exist in respect of the State parliaments. It is a power limited to laws made by the Commonwealth Parliament. One wonders what the National Party's argument would be should a State parliament go back to past practices and invoke provisions which existed not that long ago in Victoria where the valuation of property which was acquired was backdated 10 years; when land was acquired in Victoria in the 1960s, the valuations were at 1951 values and the people who owned properties were robbed legally. The Liberal and National parties are saying that we should not have a provision in the Commonwealth Constitution-the Constitution which would govern all governments in Australia-to provide the right to fair compensation for the owners of that property. There are recent examples of State governments not providing fair compensation. They have an absolute right to legislate in any way they desire.

There are no constitutional rights for the Australian people with respect to fair compensation in the acquisition of their property. It applies with the Commonwealth. The Opposition says that it should not apply where the great bulk of acquisition takes place-at a State level. I wonder what the justification for such a stand can be. There is only one-political opportunism of the worst type. A political party which says that it represents the free enterprise system, which says that it is opposed to big government, which wears its religious fervour on its shirt sleeves as a badge-it has to show it because it does not have much conviction-and which says that it believes in the rights and freedoms of the community, is going to the electorate to oppose the freedom of religion as a right, fair compensation and trial by jury. What a fraud it is. There is no other word to describe it.

This is not the first time the question of recognition of local government has been put to the electorate. It was put in 1974 in a different form and in much more substance. Tonight honourable members brushed this question aside on the basis that it does not provide any real powers. It certainly does not-as some honourable members opposite have suggested-provide for the Commonwealth Parliament to take over legislative responsibility. That is and will stay a State responsibility. It guarantees the right of existence of local government-no more and no less-and does not give the Commonwealth legislative authority, as some would suggest.

What did we do when this question was before us previously? It was then a more substantive question; nevertheless it was a question on local government. These sorts of statements were made: `This power will put the power of control over local government in the hands of the Commonwealth Parliament' and `the Commonwealth Parliament will be able to bribe local government'. That is what was said in 1974 by honourable members opposite. It was a totally specious, politically opportunist argument because the State governments of the day, all conservative, did not want any inhibitions on their right to manipulate local government in any way in which they so desired. The honourable member for Corangamite suggested that the Victorian Government was seeking to manipulate local government. Opposition members campaigned for a referendum only a few years ago to protect the right of State governments to do what they liked with local government. They are still saying the same things. They have no commitment to local government. They have a commitment to some people who have influence in the community and can deliver to them the political influence that they desire and desperately seek to restore to themselves.

I come to the major question in these referendum proposals. The first and, I must say, probably the least important is that for four-year parliaments and four-year terms for senators. We debated this question a few years ago. The Liberal and National parties have regularly sought to portray the Senate as a States House. But when the question of one vote one value comes up, they argue that it is not really a States House and that it should be treated in the same manner as the House of Representatives.

So that there can be no argument about the Senate's basis of operation, I inform the House that the Australian Senate was derived from the United States Senate on the basis of representation of the geographic areas of the various States. In the United States there has been a Supreme Court ruling on one vote one value in respect of representation in the lower Houses of the state legislatures and the House of Representatives. Representation by senators varies from under half a million electors in Delaware and Vermont to a figure approaching 50 million electors in California and New York. That variation is accepted because the Senate is not considered to be the same as the House of Representatives, but a House that is structured differently to represent different points of view. The last comparison with the United States Senate disappeared when that method was chosen, because the Australian Senate has never, since Federation, acted as a States House. Since the introduction of proportional representation in 1949 the Senate has been totally a political House and has voted on political lines on every question which has come before it in that entire period, other than on those few questions which have concerned matters of conscience and free votes.

The Senate is a political House. The majority of senators for the major parties are appointed, not elected. If a person is No. 1 or No. 2 on the Senate ticket for one of the major parties in any State in mainland Australia, he will be elected as a senator. It is immaterial whether the term is eight years or four years. The facts are that if a person gets the nod from the executive of his party, the electors have no say in whether he is elected. Every member of this House ought to be honest enough at least to acknowledge the truth of that matter. Senators do not vote in blocs as States. They have not done so other than on those occasions before the introduction of proportional representation when on several occasions the Senate had all members of the one political philosphy representing a State. There was an occasion when there was only one Opposition senator.

We have heard the argument about simultaneous elections and half-Senate elections almost ad infinitum. It is always put as a plot to destroy the power of the Senate. What utter rubbish! In the last 16 years no senator has served a six-year term. The last senator to complete a six-year term completed it in 1967. Every Senate election since that time has taken place at the same time as the House of Representatives election. There have been three short terms of the House of Representatives in modern times to bring it back in line with the Senate following a double dissolution or a dissolution of the House of Representatives for opportunistic reasons by the government of the day. They occurred in 1977 and 1984. It will continue to occur while we have separate sets of circumstances relating to the terms of both Houses.

In Victoria at the last occasion of simultaneous elections the government of the day opposed them because they demeaned the upper House. It had passed legislation at the time of every election since 1961 to have simultaneous elections. But in some way simultaneous elections are supposed to diminish the power of the Senate. Is any honourable member prepared to say now that the power of the Senate is any less today as a result of having at the last two elections a House of Representatives and half-Senate election and a double dissolution respectively while the election before those was a double dissolution and the two elections before that were half-Senate and House of Representatives elections? Is any honourable member prepared to say that that has in any way diminished the power of the Senate at all? Of course it has not.

Simultaneous elections are a matter of fact. The one thing I would like to say in addition to that is that we have heard some specious argument that by bringing the House of Representatives and the Senate into simultaneous election mode we will in some way bring about a situation which is different from that which exists when we have a fixed term for the Senate. On every occasion when the Senate has gone to an election on its own, the public has treated that election as a joke. That has demeaned the Senate and the minor parties have won seats in almost every State in Australia. The argument put up by the Opposition has no validity whatsoever in fact.

In regard to the argument for an eight-year term for senators, how many honourable members really think that a senator elected in 1980 is relevant to current political thought when, in fact, the term of such a senator under an eight-year term would not be due to expire until the middle of next year? There is no reason why senators have to be fossils to function properly. In fact, they may well function a lot better if their terms were fixed to that of the House of Representatives and they faced their electors every four years. Under the proposals the Opposition is putting forward with an eight-year term and the automatic replacement of a senator who ceases to function, resigns or such-for example, Senator Wood-such a senator's replacement could serve 15 years in the Senate and face only one election. One election in 15 years-fossils! Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the No case for simultaneous elections at the 1984 referendums. I do that because I think it is important that the Australian community--

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the guidelines that successive Speakers have outlined are that it can only be tables or such things that cannot be read into the record. The honourable member might wish to read his document into the record and that would solve his problem.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not want to read the whole thing into the record. I think that the House would understand the basis of the campaign put forward by the Opposition against simultaneous elections in 1974. These are the major points of a major constitutional reform debate. The first is runaway inflation. The Opposition did not want simultaneous elections because of runaway inflation. The other points are: absurdly high interest rates, staggering tax payments and irresponsible government spending. That is the most opportunistic, most dishonest type of argument which could possibly be put to the Australian people. It has nothing to do with the question at all and it is political opportunism. The one other item which is on the paper is democratic elections. I ask: Why are the conservative parties in this country afraid of the electorate? They have always been afraid of the electorate. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) acknowledged, when he answered an interjection, that he is happy to win elections by any means, including rigging.

SPEECH.PARA: If the conservative parties in this Parliament and in this country cannot get elected under a system where every Australian is treated as equal and is given the democratic rights to which he is entitled, they are not entitled to power. For the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to say that he believes in the States, and that where there is a gerrymander of the type that exists in Queensland, it can be altered only by the electoral defeat of a government which cannot be defeated at the polls because of the gerrymander, it is a cop-out; no more and no less. The real reason the Opposition is opposing these referendums is not for any high principle, not for any protection of the Australian people; it is because it has not got enough guts to stand up and be counted in the name of democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate I wish to speak solely to the so-called Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill. There are two concepts here that are very often confused. The first is that of equality and the second is that of fairness. Equality in electoral terms relates to malapportionment and it relates to how different numbers of people may exist in different electorates. The concept of fairness relates to the way the boundaries are drawn and to what bias might exist towards one party or the other. Effectively we have a two-party system. Over 90 per cent of the people in this country vote for the party of their choice and not for an individual candidate. Fairness is deemed to be where a party that wins 50 per cent of the vote plus one is entitled to form the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What sort of relationship is there between fairness and equity? Two examples stand out in Australian history since the Second World War. The first is the Commonwealth. In 1962 a redistribution was disallowed by the Federal Parliament. The last redistribution before that applied before the 1955 election. So when the 1966 election came around, we had the most malapportioned boundaries for any election in Australia since the Second World War. That 1966 election was the fairest election that this country has had since the formation of the Commonwealth of Australia, because the bias that existed in the two-party system was the least we had had in 40 years. So while the numbers of electors were different, there was very little bias to one party or the other.

There was a redistribution in South Australia before the 1956 election, and there was not another until 1968; 12 years later. In 1968 South Australia had the most malapportioned boundaries for any State or Federal election in Australia since the Second World War. Yet that 1968 election was the fairest that South Australia had had since the Second World War. It was fair because there was no bias in the system towards one party or the other. The party that got the majority of votes formed the Government.

Equity and fairness are two totally independent areas. So what exists today? Three States and the Commonwealth have so-called one vote one value. I would like to read out what the Liberal Party of Australia would need to win government in those States. In Victoria the Liberal Party would form government with 51.3 per cent of the vote; in South Australia, 52.2 per cent; and in New South Wales it formed government with 52.8 per cent of the vote. In the Commonwealth it would need 52.5 per cent of the vote to form government. So in these States and the Commonwealth that have so-called one vote one value, the Liberal and National parties need an average of 52.2 per cent of the vote to form government. Where is the fairness in that? I ask honourable members to compare that with the two States that do not have so-called one vote one value. In Western Australia the Liberal and National parties would form government with 47.8 per cent of the vote. In Queensland the coalition would form government with 48.7 per cent of the vote. That is an average of 48.3 per cent. So in the so-called one vote one value States there is a bias of 2.2 per cent. In the States without one vote one value there is a bias of 1.7 per cent. So equality has nothing to do with fairness.

I have heard a lot tonight about the gerrymander in Queensland. The criticisms made do not stand up to the facts. Over the last five elections in each State and the Commonwealth the bias was as follows: in Queensland there has been an average bias of 1.5 per cent; in Victoria, 3.3 per cent; in New South Wales, 4.3 per cent; in South Australia, 4.9 per cent; in Western Australia, 3.5 per cent; and, for the Commonwealth, there has been an average bias of 3.2 per cent. Unquestionably and consistently over the past 15 years, Queensland has been the fairest State in this country for the Australian Labor Party. Anyone who asserts anything different just has not looked at the figures. There is no question that there is a bias in the Queensland system against the Liberal Party and, being a member of the Liberal Party, obviously that is of concern to me. The fact here in Australia and overseas is that any party's representation in parliament is not a function simply of the vote it gets; if anything, it seems to vary with the third power and with the proportion of the vote it gets. That means that a small party will actually get a very small percentage of the representation. It affects the Liberals adversely in Queensland and it affects the Nationals adversely in Victoria, and there is really very little that can be done about that.

I would like to speak specifically about some points that honourable members have raised in the debate tonight. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said that our stance was simply an attempt to hold the coalition together. As a member of the Liberal Party I have consistently argued strongly against the legislation because it will do nothing to increase fairness in elections and, if anything, will make elections manifestly more unfair. He also talked of the freedom of choice that we in the conservative parties often tout, and suggested that perhaps we might exercise that freedom of choice. When the votes are taken the honourable member for Throsby will indeed see some members of the coalition exercising that freedom of choice. Perhaps he might contrast that to the case of a former member of his own party. When former Senator Georges from Queensland exercised his freedom of choice he was forced to leave the Labor Party.

The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) said that everyone's vote should be equal. Where is the equality when 52.8 per cent of the people in New South Wales have to vote for the Liberal Party for it to be elected to government? The honourable member for Petrie also said the Government does not attempt to pretend that this proposal will solve the problem of gerrymandering; it will solve the problem of malapportionment. That is absolutely correct. It will not solve the problem of gerrymandering; it will make it worse. Maybe it will solve the problem of malapportionment but I would strongly argue that no problem exists because what malapportionment does exist if anything serves to make elections fairer. I give an example of Western Australia. In seeking to solve the so-called problem of malapportionment, with a 15 per cent tolerance in the size of electorates, the Liberal Party in Western Australia will now need 53.1 per cent of the vote to win government. If this Bill is passed and the limit is reduced to 10 per cent, the Liberal and National parties in Western Australia will need something approaching 55 per cent of the vote to form government. Where is the fairness in that?

The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) said that the Opposition was afraid of elections and that it could not be elected by people having equal votes. We are certainly not afraid of elections but, no, we cannot be elected when Bills are introduced that will bring in a gerrymander in this country so that in every State and in the Commonwealth it is necessary for the Liberal and National parties to gain significantly more than 50 per cent of the vote to win government.

I have spoken tonight because I wish to place on record my strong opposition to this Bill. I also wish to go on the record as saying that I am totally committed to the concept of fair and democratic elections. But where is the fairness when there is significant bias to the Labor Party in every State in Australia? Where is the fairness when this Bill will significantly increase that gerrymander in Western Australia and Queensland? How is democracy served by severely disadvantaging the Liberal and National parties and helping the Australian Labor Party win with a minority of the vote? I believe the Bill will be defeated at the referendum. The Opposition is not afraid of the voters and for that reason is taking an unpopular decision and is prepared to put its case to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 18 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that when the World Heritage Committee at its meeting in Sydney in October 1981 included Kakadu National Park in the World Heritage List it (a) noted that the Government intended to proclaim additional areas in the Alligator Rivers Region as part of Kakadu National Park and (b) recommended that (i) such additional areas be included in the site inscribed on the World Heritage List and (ii) the environmental protection measures specified in the relevant legislation continue to be enforced in the region.
(2) Are the environmental protection measures still being enforced.
(3) Have proposals been made to the Government to change the environmental protection measures; if so, what was the (a) nature, (b) date and (c) source of the proposals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Environmental protection measures for the Kakadu region are being enforced through provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1978 and other Commonwealth and Northern Territory legislation.

(3) The Government has received a great many representations from organisations and individuals proposing changes of some kind to the environment protection measures for the Kakadu region. In view of the excessive time and resources it would take to compile, I do not propose to list the nature, date and source of these representations.

(4) (a) The Hawke Government proclaimed Stage 2 of Kakadu National Park in February 1984. Approximately 65% of the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases was added to Kakadu National Park, as Stage 3, in June 1987, with the remainder of the leases being proclaimed a Conservation Zone under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. The Government is currently considering re-defining the boundary of the Conservation Zone to take more detailed account of the natural and cultural values, and further geological information. The boundary changes would also correct some minor anomalies and inaccuracies in the original proclamation. A re-definition of the Conservation Zone boundary could result in some areas of the Conservation Zone being added to Kakadu National Park and some areas of the Park being added to the Conservation Zone. Under the provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, any proposal involving removal of areas from Kakadu National Park is subject to a 60 day public review period and approval of both Houses of Parliament.

(4) (b) In September 1986 the Government decided to take immediate steps to seek the addition of Stage 2 of Kakadu National Park to the current World Heritage site, and made a submission to the World Heritage Committee. Australia requested deferment of the submission by the World Heritage Committee because of legal action taken in Australia by Peko Wallsend Ltd and associated companies. This legal action eventually ended in favour of the Commonwealth and the Government then reactivated the submission. The World Heritage Committee, in December 1987, decided to include Stage 2 in the site inscribed on the World Heritage List. The Government is not in a position to consider possible additions to the World Heritage site until the boundaries of the Conservation Zone have been finalised.

(5) (a) Subject to any necessary parliamentary processes revisions to the Conservation Zone boundary of Kakadu Stage 3 may be expected early in 1988. A five year exploration and resource assessment program will be conducted in the Conservation Zone to help determine, by the end of that period, which further areas should be added to the Park. The Government's intention is that ultimately as much of the Conservation Zone as possible will be incorporated in the Park and that only mining projects of major economic significance, not merely economic viability, will be excluded from the Park.

(5) (b) See (4) (b). It should be noted that the Government can only nominate areas for World Heritage listing. The decision on whether or not the nomination is included on the World Heritage List is a matter for the World Heritage Committee of UNESCO. In making its decision on Kakadu Stage 2, the World Heritage Committee encouraged the Australian authorities to consider further extending the World Heritage site to include Stage 3 of the National Park and to modify the boundaries of Stages 1 and 2 in order to protect the entire catchment area, and to include the cultural values to the East of the present National Park.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 14 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures have been taken by the Australian Customs Service to protect people from the consumption of imported foods contaminated by the radioactive fall-out from the Chernobyl accident.
(2) What screening procedures are in place to check radioactivity in imported foodstuffs.
(3) What has been the result of the screening so far.
(4) Have any shipments of foodstuffs been rejected.
(5) What are the details of the code of safety practices covering radioactivity in foodstuffs, including details of the permitted levels of radioactivity in the listed foods covered by the code.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following assessment, by officers of the then Department of Health, of overseas information regarding the extent of contamination, an IDC, chaired by the Department of Health recommended that a program be implemented to check foodstuffs from countries suspected of being contaminated by fall-out from the Chernobyl accident. These countries were grouped into two lists. List 2 countries (Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, Turkey and USSR) are those countries close to and including the USSR, where the radioactive fall-out was highest and the potential for food contamination was greatest. List 1 countries (Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Federal Republic of Germany, Finland, France, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Monaco, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, San Marino, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom and Yugoslavia) are those where the fall-out was much lower and which were known to impose limits on the contamination in food for the domestic and export markets.

The Australian Customs Service, on advice from the Australian Radiation Laboratory of the Department of Community Services and Health, has developed profiles on goods and countries which may have been contaminated. These profiles are designed to flag targeted importation and allow Customs to assess whether the requirements of the Australian Radiation Laboratory are being met.

(2) All food consignments from List 2 countries are required to be accompanied by certificates giving the caesium-137 concentration in them. If this concentration is less than 100 becquerels per kilogram, standing arrangements with the Department of Community Service and health provide for the foodstuffs to pass through Customs without delay; if greater than 100 becquerels per kilogram, a permit to import is required from that department before Customs will release them. Permits are issued if the risk to health is assessed as negligible. Special clearance is not required for foodstuffs imported from List 1 countries.

Apart from the certification referred to above, foodstuffs imported from List 1 and List 2 countries are subject to a computer directed random sampling and testing program. In this program, the consignments undergo a pre-screening check for radioactivity, samples from the shipment must be submitted to an approved Australian laboratory for analysis and certification. Clearance procedures through Customs are then the same as for imports from List 2 countries.

(3) My colleague, the Minister for Community Services and Health informs me that, up to the present time, moist foodstuffs coming into Australia, whether caught in the random sampling program or accompanied by certificates have shown zero or very low levels of radioactivity (i.e. much less than 100 becquerels per kilogram). Only a few items, such as hazelnuts and some herbs have shown levels higher than 100 becquerels per kilogram, but they have not posed a risk to health. They are often used in processed foods, e.g. hazelnuts in chocolate, herbs in tomato sauce and the concentration in consumed foods would then be very much less than 100 becquerels per kilogram.

Because the levels in most foodstuffs have been found to be very low, resources are better spent in checking particular commodities and the program has been adapted to do this. This approach allows for checking foodstuffs which may have originated in affected countries and which have been transhipped into and re-exported from other countries, either after further processing or not.
(4) The Australian Radiation Laboratory advises that no shipments of foodstuffs have been rejected.

(5) The Australian Radiation Laboratory also advises that the there is no code of safe practice covering radioactivity in foodstuffs in Australia, but standards for this are under consideration. Maximum permitted levels, if set, would differ with the various types of foodstuffs, the consumption rates and the radionuclides. At a World Health Organisation meeting held in Geneva last September, a working group prepared harmonized standards of radioactivity in foodstuffs for universal use. For caesium-137, these standards were a few thousand becquerels per kilogram in major dietary components such as herbs and spices. These standards are many times greater than the levels found in foodstuffs after the Chernobyl accident.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 20 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Where did the concept of a Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) or Civil Aviation Corporation (CAC) originate?
(2) When was the CAA or some such similar body first proposed or discussed within the Minister's Department?
(3) What consultation has taken place between the Minister's Department and the industry concerning the CAA?
(4) When did industry consultation commence?
(5) When was the Government's intention to establish the CAA or CAC first announced publicly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It is difficult to identify where and when the concept of a Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) or similar body originated. I am advised that prior to the Hawke Government's election to office, a suggestion was made for the establishment of some form of independent corporation to operate the air traffic services system in Australia, and that this suggestion is understood to have originated outside the then Department of Transport. In November 1984, the then Minister for Aviation the Hon. K. C. Beazley, MP, in an address to the Annual Conference of the General Aviation Association raised the possibility that following establishment of the Federal Airports Corporation, remaining elements of the then Department of Aviation in due course might be placed outside the Public Service framework in a body akin to the US Federal Aviation Administration or the UK Civil Aviation Authority.

(3), (4) and (5) In October 1986 I announced, as then Minister for Aviation, that the Government had taken an in-principle decision to set up a Civil Aviation Corporation to provide and operate the civil airways system in Australia. Detailed proposals were to be brought back to the Government for consideration after consultation with industry and staff associations. Whether regulatory responsibilities should reside with the Corporation was one of the issues to be considered.

Consultation with the aviation industry was initiated by me in November 1986 in a meeting with the Aviation Industry Advisory Council (AVIAC). I also initiated consultation with staff associations. Subsequently a senior officer of the former Department was seconded to hold consultations with interested parties and obtain their views on the functions, composition, etc. of the proposed Corporation. A discussion paper he prepared was considered by a meeting of the Committee of Advisers to AVIAC in April 1987.

The Government's decision to proceed with establishment of a Civil Aviation Authority, which was to include safety regulation among its functions, was announced by the Minister for Transport and Communications in Parliament on 7 October 1987.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 20 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was Mr Willoughby of the Minister's Department seconded in 1986 to head a task force to examine options for the establishment of a Civil Aviation Authority (CAA); if so, did Mr Willoughby produce a draft or final report?
(2) Why were the task force reports never released to the public or staff associations for comment?
(3) If the task force report was not finalised, (a) why not and (b) on what basis did the Government make its decisions concerning the final structure of the CAA?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An in-principle decision by the Government to establish a Civil Aviation Corporation was announced by me, as Minister for Aviation, in October 1986. In subsequent meetings with the Aviation Industry Advisory Council (AVIAC), and separately with a number of staff associations, it was indicated that consultation on the functions, composition, etc. of such a body would be undertaken through a task force located within the former Department. This proposal was not proceeded with in its original form because a sufficient number of suitable officers could not be released from normal duties at the time. Mr Willoughby, Regional Director for Victoria/Tasmania, undertook consultations with interested parties. While the description of ``task force'' was retained, Mr Willoughby was the sole member.

(2) and (3) An initial report prepared by Mr Willoughby was discussed with the Committee of Advisors to AVIAC in April 1987. Consultation was suspended after national elections were called, and it was subsequently decided to proceed with establishment of a Civil Aviation Authority on the basis of consultations already held. This decision was announced by the Minister for Transport and Communications in October 1987. The Minister later met with a number of staff associations and discussed with them the rationale for the Government's decision.
